output: Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, I apologize once again for my delay.
This year marks the European Year of Intercultural Dialogue.
The engagement of everyone and the perception that education, knowledge, and the intertwining of different cultures with one another is crucial are now established facts.
Therefore, multiple initiatives associated with this year have been undertaken by the various areas of action and intervention.
In this context, the Erasmus Mundus program also plays its part, and a new regulation is already in place within this new perspective.

The Erasmus Mundus programme has constituted an important contribution to the creation of centres of excellence within the EU, which will, in a way, help sustain the brain drain outside of the European Union, as well as represent a noteworthy role in

in the promotion of European values among nationals of third countries who come here to study and who find in the old continent a cultural and linguistic diversity that acts as an attractive and distinct pole from models existing elsewhere in the world.
However, dialogue and interculturality have suffered considerably to survive.

The issue of visas for Erasmus Mundus students and the frequent difficulties in obtaining and renewing them often lead to them experiencing a state of semi-irregularity within the European Union, as they attend master's programs but with tourist visas and, at times, precarious arrangements.
It is considered of the greatest relevance and urgency to seek a solution that allows for solidity, transparency, and effectiveness in the issuance of pre-student visas.
Also crucial is knowledge of the language that enables cultural appreciation and mutual interaction, beyond purely academic proficiency; therefore, we can absolutely guarantee this premise.
To conclude, a word of thanks to the Member for Sarnez for the way she conducted the entire process and for the balanced report she produced.

Mr. President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, the authorization for the granting of State aid for the modernization and renewal of fishing fleets in the outermost regions should be possible only until the end of 2009, or should it remain in force indefinitely.
The specific characteristics of fishing activity in these regions justify the granting of these subsidies beyond 2009, without any minimal detriment to the marine environment.
Subsidies for the modernization and renewal of fleets in ultraperipheral regions for an indefinite period do not signify permanent and inherent aid.
would be immediately suspended if studies and assessments by the Scientific Council and the Regional Advisory Boards indicated the need for such action.
This is the solution that would best suit the very specific reality of fishing in the outermost regions.

The same reasons that underpin for the fishermen of each RUP (Regional Unit of Fisheries) an exclusive fishing reserve up to the seed also justify a differentiated treatment regarding aid for the modernization and renewal of the fleet.
Fortunately, within the Fisheries Committee, the best solutions were found that can address the specific characteristics of fishing in the outermost regions.

Mr. President, Mr. President, Commissioner Almunia, President of the Eurogroup, I want to congratulate not only the rapporteurs, but also the Commission for the initiative of producing this text, the assessment of the ten years of the Economic and Monetary Union.
It is a strategic text, and this analysis was fundamental.
The euro, as has been stated here today, is an undeniable success.

From Lisbon to Helsinki, from Dublin to Bratislava, the Euro has demonstrated resilience and solidity even during the severe turbulence we have witnessed, and it is clearly important that the borders of this club be expanded.
But the times we live in put the solidity of the European project to the test daily in many other dimensions.
The euro, as I mentioned, is a central instrument in the operation of the financial system.

However, the Commission’s own text clearly points to the fundamental conclusion that neither the growth of the real economy nor convergence, in either social or spatial terms, accompanied this success.
Conversely, the Commission concludes clearly that disparities have worsened dramatically during the decade of the single currency's operation.
This divergence affects regions of my country, particularly northern Portugal, but also other regions of member states.

The impacts of the single monetary policy, particularly due to the extremely high exchange rate, have disproportionately affected regions more exposed to international competition and those with higher export volumes.
Today, the crisis resulting from the deregulation of financial markets is violently impacting the real economy and further exacerbating the situation of many citizens and many regions.

These regions—those exposed to international competition, those dependent on small and medium-sized enterprises, those in which access to credit is most important—are today being victimized by this process and even face the threat of depression.
Mr. President, Commissioner, President of the Eurogroup, the success of the euro depends on the trust that European citizens place in it.
The most powerful European countries have already initiated the process of revitalizing their national economies.
We have the case, in particular, of initiatives concerning the automotive industry.
But, in Europe, it is more than that.
It must be considerably more than the more or less coordinated sum of national policies.
The time has come to transform the euro into a central tool of Europe, supporting a robust currency but also a robust real economy, and to ensure the proper functioning of the euro.
of mechanisms that guarantee the central objective of achieving social and regional convergence, because it is at the essence, at the core of the European project.
Debates concerning the coordination of economic policies within the Eurozone today possess a reinforced and undeniable impact and relevance.
But coordinating national policies is not enough.
More is needed.

Having a Lisbon strategy—which is a summation of national initiatives—and a stability and growth pact, which applies differentiated pressure to the various countries that utilize it and which they must adhere to, are limitations to which the limited budget we have adds.
Crises generate opportunities.
The monetary union can only be sustained by a convergence of well-being among the member countries that comprise it, irrespective of their citizens, irrespective of where they were born.
What other way would we have of mobilizing citizens for the single currency?

The Commission must live up to its own assessment, and that is why we eagerly await the concrete proposals that the Commission will bring to this Plenary on 26 November and will present to European citizens.

It is essential that, emerging from this crisis, a new phase of the Union be launched, in which the consolidation and strength of the financial system are accompanied by genuine prosperity comprised of cohesion and an economic citizenship as well.

Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, this oral question presented to the European Commission by Gerardo Gagliotti, on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development of this Parliament, is entirely justified and relevant.

In truth, the reasons leading the Council to block the reform of the Solidarity Fund must be made clear, given its inability to reach an agreement on a common position that would allow the legislative process to proceed.
It is difficult to discern the reasons underlying the Council's position, save perhaps for petty financial considerations.
Doesn't the Council desire a more agile and immediate response to natural disasters that occur?

I do not want the Council to permit this type of swift response to be given to other types of catastrophes, such as severe industrial accidents, terrorist attacks, or serious situations concerning public health.

It is important that these questions have a clear answer, just as it is important to clarify the European Commission’s view of this situation and whether it intends to take any measures to unblock the legislative process.
The value of solidarity must also be fully realized in this area.
The citizens would not understand it at all if we were not.
I wish to state that I wanted to protest against the declaration made by Mrs. Lulling, which seeks to condition the vote of the deputies in this house, and this conditioning makes no sense.

The interpretation you are offering is one that we do not share, and it is only in that sense that I would like to ask my colleagues who know what they are dealing with, who know that we are defending other interests—the interests of public health, the interest of citizens, and the interest of the countries that genuinely vote in favor of the report—
Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, for the past two months, the political and media agenda has been dominated by the financial and economic crisis.
The referendum in Ireland or the difficulties in the Czech Republic regarding the Treaty of Lisbon receive scant coverage in the media.

Don't you think that now the Commission's information and communication strategy should be reinforced with the necessity and urgency of the Lisbon Treaty coming into effect, also as a political response to confront and overcome the crisis in which we are living?
Madam President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, at that moment the powers of the world had the international financial system in their grasp.
They were seeking a handcrafted detail, and it was past due.
And therefore, perhaps it is time to resolve another problem now, one we have heard about for decades.
For decades we have heard this music of ignoble plundering of resources, how many times, as now again in the Congo, over the blood of the populations.

I believe it is also the time to pursue these companies, to pursue this ignoble trade, to freeze the accounts through which the profits of shame from this mineral exploitation circulate and where they are deposited – an exploitation that comes at the cost of the blood and suffering of the populations.
I do not understand why these companies are not listed in the same way that we have already compiled a blacklist of terrorist organizations.

And I don’t understand why the international community is unable to pursue those businesspeople who, strictly speaking, are not businesspeople, but authentic bandits who jeopardize regional and global security.
I urge the French Presidency and the Commission to develop an international initiative to that effect.
We have heard here today on several occasions that a crisis typically generates an opportunity, and so it does.
And if we wish to seize the opportunity that is open to us, the agenda is easy to ascertain.
First, we know, at the European Union level, the need we have to introduce mechanisms of transparency, regulation, and supervision in financial markets.
It is not necessary for your Commissioner Macri to launch further consultations, nor is it required that the Presidency analyze and invoke additional studies.
There are more proposals; it simply requires looking at the proposals that were promptly put forward by the socialists, and that many of them were subsequently adopted by this Parliament.
Secondly, internationally, Europe cannot occupy an international space passively.

She must be an active agent in the construction of the new international order; she must be the champion of a new architecture that does not leave black holes in the system, as tax havens do at present.
Thirdly, we heard here today, Mr. President of the Commission, that there is a reluctance in the coordination of strategies at the level of the different Member States.
It is true that, had we not heard, for so long, from many members of the Commission, that markets self-regulate and that the State should remain aloof.
that financial markets have no impact on growth or employment, perhaps there would be a more active and effective spirit of solidarity at the level of different countries.
But today's proposal is nothing more than a first step. When compared with the programs of China and the United States, however, it
does not sufficiently clarify what the objective is, and the objective must be employment, and thirdly, because a European programme cannot be a sum of national agendas.
Today is the moment to demonstrate to the citizens of Europe that Europe is a network of rights, also economic, which protect them in times of crisis, in terms.
solidarity, a growth program, and support for small and medium-sized enterprises that, at this moment, are not seeing the results of the interventions implemented at the banking level.
The real economy is precisely that, and we are here as Europeans to show citizens that Europe is here too, and above all, because of them. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, it is with particular satisfaction that I present myself before you to outline the work done, work accomplished in conjunction with everyone on this initiative report.
For me and for all those who collaborated in the unfolding of this process, we can say that we have done our work.

To everyone, in particular to the shadow rapporteurs from the various political groups who worked so diligently to reach agreements for the future, to the regional development staff always available, notably Miguel Tel Cremades and Elisa da Fara,

To the staff of the PSE, to Lilla and Petros, to the European Commission, which consistently made itself represented by its many diverse directorates-general, a situation necessitated by such a brilliant report, followed the work closely and diligently, striving to ensure its successful completion.
To my office and, in particular, to Joana Benziño, my sincere thanks to all of you for a more harmonious and structured development of coastal regions and for tourism within the European Union.
The 27 member states of the European Union collectively possess over 89 kilometers of coastal zones.
It exhibits a variety of very particular characteristics that, depending on their location, are defined either by cosmopolitanism, if we were speaking of cities like Lisbon, Copenhagen, Stockholm, or

the difficulties of existing in peripheral or ultraperipheral regions, with problems of connections to major urban areas or with accelerated contexts of desertification, such as the Algarve, Liguria, the Canary Islands, or Madeira.
One way or another, everyone identifies with the notion of coastline and coastal zone and lives daily the advantages and disadvantages associated with them.
According to available data up to 2010, approximately 75% of humanity will reside in coastal zones. These zones
According to the circuits and relationships between them, we define as the 50 kilometers in a straight line that run from the coastline to inland areas.
Yes, regions and not detached maritime zones lacking an integrated vision that these matters so desperately need and that our ancestors would also endorse.
Here, this population will concentrate in search of opportunities and economic synergies, and in many cases, with the expectation that these will revolve around tourism.
Thus, the evident need for a pragmatic and integrated vision of the impact of tourism on coastal zones took hold of our minds and led us to take action.

In the current context of financial crisis, in which the impact on the real economy becomes increasingly insurmountable, tourism emerges as a sector with enormous potential to be directly or indirectly affected in a severe manner.

Regions, which for their development have an overwhelming or total dependence on this, see their activity threatened and view the future with distrust, especially because tourism is not presently a competence of the European Union.
However, articulated measures can and should be taken, and the spirit imbued in the Treaty of Lisbon reflects this same tendency.
However, waiting until the entry into force of the Treaty to begin acting is waiting for the stage at which we will weep over spilt milk.
The current political and tourist activity, and the fragile reality of the regions that depend on it, demand urgent and effective action from us.

The fact that these are zones structurally dependent on tourism, as an employment generator, despite often being seasonal employment, this labor-intensive activity cannot be overlooked in a context of pressure on urban areas and unemployment.

Therefore, this report that we bring to you here and now, which was already of the greatest opportunity and urgency when the Committee on Regional Development of this House decided to promote it, must now be viewed as a priority for the European Commission and the European Council.

Priority should be given to the numerous initiatives it incorporates, as well as those that enjoy its explicit support and have already been disseminated by other institutions, alongside the measures adopted in the emergency plan.

of the Commission, among which I highlight the review of the Globalization Support Fund, in which the issues associated with this sector and the shock it is currently subject to should obviously be covered.

It is crucial to ensure the development of new segments of the economy in these coastal zones, guaranteeing their social and environmental sustainability and promoting the real integration of different sectoral policies, such as the maritime sector, transportation,

energy, the existing instruments of cohesion on the ground, the new policy for quality products incorporated by the revision of the CAP with the announcement of the EFSC report and the new tourism products in these coastal zones, taking into account their crucial contribution to the European economy.
The implementation of an appropriate and holistic vision for this policy should become a reality in the near term within the European Union.

And, to conclude, Mr. President, only with the clear articulation of these instruments and swift, effective action involving all partners already on the ground can we guarantee that we will have in the European Union a sustainable and future-proof coastal tourism sector.
Mr. President, Commissioner, Minister, eJustice is an important step in accessing the law, justice, and courts.
I would like to congratulate myself on the initiative, commend the rapporteur, and the French Presidency.

The EJSTIS was one of the projects under discussion, and Portugal, during its presidency, is tasked with leading the development and implementation of a pilot project that will allow all citizens access to services from other Member States in a simpler, more affordable, more comfortable way, and in their own language.
This multilingual portal should be designed to serve citizens and businesses seeking legal support and basic legal advice regarding legal and cross-border issues.
The e Justice must be coordinated and sworn in by a responsible unit, which will also coordinate the contributions of the various Member States and their articulation with this responsible unit.
Justice will serve the citizen and strengthen our democracy.
I congratulate the launch of the portal in December 2009.
Mr. President, Madam President, ladies and gentlemen colleagues, I congratulate the work of Carlos Coelho, of the Honourable Member Martin Rühi, and of the other Members of Parliament.
In December 2004, the Council adopted a regulation establishing standards for the security features and biometric data of passports and travel documents issued by Member States.
Now, we needed to take new steps to combat the abduction and trafficking of children.
The use of passports by children, in accordance with the principle of one person, one passport, may be the fundamental means of winning this difficult and important struggle.

In my country, Portugal, the collection of fingerprints from children aged six and upwards is already an established practice with a long tradition, and perhaps for that reason, it does not cause me any objection.
As a proponent of the European cause, I believe that, in this matter, harmonization is important.
It reassures me to know that Member States, such as Portugal, which long ago established the age of six as the minimum for collecting fingerprints, will not have to amend national legislation.
It should be emphasized that the security of passports, which is being strengthened today, does not solely reside in the existence of the passport itself.

The passport, in and of itself, corresponds to an increase in the level of security, which ranges from the presentation of the necessary documents for passport issuance, followed by the collection of biometric data, to verification and matching at cross-border control points.
This report represents a further step towards affirming the rights of the individual and ensuring their safety.
Mr. President, first of all, I would like to welcome the rapporteur, Alexander Lambsdorff, and the shadow rapporteurs, with particular mention of Barbara Weiler.
Dear colleagues, I deem it essential to advance towards the integration of national defence markets and even the strategic coordination of their productions.

We must move forward effectively with the necessary specificities and precautions towards the application of the essential market rules to the defense industries, increasing transparency in the tenders organized and the contracts signed involving the Member States of the European Union.
However, at the same time, we must assist in the development of conditions that enable the greatest competitiveness of European equipment and products in global markets.

It seems important that this directive can guarantee progress in the legal framework relating to public contracts in the areas of defence and security, advancing the construction of the internal market.

while respecting, of course, the interests and rights of the Member States, particularly in the area of security, and notably those involved in the manufacture of armaments, ammunition, and security equipment, such as my own country.

I would also underscore the provisions that facilitate easier access for small and medium-sized enterprises to this market, particularly through the improvement of subcontracting rules and the prospect of thus advancing with greater impact and depth in the

industrial towards the creation of a genuine European market in the defence industries, which may also contribute to strengthening research and development, not only in the defence industries but also in a range of European industries that benefit from the development of defence industries.
To conclude, I believe one can refer to the obvious articulation between defense industries and the European Union’s foreign policies.
But I would like to cite, with respect to DETA, a recent intervention, translating a classic Romanian saying: if you want peace, prepare for war.

The European Union, as we might call a peaceful superpower, refers to these industries as defense industries rather than war industries, because we desire peace, not war, and therefore we also need defense industries.
Mr. Vice President Barrot, I concur with you, I concur with you in dissatisfaction.
In truth, we must be dissatisfied with the breadth of the measures.
The truth is that irregular immigration continues to Europe, human trafficking continues, there are zones where there is much
Regarding immigration, particularly in the Mediterranean towards Italy, France has put forward a series of important bilateral collaborations, but other Member States have not followed suit.
It is necessary that the Commission continue without losing enthusiasm for this policy of cooperation and assistance to the United States.
Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, I will attempt to present the issues in a very concise manner.
First point, the question of the European Union’s special monitoring mechanism for testing, which ended, as stated here, on December 31, 2008.
It is lacking, Commissioner, the timely and routine publication of statistical data on imports, exports, and price, similar to what occurs in the United States.
Without this data, the European Union is unable to react against potential unfair practices, and the Commission itself becomes incapable of defining its strategy.
I requested your attention to this, similarly to what other colleagues have already done.
Secondly, producing within the European Union increasingly requires compliance with safety regulations, social standards, and environmental norms.
RITES, for example, is a recent initiative that imposes further constraints on us.
It is important that the Commission has a clear strategy that is perceptible and capable of monitoring, so that imported products have identical requirements.
In what way are these aspects being duly considered in the ongoing free trade agreements?
And as for Meidine, can Meidine actually help resolve this issue?
Thirdly, the European Union has launched an economic recovery plan to combat the current crisis.
What role will trade policy play in this context?

At this moment, what is the Commission preparing to do when a series of other countries, such as China, begin to proliferate the imposition of non-tariff barriers, increasingly preventing our European imports from accessing Chinese markets?

What do you propose, with regard to the updating or adjustment of the Fund for Globalisation, as well as the support available within structural funds to improve the immediate situation of the European textile industry?
Final question, last of all, indeed: will the crisis we are experiencing finally make the Commission sensitive to the devastating impact on the European economy of an overvalued euro?
How can the Commissioner sensitize, I conclude now, sensitize her colleagues and the entities that deal with European monetary policy, to rebalance their monetary system?
It is clear to us that we should applaud President Obama’s decision—the decision to close Guantánamo, to prohibit torture, illegal interrogations, and the suspension of military trials.
However, dear colleague, who is no longer with us, Portugal and the Portuguese socialist government have no sense of guilt.
The Portuguese socialist government did not collaborate with the Bush administration, quite the contrary.

It was precisely now, with the Portuguese administration, with the Portuguese Government, with the initiative of Minister Luiz Amado, that the possibility and the duty of the European Union and democratic countries to welcome and receive the detainees without formed guilt in Guantánamo were triggered.

This is what truly matters; this is what should be emphasized as an example to be followed by the remaining Member States of the European Union. It is also important that the resolution be approved tomorrow by all the parties that comprise this Assembly so that, in unity, the decision can carry more weight.
Mr. President, thank you very much to the colleague Napolitano for the excellent report.

14 years after Barcelona and 5 years after the first Euro-Mediterranean Parliamentary Assembly, we have the Union for the Mediterranean with economic power, parliamentary power, civil society, and heads of government deciding together.
All with a desire to do more and better in a territory where 720 million citizens represent a potential for development and peace for the world.
Following them solely from an economic and business perspective is a clear error.

Addressing growth crises requires, naturally, political responses, but addressing humanitarian crises, emergency situations, and military crises, such as the one experienced at the end of 2008 and the beginning of 2009, is crucial.
Politicians and citizens must provide answers to the world’s problems.
The world demanded answers, and months later, we citizens and politicians, particularly within a forum such as the Union for the Mediterranean, continue to delay in responding.
I hope that, at the very least, this moment has served to learn and progress, for one only learns through error, but progressing in the streamlining of the response is absolutely crucial.
The interest in the approval of this directive proposal lies essentially in how it can contribute to stimulating economic activity at the local level and supporting actions at the social level.
This application of a reduced rate is of great importance in the housing sector, both for construction and renovation, allowing Member States that adopt it to reduce its cost for the end user.

The provision of local services, particularly by small businesses, can also benefit from this reduction in the standard rate, ensuring and generating more and better employment through the promotion of consumption of goods and services, thereby stimulating the economy itself.

The activity of restoration, fundamental for the proper functioning of local economies and the increase of tourism itself, can thus gain considerably at the local level with this reduction in VAT taxation.

These services, dear colleagues, should not circulate within the European internal market, which will help to reduce the reserves of some Member States already verified within the Council’s framework.
Therefore, I cannot agree with the extension of this reduced rate to equipment, whatever the pretext.

The prudent manner in which this proposal should be handled in the European Parliament should not give grounds for governments with some reservations regarding the European Commission’s proposal to practically use the right of veto that European legislation still decomposes into fiscal matters.
Thus, here one must prudently reject alterations of a substantial nature, which only serve to impede the text’s acceptance.
As has been mentioned here, not only is the excellent the enemy of the good, but he who wants everything, loses everything.
This draft directive is important not only for strengthening local economies, but also because it aligns with ambitions repeatedly expressed by various Member States.

Therefore, let us support the Commission's proposal as it was presented; that was, indeed, the purpose of the vote, as I, in agreement with the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, concur.

I commend the work of the rapporteurs and appeal for the approval of this proposal in its exact terms as presented by the Commission and as voted on in the Parliamentary Committee for the Internal Market and Consumer Protection.
I yielded the floor to disagree with my colleague Edith Estrella, and that, indeed, was what motivated me to speak. It was when she caricatured the intentions of the Czech Presidency.
No one wants to send women home. The problem is that there are women who want or would like to stay home.
There are even associations that seek to defend them, women who are ignored, scorned, and discriminated against because they want to dedicate themselves to their families, and we do not hear them.
And that is a matter of freedom, a matter of freedom of choice that the left so likes to invoke, but which it forgets here.
It concerns respecting or not the freedom of organization of couples.
It is about being able to provide those who wish to do so with a greater quality of life, more fatherhood, and more quality motherhood.
That is what our society also needs to do.
We will not go there; we will not resolve the problems of birth rates and people's happiness with prejudices.
We resolve with policies adjusted to reality and the spontaneous desires of people.
We are not going there as an opposition to the State and the market.
Let's proceed with a fair look at the family.
Mr. President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, the difficult situation at Quimonda was exacerbated by the emergence of the financial and economic crisis.
The Portuguese government has done everything it deems appropriate and useful to help resolve the situation.
We would also like the Bavarian government to demonstrate a strong sense of responsibility in this area.
Saving the Munich facilities will have a decisive impact on the Vila do Conde and Dresden units.

The Portuguese minister himself, Manuel Pinho, affirmed the considerable interest in enabling this company, so important for Portugal and for Europe, stating that Aquimonda could be a globally competitive enterprise.
Mr. President, the Government of Portugal will maintain its efforts towards a solution that guarantees the company’s viability.
We hope that German governments, at both the federal and state levels, will genuinely commit to resolving this issue.
As for me, I would like to reiterate the strategic importance of maintaining this type of industry within European territory.
that no national or state executive commit the error of allowing this company to close facilities and liquidate jobs within the Union’s territory.

Dear colleagues, we understand the need to assist in the restructuring of large automotive industry groups, but the Union’s funds and the European Commission’s efforts cannot be exhausted by these aids.

Mr. President, dear Commissioner, our appeal to Commissioner Vladimir Špila, to whom we are bound by professional and political security ties, and to President Barroso, who will never forget that he is our compatriot and of a significant portion of Quimonda’s workers, is to commit the Commission to supporting Quimonda, overcoming potential communication failures.

We must emphasize, before concluding, that the Portuguese President, Cavaco Silva, in Germany, recently stated that there was new hope regarding Quimonda, and also referred to the importance, as colleagues have already noted, of the very economic sector in which Quimonda operates.
We take into account that the Portuguese Government has expressed its willingness to support Quimonda with whatever is necessary, considering the economic dimension of the country.
Ladies and gentlemen, let us help save Quimonda; time is of the essence.

Madam President, Commissioner, we have been discussing the Lisbon Strategy for years, and the times we are living through may perhaps not be the most appropriate for talking about the Lisbon Strategy, but undoubtedly we need a strategy.
in a strategy that responds to the difficulties and challenges that the present crisis poses for us.
And that is also what we expect from the Commission.

It is essential that the Commission does not deviate from this matter and, instead, possesses the capacity to coordinate actions with the governments of Portugal, Germany, and the historical figures of Germany.

It is essential to bear in mind that this is an industry, as has already been stated here, that interests Europe due to its quality and value, the research it develops, and also the environmental quality associated with it; and it is indispensable that the Commission does not deviate.
I subscribe to the invitation extended by my colleague Pineda for your Commissioner and the Commission to travel to Portugal.

It is essential that the Commission bear in mind that, at this moment, Europeans are looking to Europe and expect answers from the European authorities. They need to feel that the European authorities are close to them.

European citizens do not understand a Europe that washes its hands of responsibility; rather, they want a Europe that has the audacity to get its hands dirty and to put its hands to work, helping to overcome difficulties. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, I also join the tributes to Jammeh, but I requested the floor to commend your President for the statement he made regarding European Day in Memory of the Victims of Terrorism.
It was at my proposal that, five years ago, we adopted this approach, which the Council enshrined at a meeting on March 25th, following the tragic attacks in Madrid.
But my intervention was an appeal.

Parliament has always remained faithful to the celebration of this date, but, unfortunately, this date has not yet, across the European institutions and Member States, received the recognition it deserves.
I believe that the celebration of this date is one of the most important tools we have to honor the victims, as their President did, but also to raise the level of public awareness.
I know there are some celebrations in Madrid today, but little else.
Consequently, the appeal I make to the Commission and to the Czech Presidency is that all Member States commemorate this date appropriately in the future.
Ladies and gentlemen, my dear colleagues, the crisis is deeper than we anticipated, and unemployment will be greater than we predicted.
There are good reasons to assume that the planned European stimulus is insufficient, but it is already clear at this point that it is taking too long to reach citizens.
The Parliament’s position is strong and clear; it has been and I hope it will continue to be so.
Our objective is to maintain employment and to create new jobs, with cohesion, with solidarity, both territorial and social.
And at this moment of crisis, citizens cannot resign themselves to a Europe that does not provide them with answers, a Europe that is powerless in the face of the problems they are experiencing.
What will the Parliament ask of the Commission?

It requests, naturally, through these reports, that you coordinate national interventions, requests that you utilize all the means currently at your disposal to intervene, and provides you, as a budgetary entity, with all the conditions for this to occur.

It asks him to launch a clear European employment initiative and tells him that it is important to have a timeline-driven agenda for implementing financial market regulation measures, as well as to extend credit to the real economy.
But what is being requested of the council?
The Council is urged to rediscover the political will that lies at the heart of the European project’s construction.
The European Union is competition, but it is equally cohesion and solidarity.
And there cannot be a single market without that guarantee of solidarity and cohesion.
That is precisely why we all delegated, at the European level, the national autonomies we had before adhering to this project. Thank you very much.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, anyone visiting sub-Saharan Africa readily recognizes in the majority of countries the enormous weakness of their healthcare systems and the extremely negative impact this weakness has on the lives and health of the populations those services should serve.
The internationally disseminated indicators consistently confirm this.
And, in that sense, the notion is profoundly disturbing that simple gestures and even relatively uncomplicated practices, not particularly costly either, could be sufficient to save many lives.

European financial support can be crucial in this regard, and we must always bear in mind how cooperation in the field of health is truly strategic and directly addresses not only one of the Millennium Development Goals, but many of them.

The Court of Accounts found that community funding for the health sector has not increased since 2000 in proportion to its total development aid, despite commitments made by the Commission regarding the Millennium Development Goals and the health crisis in Sub-Saharan Africa.
Finalize-se.

And recognized, I quote again, that the Commission contributed significantly, through its funding, to establishing the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria, but did not grant the same attention to strengthening health systems as was anticipated to be one of its priorities.
(FINE) Fine quote.

According to the Court, this occurred again because the Commission lacked sufficient experience in health matters to ensure that the funding of assistance granted to this sector was utilized in the most effective way.
I got that.
This is, therefore, a strong challenge that the Court of Auditors is directly launching at the European Commission, and one that I support.
On our part, I want to reiterate that same challenge, now grounded in the objectivity of this data and this assessment.
Healthcare services are already part of, but should increasingly be part of, our development assistance priorities, deserving of increased funding.

Optimizing the manner in which assistance is delivered, keeping in mind the seemingly antagonistic needs of coordination in its management and proximity to beneficiary populations, is to provide a service that can save many lives.
The European Commission cannot fail to respond positively to this request, and it is in this spirit that I urge it.
Colleague Bowis, just now, gave a moving presentation here and was able to put faces, human faces, on the dry coldness of these figures from the Court of Accounts.
The challenge for us, Madam Commissioner, is for our cooperation to be capable of bringing a look of joy and hope to those very faces.
And for that, Commissioner, it is indispensable that different figures be used in the health area within our cooperation.
Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, once again, for sad reasons, we are discussing here the situation in Guinea-Bissau, which is a truly lamentable situation.
It is a country that has lived with chronic instability for many years, attempting a path toward democracy in the early 1990s.

Nothing went well; there was a coup d'état, a minor internal war, and the country exists in significant political and military instability, with tensions, deep rivalries, and now, recently, also a deeply concerning presence, increasingly evident to all observers, of drug trafficking interests.

We strongly condemn these attacks, the bombing death of the Chief of the General Staff Tagme Naouye, and also the assassination, in particularly barbaric, to say the least savage, terms, of President Nino Vieira.
Regardless of your past, we express our solidarity with your families, the people of Guinea-Bissau, and deeply regret and severely condemn these attacks.
We desire a return to normality, and the lesson I draw and would like to emphasize in the resolution is that impunity is not a remedy.
In the past, concerning the murder of Assumane Mané and General Alvares M. Ciabra, how did it come to pass that eyes were closed to ensure the perpetrators were not found and brought before justice?
It is evident that this is not possible.
Consequently, we must make it clear to the State of Guinea-Bissau that those responsible must be found, the guilty must be brought before justice, and we must provide all necessary assistance.

I would also like to draw attention, to conclude, to the concern regarding the presence of drug trafficking throughout the region, the risk this represents also for the European Union, and the shocking presence, due to its evident nature, in Guinea-Bissau.
I would also like to appeal for the relationship with Cabo Verde to be strengthened, in this context.

We have established a special partnership with Cabo Verde. Cabo Verde has very close relations with Guinea, a great deal of knowledge, but it is also very vulnerable, and that is essential for our own European security as well.
Therefore, the deepening of the special partnership with Cabo Verde is also very important in this context, thank you very much.
Madam President, esteemed colleagues, I would first of all like to thank everyone for the work celebrated.

The three lines defined in the Green Book—concentration, interconnection, and cooperation—can provide solutions to some obstacles to the harmonious development of the Union, particularly the negative effects associated with

concentration of economic activity, inequalities in access to markets and services resulting from distance and divisions imposed by borders between Member States, particularly those most disadvantaged, but also between regions.
We must, therefore, promote the improvement of synergies between these policies with effective methods of assessing their territorial impact.

Therefore, I have always advocated for the definition of supplementary qualitative indicators, with the aim of improving the allocation and implementation of the corresponding policies on the ground, taking into account the diverse territorial specificities.
For now, GDP remains the sole eligibility criterion for receiving support from the Structural Funds.

However, this definition of supplementary indicators and the undertaking of territorial assessments should not give rise to further bureaucracy or delays, but rather to simplification, the implementation of new policies, and support actions for territorial cohesion.
The fifth Interim Report, and to conclude, Mr. President, makes a specific reference to transition regions situated between convergence regions and regions of competitiveness and employment.
It is necessary to note that these regions need a clearer status, with greater security and stability for their development. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, within the context of this major debate on territorial cohesion and the future of economic and social cohesion policy, I could not fail to mention the very specific issues facing ultraperipheral regions.

Regions that, due to the combination and persistence of certain geographic factors, reveal significant economic and social vulnerability, particularly felt within a context of a severe international crisis such as the one we are currently experiencing.

It would, therefore, require appealing to the European Commission and, in particular, to Commissioner Hübner, to pay very particular attention to the effects of the current crisis on the outermost regions.

An assessment of these effects in each of the outermost regions, specifically concerning tourism, construction, and increased unemployment, would be important to allow for a European response tailored to these regions.

Therefore, I challenge the European Commission to prepare a European response to the crisis for the outermost regions, going beyond the measures already announced under the economic and social cohesion policy for all European regions.
a specific European response to the crisis for the outermost regions.

Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, in response to the global financial crisis, the European economy recovery plan states that cohesion policy contributes significantly to public investment by Member States and regions, and should act as a means of recovering from the current crisis.
Specifically suggests the adoption of actions in priority areas of the Lisbon Strategy, in order to achieve growth and employment.
All activated instruments seek to achieve this purpose and accelerate the attainment of results.

In this regard, the expansion of the scope of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund and the streamlining of the European Social Fund have, in particular, the responsibility to respond to the multiple social and economic emergency situations that require support.
I am certain, today as in the past, that your action will be all the more effective the more complementary your actions and areas have been.

However, as the mobilization of new funds or new lines of action in the field was not foreseen, it is particularly important that the European Social Fund be used to its full potential in combating unemployment and the rapid increase in competitive pressures on the European economy, resulting from the current financial crisis and economic slowdown.

I would like to emphasize that the Committee on Rules has repeatedly identified simplification as essential for the improvement of the management and implementation of structural funds, as the European Commission now proposes.

We were asked for urgency, however, in this matter and, in the adoption of this regulatory package, we took it into consideration, and this cause never shied away from assuming its political responsibilities.

Therefore, despite the numerous perspectives that the particularity of the moment provokes, beyond the assurances of process expediency and the real benefit for citizens that the proposal intends to provide, we refrain from presenting new proposals and alterations at this time.
However, we wish to emphasize the need to initiate an evaluation process for this fund immediately, with a view to a supplementary review to be carried out as soon as possible.
The crisis, among other aspects, allowed for the highlighting of significant imbalances between the countries of the Eurozone, perhaps the primary source of tension.
conclusion of the Economic and Monetary Union, but, above all, the extreme vulnerability of countries that, while belonging to the European Union, do not belong to the euro zone.

Therefore, strengthening the resources available at the European level to support balance of payments crisis situations is absolutely indispensable, and therefore we welcome the increase from 12 to 25 and then to 50 million euros in necessary funding.
However, the most important thing is to address the root causes of problems and not merely their most evident manifestations.
Today, the expanded Europe and the Eurozone must reinterpret the meaning of European solidarity and the objectives of cohesion and real convergence.
It is necessary to view this in that light, assessing the capacity of European horizontal policies, but it is also necessary to revisit new financing instruments, such as eurobonds.
Financial assistance to the balance of payments is necessary, but falls far short of being sufficient to guarantee the sustainability of the European project and the single European currency.
Mr. Chairman of the Commission, Mr. Presiding President, we are in an unprecedented crisis.

It was, in fact, not the time to discuss internally how we should organize ourselves. Therefore, my hope is that the Treaty of Lisbon will be rapidly ratified so that we can face the global scene united and in solidarity, as Europeans.

Regarding the economic crisis, in the report of which I was the author and which this Parliament largely approved, it was acknowledged that the recovery plan, subsequently presented by the Commission, would not be sufficient.
Today, we are certain that he is not sufficient.
A financial crisis that began is extending to the real economy, then to employment, and then to the social sphere.
He is insufficient and unfocused.

This is the Commission’s opportunity to respond to the genuine problems of Europeans, through serious financial regulation, and not through any regulation, however slight or piecemeal, proposed by the European Parliament.
possible, how it is underway, not in fact from individual national plans, but from a genuine European initiative, not through dispersed means, but focusing on the very challenge that I employ.

In every crisis, there is an opportunity; this is the opportunity for the Commission and for Europe to respond to the genuine problems of European citizens, and I hope that this will happen through a new approach to the recovery plan.

Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, I merely wished to express, not only on behalf of the PPE, as has already been done by many deputies, but in particular on behalf of the Portuguese deputies of the PPE, the great satisfaction with the result of the referendum in Ireland.
We believe that this clearly strengthens the prospects for development and evolution of the European Union, creating conditions for a new phase.

We naturally wished to greet all those who contributed to the Treaty of Lisbon, in particular the Commission and the Vice-President here present, and also, naturally, the Portuguese Presidency of the European Union, which

You have here a very important role, and for this reason, we also wished to express with pleasure that we have observed that, despite all these vicissitudes and while we await with anticipation the position of the Czech Republic, it will be with great joy that the Portuguese will see the name of their capital linked.

It is a decisive step in the evolution of the European Union, and I wanted to say that we can also count, from this perspective, on another flag, which will also be a flag always of the Portuguese deputies of the PPE, that is, the flag of national parliaments.
We contend that the Treaty of Lisbon marks a decisive step towards incorporating the presence of national parliaments into European democracy as well.

And for that reason, we believe that this dimension, which is the most important dimension of democracy, which is the representative dimension and not, as we sometimes hear in this Chamber, the referendary dimension.

If the fundamental and essential aspect of democracy is representation and not direct voting, then the Treaty of Lisbon is also a significant step towards increasing the participation of national representative democracies in the European process.
Therefore, we are very pleased with this decision of the Irish people.

Mr. President, Madam Minister, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, a brief intervention to welcome the historic and comprehensive result of the referendum in Ireland and to highlight the decisive role that Fine Gael and its leader and incoming Prime Minister of Ireland, Enda Kenny, played in leading this process.
A process in which the need to bring the European Union much closer to its citizens became strikingly clear.
They are, we are all of us, the primary recipients of all Union action.
It is fundamental that everyone be aware of the impact and benefits that Europe has daily on our lives.
Europe is our Lebensraum.
What is good for Europe is good for each Member State, it is good for its citizens.
It is certainly the case with the Treaty of Lisbon.
With this treaty, it becomes much more evident that one can be, simultaneously, a proud and committed national citizen and a staunch defender of the European project.

And the European Union, having concluded a prolonged debate about its organization and functioning, can now focus much more effectively and with considerably more effective instruments on the genuine problems facing Europeans: competitiveness, growth, and employment.
Concluding, Mr. President, Madam Minister, with a proposal intended for future generations.

Considering the deficit of information regarding the values, competencies, objectives, and mode of operation of the European Union, the European Parliament should propose, at the end of compulsory schooling in each Member State, a new subject of European studies with mandatory status.
In an objective, truthful, and concrete manner, young Europeans will effectively learn our principles, who we are, what we do, and where we want to go.

It is through knowledge, from a young age, that they will come to understand throughout their lives the potential and immense utility of European identity within this unique project of voluntary sovereignty sharing on a continental scale.

Mr. President, Mr. President of the Commission, I begin by greeting you in this first debate concerning what this new instrument of political control means for the advancement and development of parliamentary democracy in Europe.
It is European citizens, through their representatives, who stand to gain.

Considering the most recent developments—the Irish referendum, ratification by Poland, and the latest statements by the President of the Czech Republic—I would like to know your assessment of the process of entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon.
There have been efforts on the part of the Commission President.
and what is the prediction it makes for a potential entry into force date of the treaty, and on the other hand, to know whether, at this moment and in light of that prediction, the Commission

Some transitional steps regarding treaties, from the Treaty of Nice to the Treaty of Lisbon, have already been taken, or we are still in a phase of, let's say, anticipation, therefore, a phase of waiting to see.

Mr. President of the Commission, having heard that, I would like to know the following at this stage, when everyone is awaiting the formation of the Commission: fundamentally, what is your perspective?
Will we now, until the final ratification by the Czech Republic, have a management commission, or will the procedures for appointing the new commissioners proceed?

Mr. President, it is fundamental that the primary objective of the creation of the European Union External Action Service realize the efforts of the European institutions to ensure the establishment of an effective service, capable of articulating, formulating, and implementing a European response to today's international challenges.
It must also represent more than the sum of its parts; it should be a value-added element relative to the current efforts of Member States and the European Union.
In this sense, it seems essential to me that what defines the specificity of the Union be at the center of this new reality, and that specificity is the Community method.
That is why I give my full support to the Brok report, which advocates for and safeguards a close articulation between the Commission and the future Service.

I wish, for this purpose, to highlight two aspects: the importance of close coordination between the President of the Commission and the High Representative, also Vice President of the Commission, to ensure its effectiveness and proper functioning.
Finally, the need for an alliance between Parliament and the Commission to combat the emerging intergovernmental drift that could compromise the effective functioning of the service.
Parliament must, therefore, remain vigilant and ensure that the European Service for External Action will be a center of excellence representative of the best expertise in external policy.
Mr. President, Commissioner, first and foremost, I want to emphasize the importance of this issue raised by Deputy Gloriano, because it is a matter of fundamental justice.

We are all perfectly aware that, in a situation of an influenza A pandemic, it will be the southern countries that will suffer most from this problem and the consequences of the virus’s proliferation, not the northern countries.

And we witness every year, with complete passivity, the death of millions of citizens as a result of pandemics that have either been eradicated or have treatments available in Northern countries. A vast list of malaria, dengue fever, yellow fever, tuberculosis,
We have no limits for this list and passively observe this problem.

We effectively use the countries of the Global South as suppliers of free title samples of new virus strains so that we can improve treatment in the countries of the Global North, but, nonetheless, we remain without an effective response to these problems and, therefore, to the questions that were raised; I would simply like to add a few more.
We want to effectively treat this problem as a public health issue or as a business.
Because, if it is treated as a public health problem, we must ensure equal access to treatment in all regions of the world, and to that end, efforts must be more effective.
On the other hand, I would like to ask, and I hope it is not the case, whether we are anticipating that vaccine stocks in Europe will ultimately become so overburdened.
that the secondary IFPs prove so negative in this regard, so that we may then have an act of generosity and, suddenly, begin sending the necessary vaccines to Southern countries.

Finally, I would simply like to ask whether the European Union, we Europeans, and the Commission feel comfortable with a system or model in which northern countries address pandemics through a preventative model, while in southern countries they are treated with palliative measures or merely with leftover resources.

Mr. President, first and foremost, I want to express my full support regarding the issue raised by Mr. Deputy Reul and, above all, to highlight the underlying issue, the fundamental political issue that is at stake in this matter, which precisely concerns the joint programming of research.

What transpired regarding joint programming on neurodegenerative diseases and, in particular, Alzheimer's, was that during the process, the rules changed; we ceased to have a report and instead began to have a resolution, thus eliminating our co-decision-making capacity in this area. We no longer functioned as deputies, but rather as consultants.
And therefore, I would like to know whether, at the very least, what we recommend will be considered or not.
The programming of research activities, regardless of the subject matter, is a political choice, not a technical one, and, in this sense, the role of Parliament should be valued and strengthened.
It seems to me that defining priorities that are political means that they must be streamlined, that they must be transparent, and that they must be democratic.
What transpired with the process concerning the joint decision-making and joint programming of the Alzheimer investigation is a process that should not be repeated, and if it were to

Please repeat, and ensure sufficient advance notice. I therefore hope that the last thing that can happen to us is that the decisions and recommendations presented by Parliament on this matter are not considered.
The president, over the past month, the regions of Europe have been particularly prominent.
European Week dedicated to regions and cities highlighted the position of regions as a fundamental part of the solution in Europe’s response to global challenges.
Thus, they concluded, leaving no room for doubt, President Durão Barroso, Commissioner Samezky, and the hundreds of debates that transpired.

Also, at a more specific level, the holding of the important meeting of the Conference of Presidents of Europe’s Ultraperipheral Regions, which for the first time included the participation of Members of the European Parliament, constitutes a milestone in regional policy in favor of European construction.
Global challenges and European responses present an excellent opportunity for a new strategy for Integrated Rural Development Programmes.

These regions, such as the Azores, beyond the permanent constraints that everyone is accustomed to hearing about, present a set of potentialities that confer clear opportunities to realize our progress and give a distinct advantage to Europe in new domains essential to addressing global challenges.

Therefore, it is demanded that the President of the Commission put an end to the palace coup that the Commission’s No Paper indicates was being prepared, while we, deputies and European citizens, were extolling the ratification of the Treaty of Lisbon and its importance in defending the cohesion of the territory.
Firstly, I would like to greet the rapporteurs, namely Mr. Martin and also Mr. Corbet, to say that, as a member of the EPP, I essentially endorse the proposed amendments to the Rules of Procedure.
It is essentially important to highlight the point that seems to me important here and that has not yet been brought up this evening, which is the point of national parliaments.
The democratic strengthening of the European Parliament undoubtedly results from this regime and the Treaty of Lisbon, but European democracy also stems from the connection to national parliaments.
And what this Bylaw or this proposal now seeks to do is precisely to create these two democratic legitimacies, to reinforce democracy.

On the one hand, democracy resulting from the European Parliament’s own instruments, its control mechanisms, and its legislative capacity; and on the other hand, democratic collaboration between national parliaments through various instruments.
And that is why I am, let's say, completely in agreement with the proposals made.
I disagree with my colleague Duff when he suggests we postpone the interruption of mechanisms for engagement with national parliaments.
I believe we can do this immediately, in light of the Treaty of Lisbon, and that is very important.
I would also like to state that I support the proposal by my colleagues Sayer and Brock regarding representation in the COSAC, and finally, that I am
I am entirely in agreement with the observations made here by Colleague Brok and other colleagues regarding the Parliament’s and Members’ services.
Mr. President, Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I congratulate the rapporteur colleague on the work developed in this report and on her intervention just now.

This new microfinance instrument will enable the provision of microcredit to small businesses and to individuals who have lost their employment and wish to create their own business and their own job.
This is very important in a period when the economic crisis is expected to result in the loss of three and a half million jobs alone in the European Union.

As a consequence of the economic slowdown, banks have ceased to grant loans for job creation and business ventures, and access to credit has become more difficult at a time when it should be more accessible.
Now, this new microfinancing mechanism will counteract the current trend of restricted access to credit, facilitating the acquisition of funds necessary for the launch of new businesses and new jobs.
The European Commission's proposal aims to reallocate €100 million from the PROGRESS programme's budget to this financing instrument.
We cannot agree with this proposal.
The financial and economic crisis is equally a social crisis.
Thus, the reallocation of resources from the PROGRESS program, aimed at the most vulnerable groups, is not entirely the most suitable solution.
For this reason, the creation of a separate budget line to finance this instrument is supported, as well as an increase in its allocation to 150 million euros.

We also agree with the need to clarify within the legislation itself that the target group consists of vulnerable populations who experience difficulty entering or re-entering the labor market and who face the threat of social exclusion.
Thus, the reference to specific groups should be suppressed.
Finally, we emphasize that it is essential that individuals receiving financial support also possess adequate training. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. I would like to begin by greeting the Swedish Presidency and, in particular, Prime Minister Reinfeldt, both on behalf of the EPP and on behalf of the Portuguese delegation of the EPP.
Our assessment of the Swedish Presidency is of an almost complete success, essentially in four fundamental areas.
First, within the institutional sphere, Sweden’s Presidency's contribution to the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, and to the highly successful election of the President of the Commission.
For, notably, all matters related to the ratification process were extremely professional and met the standards expected of the best practices of the European Union.
Naturally, for a country like Portugal, which played a decisive role in the approval of the Treaty of Lisbon, this contribution from the Swedish Presidency is invaluable.
A second point is the climate agenda, where, naturally, the Commission’s work was also extremely important.
We must say that, from my perspective and from the perspective of many EPP deputies, it is in the area of climate change that the European Union has had the greatest success.
It is moving forward on the true frontline of global action, and this is due to the efforts of both the Swedish Presidency and, in particular, also the Commission Presidency.
We consider this balance to be very positive as well.
A third point concerns financial regulation, which, particularly with this latest Council, took a step we consider decisive and that may have a significant impact on exiting the crisis.
And therefore, I also wanted to congratulate you on the achievement of an agreement in that area.
And finally, I wanted to dedicate a word to an area that is, for me personally, particularly significant—that of the Stockholm Programme and, consequently, the area of security, justice, and freedom.

I believe that I, who followed both the tempering process and, in particular, the AIA process afterward, consider this Stockholm program absolutely essential and wanted to congratulate the Swedish Presidency and Prime Minister Reinfeldt for it.

Mr. President, for the recognition of professional qualifications, 15 directives have been consolidated into a single legislative act, as is well known, which has given rise to various practical problems in their application within the different Member States.
The difficulties are well known, and the Commission should inventory the critical points and analyze the problematic areas that arise in the application of this important internal market instrument.
Protectionist measures, manifesting at various levels, constitute an impediment not only to the free movement of people but also to the internal market.
We must attempt to identify the ambiguous points so that the directive's effectiveness is not undermined by distrust.
The Union is not being asked to do what the Member States should do, but there is a facilitating effort to be made that helps to dismantle professional corporatism.
An improvement in the application of this directive should involve the disclosure of recognition of qualifications through the SOLVIT network and the EURES network by incentivization.
common platforms, the implementation of effective contact points, and, no less importantly, it should provide an articulation of this directive with the Services Directive.

Mr. President, Commissioner, Ladies and Gentlemen Members of Parliament, it is urgent that a debate be promoted regarding the Community budget and how, in the future, we can contribute to its sustainability and transparency.

The post-2013 financial framework should be built on the principles of solidarity and territorial cohesion, values crucial for regions such as Madeira, which face persistent difficulties and, therefore, require ongoing support.
I would like to share with you some ideas that I believe should always be present when considering and building cohesion policy.

The Commission has repeatedly referred to certain aspects that I consider essential, such as the need for greater flexibility, simplicity, efficiency, and a more results-oriented approach in the definition and implementation of this policy.
But there are questions that concern me, particularly considering the needs of the outermost regions.
In this matter, allow me three brief notes. Firstly, the current approach in terms of regions should prevail over alternative guidelines, such as, for example, value-added sectors.

Such a reorientation could jeopardize Objective 2, which currently benefits approximately two-thirds of European regions, and may also prove counterproductive in regions with distinct economic profiles and competitive advantages. Secondly, it seems to me that maintaining the proximity criterion in cohesion policy is vital.

It should continue to prioritize the allocation and management of structural funds from a regional perspective, rather than a national or even centralized one at the European level. Thirdly and finally, but no less importantly, it would cost to remember and underscore Article 349.
Article 349 of the Treaty of Lisbon provides for special treatment of outermost regions with regard to access to structural funds, precisely due to their economic and social situation.
The situation is exacerbated by conditionalities and unique characteristics of a permanent nature, which manifest in these constant difficulties and therefore demand the claimed permanent assistance.
Mr. President, given the urgency, what we witnessed in Copenhagen were several steps backward.

It is true that Copenhagen mobilized more heads of state than Kyoto, but it also created more divisions, and as a result, we ended up with a situation of each for themselves, where each state can define its own objectives and moreover, under a voluntary regime.
It should be noted that if we have a two-degree target or funding targets without any clarification, those also cannot serve as consolation for us.
And therefore, what I think is that we need to act in terms of the future, and acting in terms of the future is moving away from rhetoric and toward action.
The European Union has always wanted to be a leader, it has always stated so.
But, when we arrived in Copan, he ended up hesitating, failing to define or defend the goals he had previously stated were his goals and from which he would not deviate.

And therefore, what I ask is whether, for the future, we will no longer be just, whether we will continue to permit that, at the expense of this failure and the decisions of some over others, the poorest will continue to bear the heaviest burden.
Mr. President, I wished to denounce here what is currently happening in Portugal, where it is clear that the media is one of the world’s principal problems.
It brought to light a government plan to control newspapers, to control television stations, to control radio stations, which challenges freedom of expression.
Earlier this week, a well-known journalist, Mario Crespo, saw one of his chronicles censored, also at the suggestion or apparent suggestion of the prime minister.

In light of this, Prime Minister José Sócrates must provide substantial explanations to the country; he must explain that he is not dominating, correcting, or censoring freedom of expression in Portugal.

The way things are progressing, Portugal is no longer a state of law, but a formal state of law, where the prime minister is limited to formalities, procedures, and formalism, and is unwilling to provide substantive explanations.
For Portugal, we want a substantive rule of law.

Mr. President, the green paper for the reform of the common fisheries policy, reported on by my colleague from General Affairs, Maria do Celso Patrão Neves, represents a unique opportunity for debate concerning a sector that assumes considerable importance in the balanced development of ultraperipheral regions.

Madara follows the ongoing discussion with particular interest and considers it imperative to propose a differentiation between artisanal and industrial fleets, which should benefit from different fishing regimes.
It is fundamental to defend a principle of positive discrimination, with respect to limiting access to territorial waters within the exclusive economic zone to local artisanal fleets only.
In the wood sector, priority is given to the modernization of vessels, as well as to a management approach that ensures the long-term conservation of a broad range of species.
Only in this way will we be able to avoid unsustainable situations for economic, environmental, and social equilibrium.
Finally, we will strive to ensure that fishing in the outermost regions receives permanent, not time-limited, support.

This report concerning the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD) aims to broaden the eligibility of interventions in the housing sector in favour of marginalized communities in our Member States.
To date, this support has been applied solely to marginalized communities residing in the urban areas of the new Member States.
In other words, given that the vast majority of these communities live in rural areas and in inadequate housing, they could not benefit from support to replace substandard dwellings.
Ultimately, this concerns how to neutralize a vaccine and grant Member States and their regions greater possibilities in the policy of mitigating the specific difficulties of these communities.

I also acknowledge the principle of equal treatment for all Member States, as marginalized communities with needs for support and integration deserve our concern, regardless of the Member State to which they belong.

Upon concluding the first reading of this important report in the fight against poverty and for human dignity, its rapid implementation within the framework of the economic recovery plan is also achieved, responding swiftly to the crisis affecting us.

Mr. President, Commissioner, allow me to begin by highlighting the role of the rapporteur, Mr. Van Nistelrooy, for his work in seeking consensus on this matter and also for the availability he consistently demonstrated in incorporating other contributions into his report.
Tomorrow, we will vote on amendments to the FEDER regulations that assume particular importance for the so-called former Member States and also for Portugal.

These changes will allow for the extension of the use of the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) in the housing sector to benefit marginalized communities, as currently this fund can only be allocated to urban development operations.

The changes proposed, together with other colleagues and approved by a large majority in the Regional Development Committee, will allow former Member States, and not just the new ones, as originally envisioned in the proposal, to also benefit from this funding possibility.

With this, I sought to prevent the establishment of a precedent that I consider dangerous and that would exclude all former Member States from this and, likely, from other additional uses of Community assistance.
What would make no sense, given that housing-related issues, particularly among marginalized communities, exist in both new and old member states.
I wish to reiterate that the seniority of accession to the European Union should not be a criterion for the allocation of structural funds, and that this criterion should be abandoned definitively.

The negotiation of the post-2013 cohesion policy should be based on solidarity, aiming for territorial cohesion, and should be oriented towards rewarding, rather than penalizing, regions that have demonstrated exemplary performance in the utilization of Community funds.

Mr. President, at this essential moment, I primarily wanted to emphasize to the Commission and to the President of the Commission the manner in which they worked with this Parliament over these months of investiture.
There is no body in the world possessing both executive and legislative authority that is subject to the presentation of a program by its president before Parliament, nor to hearing by all groups.

deputed to an absolute and substantial vote, to bring here all the commissioners to be heard individually with their own program, with three to four hours of direct questions, of questions with answers.
someone who agreed to negotiate with Parliament a framework agreement, in which they accepted, firstly, to justify and expand the powers of Parliament within the scope of legislative initiative.

that accepted the principle of total access to information, whether in legislative and political action, or in international negotiations, that accepted taking the Parliament’s opinion into account regarding commissioners, regarding the remodelling of commissioners.
This means, once and for all and from my perspective, that the Commission has, from July until now, demonstrated its willingness to have a close relationship with Parliament and that it is

The President did so, demonstrating clearly, vividly, and unequivocally that the strategic alliance of the Treaty of Lisbon for the community method of which Mr. Sarkozy Zwolowski spoke is the alliance between Parliament and the Commission.
And therefore, the Commission and the framework agreement deserve the full support of the EPP.
Mr. President, five years after the Orange Revolution, Ukrainians appear to view this period as a lost opportunity.
And the blame isn't solely with your political elites.
It is true that these consumed themselves excessively in power and influence struggles.
