that many reforms remained unfulfilled, many never progressed beyond the paper they were written on.
It is inconceivable that in any democracy electoral laws should be altered between the two rounds of an election.
It does not dignify those who proposed them, those who voted for them, or those who promulgated them.
and translates the little praiseworthy and recommendable intentions in its genesis.
Much remains to be changed given the lack of judicial independence, subject to excessive influence, not only from the political power, but also from economic actors.
Without a free and independent judiciary, there is no rule of law, human rights are not guaranteed, there is no foreign investment, and there is no progress.
But the blame for this disillusionment also rests with this Parliament and, essentially, with many Member States.
I would like you to, for a few moments, put yourselves in the shoes of a citizen of a European country that, due to the vicissitudes of history, is not yet a member of the European Union.
What is Spiritism not?
solidarity.

But many chanceries, with the sole concern of not inconveniencing and displeasing Moscow, exploited and abused the persistent internal struggles in Kyiv to avoid unequivocally affirming that Ukraine is an independent and sovereign country.
As such, if this represents the freely expressed will of its people and provided that the established criteria are met, Ukraine may aspire to become a member of the European Union in the future.
I wish to emphasize that in island regions, air transport offers the sole possibility of access, and operating conditions are dependent on the dimensions of passenger and cargo flows.

There are island regions where the abundance of these flows is appealing to many air operators, attracting competition and low transport prices, thereby improving accessibility. Others exist, such as the Azores, where these flows are still reduced and do not attract operator interest.

Consequently, airfares are higher, constituting an obstacle to population mobility and a constraint on attracting tourists that would allow for the flourishing and development of its enormous potential for economic development and diversification.
This picture is particularly detrimental in times of crisis such as the one we are experiencing.

It is therefore essential to provide temporary support that fosters an increase in flows so that the market can function, also sharing these regions of high tourist potential among the objectives of the trans-European networks in bringing the European peripheries closer together.
Mr. President, I took the floor in this Chamber today with a voice choked by the consternation of someone who lived through and personally witnessed the tragedy that struck the woods last Saturday.

My words are, of course, to associate myself with the feeling of pain and mourning that has struck the families of the deceased, currently numbering 42, to whom I pay my respects in recognition of their losses.

The true extent of this catastrophe remains to be revealed, as search and rescue teams working tirelessly since Saturday—in a Herculean effort that is only now being recognized—are beginning to reach the most isolated populations.
and we fear that the number of casualties may increase.
The scene is one of widespread destruction, with significant material damage to access routes, roads, and bridges completely leveled, and to essential services such as water and electricity supply.
Approximately 600 people are displaced, having lost their homes and personal belongings.
The economic and social impact of this catastrophe prevents people from resuming a normal life course.
You now need to look ahead.
I also need to deliver a message of solidarity, hope, and confidence to the people.

It is necessary to provide assistance, and it is in this area that the European Union and the Parliament, in particular, have a role to play. They are fundamental to the mobilization process of the Solidarity Fund.
And when we are called to intervene, we must do so swiftly, because we cannot ask these people to wait, especially when they need us most.

I appeal here to the Commission and its President, Mr. Barroso, and in particular to the Commissioner for Regional Development, João H. Ahn, and welcome your initiative to visit Madeira in the shortest possible time.
I ask that he also carry this message of hope, of help, and of support for the reconstruction, because now is the time to rebuild what nature, unfortunately and once again, has taken from me.
But I am certain that we will, because, as the anthem of Madeira suggested to me, the Madeiran people are humble, stoic, and valiant.
It is the people who toiled the land among the rocks, a hero of labor in the rugged mountain.
Through wood, it will honor its history, and in the exit from work, it will strive and attain its well-being and glory.
We begin this plenary session today with a minute of silence.

It was a minute of silence with two meanings: that of solidarity for the victims of this catastrophe that has struck Madeira and their families, and a sense of tribute to all the workers who have provided assistance to these victims tirelessly.
But the minute of silence should make us reflect and should also lead to a reflection that extends beyond the one we are undertaking here.
What we hear in wood is a phenomenon that will tend to repeat itself increasingly.
Climate change is causing extreme events to recur, and we must have responses to them.
We cannot avoid natural disasters, but neither should we be condemned to accept that they must always have such dramatic effects on people’s lives.
That is why we must advocate for planning and land-use policies oriented towards the public good.

But I want to conclude, Mr. President, with what is most important and what brought us here, which is that the European Commission, the European Parliament, and the European institutions must have the capacity to respond urgently to an emergency situation, and for that purpose the necessary financial resources are required, and the necessary speed is essential.
A tribute of solidarity to the families and friends of the victims of Saturday’s tragic events on the Island of Madeira.

As a Syrian, as a Portuguese person, and as a European, I cannot fail to appeal to the Parliament and to the Union for their demonstration of active solidarity in favor of the autonomous region of Madeira and its populations.
It is in the regions that the presence of the Union needs to be felt, and precisely in these moments when its solidarity is most necessary, that it is also most important for it to be felt.

Mr. President, I too wish to express my solidarity with the pain of the people of Madeira and to urgently appeal to European institutions and, in particular, to the Commission, to unlock all available resources, all resources within their reach, to provide that assistance.
I would also like to emphasize that, when a disaster of this kind occurs, it is considerably more difficult to address its consequences when it happens in poor countries and impoverished regions.

However, in the case of timber, we must also consider that the economic foundation of the timber industry is directly affected by the fact that, depending on tourism, it experiences a twofold consequence when its natural beauty, its access routes, and its quality of life are all destroyed.

Consequently, there is, in fact, a different situation when we have problems of this magnitude in poor countries and in poor regions, and in particular, in mountainous and tourist regions, as is the case with Madeira.
Therefore, it is absolutely essential that all adaptations that were foreseen and requested, and that have been recalled here in relation to the Solidarity Fund, do not await any further delay.

that they immediately come into effect, because, due to climate change, these processes, unfortunately, will repeat themselves, especially in the poorest regions of Europe, which are those experiencing torrential rainfall and extreme drought during the summer. Thank you very much once again, Mr. President.
Mr. President, Commissioner, and Members of the Council, we are here to discuss the reinvention of the energy system at the European scale through investment in low-carbon technologies.
I believe it is one of the very important challenges, as is mentioned, indeed, in the communication that is made.
It is one of the challenges we must face centrally, but there is no clarification here, and thus, the importance of raising these questions and requesting clarification.
It appears that not only is clarification of funding lacking, but political clarification is also absent.

Discussions revolve around energy efficiency, carbon capture, nuclear power, biofuels, and solar energy; it is even discussed that energy efficiency represents the most cost-effective way to reduce emissions.
It surprises me that there are far cheaper ways to reduce carbon emissions that don't even involve this communication, such as, for instance, reducing consumption itself.
energetic, microgeneration, distribution, and different forms of distribution and different projects that do not have to pass only through large structures and access to energy.
I hope that we were contributing assuredly to further financial clarification to make the plan more affordable.

And therefore, within this political clarification and within this financial clarification, there remains the need to address what appears to me to be an absolutely important point: the emphasis that is permanently placed on public or private partnerships, as if they were the solution to everything.
When asked where the money comes from, the Commission tells us it comes from where he is.
I confess that I am not made any clearer by being told that the money will come from where it is, without being told exactly where it is.

Therefore, this investment in public or private partnerships, which is consistently made when discussing low-carbon technologies, certainly holds a certainty: not knowing where the money comes from and knowing that they are public or private partnerships, we know from whom the payment will come.
Ultimately, it is the taxpayers who will pay—initially, and the consumers who, incidentally, are also taxpayers in the end.

And we know that those who pay less, from now on, are the institutions and private organizations, and those who make investments are remunerated for it, but ultimately they end up monopolizing the profits.
Without this clarification, it appears to me that, once again, we are systematically passing the bill for Europe’s energy model transition on to future generations.

Mr. President, the European Union recently celebrated, within the framework of the World Trade Organization, an agreement with the countries of Latin America, in which it committed to substantially and progressively reduce tariffs on banana imports from those countries.

I draw your attention to the fact that such an agreement has directly negative effects on European banana producers, specifically on the banana producers of the Madeira region in Portugal, but also, in an even more intense way, from the Canary Islands, in Spain.

I wish to reiterate that the situation of producers in these regions is already seriously complicated by the physical and orographic characteristics of the islands and the scale of their operations, which leads them to face persistent difficulties that hinder their development.

It is, therefore, urgent to take measures in defense of banana, timber, and Canary Islands producers, considering the serious and immediate impact that the new Geneva Agreement has on the European market for imports and, consequently, on the production and marketing of bananas originating from these outermost regions.
Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, Commissioner, as rapporteur for the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I would like to begin with a point.
To commend Deputy Kirilov, even in his forced absence, and to highlight the manner in which he was able to craft this important report, thereby facilitating the principal objective.
I would also like to commend Deputy Creol for the presentation she gave us.

This primary objective, without further elaboration, is to simplify procedures and accelerate the implementation of programs funded by the Cohesion Fund, the Structural Funds, and the Regional Development Fund.
Within the context of the current financial, economic, and social crisis, pressure on national financial resources has been increasing.
This pressure will diminish with better utilization of community funding, and with the faster arrival of these resources to those most affected by the economic downturn.
Over 20 million Europeans are unemployed, that is, 4 million more than a year ago, and, regrettably, the trend is upward.

This situation demands ensuring the proper implementation of cohesion programs, as they represent a more powerful and relevant lever for supporting the real economy, particularly within small and medium-sized enterprises and employment.
SMEs are the engine of the European economy and key players in sustainable growth, generating employment in both quantity and quality.
The continued simplification and clarification of the rules governing cohesion policy will undoubtedly have a positive impact on the pace of program implementation, particularly because it will be

National, regional, and local authorities have the possibility of resorting to clearer and less bureaucratic rules, which will allow greater flexibility in adapting programs to new challenges. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, of course this was an unforeseen crisis and of course the principle of precaution had to take priority.
But there are lessons to be drawn, and the first is that, over five days, not a single sufficiently strong and politically irresponsible European voice was heard.
And that voice was sorely missed with regard to the defense of passenger interests, the clarification of their rights, the pursuit of transportation alternatives, and the coordination of solutions.

A second conclusion is that the exit from the crisis must not appear, to the average citizen, to be a game of forces between those who want to avoid losses and those who want to defend the principle of precaution.
There must be a clear transparency and a clear objectivity regarding the conditions under which one exits a situation of full space beam within the European space.
And therefore, the improvement of scientific tests and coordination also at the level

Mr. President, I would also like to begin by congratulating the colleague Thyssen Kohl on her work and persistence in this very important dossier, and for the work she has done to improve the energy performance of buildings and for a more sustainable Europe.
Energy expenditure in the European Union, as we know, is significantly above what is acceptable, and that is why moving forward with proposals of this nature is so important.
It is more than time for us to have an ambitious policy in European terms and to add to this ambitious policy complementary measures, especially in the crisis situation we are living through.
The construction sector is considered one of the sectors, one of the markets with the greatest potential in terms of economy and energy, but it's not just that.
And it is not only that, and therefore it is a sector par excellence for the implementation of public policies, and it is in this sense that I would like to conclude, Mr. President.
We therefore have to seize this opportunity presented by investments in improving the energy efficiency of buildings and their potential to create millions of jobs in the coming years.
And it’s not just about new buildings, but also in the rehabilitation and recovery of existing buildings, degraded or unsuitable.

Let us, therefore, leverage this legislation as a fundamental contribution to the revitalization of the European economy, and we cannot continue to squander the investment that can and should be strategic for recovery from the crisis. We hope for investment from the Commission and that Member States will know how to capitalize on this investment.

Mr. President, Mr. President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would like to begin by congratulating the colleague Manders on the work developed in this report, as well as thanking the colleagues who collaborated with him on this dossier.

In truth, the mere fact that this proposal simplifies and improves the current regulatory framework, bringing together in a single regulation all existing legislation, three foundational guidelines on the designation and labeling of textile products, is itself a significant development.

But, beyond that, this proposal will have a positive impact on private entities and public authorities, and will also provide a framework for newly developed fibers, thus encouraging innovation in the textile and apparel sector.
This review will also enhance the transparency of the process for adding new fibers to the list of harmonized fiber denominations.
It appears there is little doubt that the agents involved will benefit from this regulation.
Let us examine how the textile industry will benefit from reduced administrative costs and the possibility of marketing new fibers sooner.
For their part, the authorities of the Member States will not need to transpose the amendments into national legislation, which will enable a significant cost saving for those Member States.
And consumers will have the assurance that the fibers designated meet specific characteristics, also benefiting from the fact that the new fibers reach the market sooner.
For the European industry, the introduction of these new fibers is important as a means of promoting innovation, while also increasing the level of information provided to consumers.
Within the current context of a globalized world, of emerging economies, with increasingly expansive markets, in which millions of products circulate, produced by millions of companies.
Investment in innovation and the speed with which that innovation reaches consumers are absolutely crucial for businesses, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises.
that the application of this regulation may increase its competitiveness.
These small and medium-sized enterprises will assuredly gain market share with this new regulation, and through that route, will contribute to increased employment in Europe.
Madam President, Minister, Commissioner, the shortage of organs for transplant is a greater problem.

It has been referred to here on several occasions and represents a more significant problem that raises questions both of public health and of issues associated with the strengthening of the parallel market and organ trafficking, which does not enhance our healthcare systems or our citizens.

And therefore, we must combat this crime and combat it through legislation of proposals, such as those we are discussing here, which is, it seems to me, more than important and more than relevant, and for that reason I want to focus on the most important dimensions and issues raised by these two proposals.
Because the system we have thus far, and without these two proposals, is a system of enormous inequalities.
Inequalities between member states, inequalities between existing systems, inequalities of access to bodies, inequalities between citizens—which, it seems to me, we cannot sustain.
Consequently, it is important to emphasize that these inequalities should be reduced, and these proposals aim to combat precisely that.
I believe that a European system which, in any event, retains some specificities of certain countries so that they are not obliged to have more restrictive systems is the answer to this problem.
And the work developed by the rapporteurs, Mr. Deputy Miroslav László Jároly and Mr. Deputy Perello Rodrigues, is work of extreme importance and a contribution to this problem we face.
We are discussing proposals based on and supported by issues such as altruism, volunteering, I apologize, gratuity, confidentiality, and data protection.

Traceability, accountability, and here I believe it is important on the part of Parliament that there be patient recovery and not just donation and cooperation between Member States; I think we are on the right track.
I must, however, in relation to donations between living individuals, express my pleasure at the inclusion and expansion—an expansion accomplished with rights.

Obviously, all rights and all conditions were guaranteed, but it is vitally important that we went beyond the restricted cycle of the conventional family, because otherwise it would be just another way of achieving other forms of equality.

Advancing the Patient Data Access Dossier (DAD) as the primary source of transparency and safeguarding patient data and security seems to me to be more than sufficient reasons for us all to come together tomorrow and vote favorably on these two proposals of extreme importance to healthcare.

Mr. President, Minister, and Commissioner, the ability to replace deteriorated human organs with those of another person, preventing their rejection, is one of the great successes of contemporary medicine.

European benchmarking reveals that mid-sized countries, such as Portugal, perform very well in such comparisons, and larger countries, like Spain, are now recognized as organizational leaders and exemplars of best practices.
certain principles and practices to safeguard.

Firstly, the strengthening of scientific knowledge and information, which leads increasingly more donors to living donation and to generalizing post-mortem donation. Secondly, the prohibition of the commercialization of the

of donation, not only within Member States but also outside them, preventing transplant tourism and combating organ trafficking. Thirdly, the proactive promotion of donation in hospitals, as a means of overcoming scarcity.

Finally, Madam President, ensuring equal access to transplantation for all those who need it and who qualify according to harmonized clinical criteria, adhering to the principle of universal access to healthcare—a paradigm of the social Europe of which we are proud.
I commend the rapporteurs for their work.
I would like to underscore that it is with great, let's say, satisfaction that the European People's Party and the Portuguese deputies of the Party
On the European side, they see the initiation of this accession process, of the European Union gaining access to the European Convention on Human Rights.

We, ultimately, a country like Portugal, which has always been at the forefront of human rights, with the abolition of slavery in Portugal itself in 1761, and with pioneering efforts in the abolition of the death penalty, can only evidently be interested in and supportive of this accession process.

I would, however, like to draw attention to the fact that we consider it very important that the European Parliament follows the entire negotiation of the European Union’s accession to the European Convention on Human Rights step by step.

We consider this aspect, from a technical, legal, and political perspective, to be fundamental, because Parliament is also a home of human rights and a place where human rights have great relevance, and I would now simply like to note what we consider to be very important.

For us, members of the European Parliament, who are in contact with many states outside the European Union, it is very important, a very positive signal that we give to the members of the Council of Europe, upon entry into the European Union, to the members of the Council of Europe who are not members of the European Union.
For these members of the Council of Europe, it is a sign of strengthened commitment from the European Union to its situation and to levels of democracy and respect for fundamental rights.
Madam President, Commissioner, social housing is an economic service of general interest, with an important role in the market, creating positive externalities to the benefit of all of society.
According to Protocol 26, annexed to the Treaty of Lisbon, the responsibility for executing and organizing this type of service rests with national, regional, and local authorities.
Hence, this restriction of the target audience to families with incomes below 30 euros is scarcely comprehensible.

This concerns a measurement of poverty that is conducted in absolute and purely financial terms, failing to account for the diversity of the twenty-seven Member States, and reducing itself to a simple argument of solvency.
Now, social housing responds to cultural, social, proximity-to-workplace issues, the significant redefinition of women's roles in the market, and the mobility of workers within the European space.
The struggle that the European Union undertakes to overcome the current crisis involves economic growth, which entails an increase in immigration and ethnic minorities.
economical and cultural, and by the necessity of its integration, even with the risks of ghettoization associated with it, which we must combat with just balance.
Is the Commission not encroaching upon the competence of the Member States?

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, allow me, Madam President, to note that we are debating the first report from the Committee on Agriculture, subject to the new ordinary legislative procedure as laid down in the Treaty of Lisbon.

This concerns a historic moment that, should this Chamber confirm the proposed vote, will initiate in the best possible way this new period of sharing agricultural competencies within the European Union.
I speak directly with Icelanders about their ultraperipheral regions, a practical demonstration of the will to build a Union strengthened by cohesion.
in the spirit of active solidarity, with respect for the specificities and differences of its parts, as the only viable path to the construction of our common European project.
I also introduce fundamental regulation to enable the already century-old sugar sector in the Azores, the region from which I hail, therefore I am particularly pleased, thus contributing to a
Healthy diversification of agriculture in a region where the dairy sector occupies, as we know, a unique dimension on a national scale, irreplaceable, which we must sustain and consolidate.
Madam President, I would like to thank Commissioner Cioloş and the senior officials of the Commission, with whom we have worked and negotiated, for the openness and flexibility shown.
The Spanish Presidency of the Council also exerted every effort to ensure that our party’s desire to reach an agreement at first reading became a reality.

This acknowledgement is, of course, extendable to the members of other political groups, as well as to the excellent staff of the Secretariat of the Committee on Agriculture of this Parliament, whose collaboration enabled us to reach a result that I consider very positive.

I would also like to emphasize the decisive contribution made by the Azores Agricultural Federation and by the regional and Republic governments in the way they engaged and committed themselves to finding a solution for Azorean sugar.

The presentation of the Council’s proposed regulation on 2 October in the Agriculture Committee occurred at a time when there were no prospects for the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, which continued to await ratification by all Member States.
In this context, the initial idea of the Commission and the Council was that the proposal would be approved in a simplified procedure, without any amendments, to take effect as of 1 January 2010.

with the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon and, despite, at the time, dominating the opinion among other political groups, as well as the Council and the Commission, so that the proposal would remain in a simplified procedure, because they understood that

The proposal did not require amendments and should enter into force rapidly. Despite this prevailing opinion, I, along with the Socialist and Democratic Group, believe that Parliament should already pronounce itself within the framework of the Treaty of Lisbon, assuming its role as co-legislator.

Fortunately, we did it, because from then on new possibilities opened up, first with the contribution of the Regional Development Commission and the partnership of colleague Nunta Sheira, to whom I also take this opportunity to

I would like to congratulate and thank you for the constant cooperation provided throughout this process, and subsequently, with my report, introducing new possibilities for sugar in the Azores, as well as with the contribution and support of the colleagues from the Agriculture Commission.

Finally, in this initial intervention, I would like to state that regarding the amendments proposed by the REGI Commission and voted on in the AGRI Commission, which I supported, we were unable to secure their acceptance of the commitment reached in the triangle.

It was essential to secure a first reading commitment, thereby safeguarding the improvements already achieved and the need for effective entry to avoid its retroactive application since January of this year.
However, with the Commission already preparing a review document for POSEI, we will certainly have the opportunity to discuss them again soon.

Mr. President, Mr. President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, we are facing an acceleration of a global change that has devastating consequences for our economic, political, and social systems, and consequently, for all our citizens.
We are witnessing today an unprecedented weakening of the capacity of states to respond.
The European Union must, therefore, identify common and allied causes and act clearly and unitedly on the world stage.
Extraordinary situations demand clear, coordinated action.

If we do not adopt the necessary collective measures of rigor and accountability, Europe will be consigned to marginalization and impoverishment, and only a strong Europe, one that respects its common rules, can provide an adequate response to the new times.
Fragile and indebted states lack the capacity to protect their citizens.
Consequently, we need to be able to restore citizens’ trust, win the battles of stability, budgetary rigor, job creation, the stability of the monetary union, globalization, and strategic choices.
Otherwise, our future will be compromised.
And it wins if the future is invested in social cohesion, ensuring peace, building a new model based on values of freedom, social justice, and responsibility.
Thus, the Europe 2020 Strategy and the Integrated Guidelines Europe 2020 constitute essential instruments for a new cycle of growth and employment in Europe.
For proper implementation and achievement, it is necessary to define quantifiable and clear objectives in the areas of employment, education, and poverty reduction.

It is also decisive for the success of the strategy that everything be done to facilitate the transposition by Member States of its national objectives and to ensure the correct implementation of this strategy. Thank you very much.
When the economic and monetary union reached its tenth anniversary, the Commission considered the euro the Union’s most successful project.
Today, we would have difficulty affirming it without limitations, because the crisis demonstrated the evidence that the economic and monetary union is an unfinished project.
Minimal measures of salvation were taken amidst a climate of emergency, but let us not be deceived: the conditions of pressure, the direct interests of the main
The member states, the painful nature of decisions, their slowness, have weakened the image of the euro and the European Union in the eyes of citizens and of the world.
We must face the facts.
The European Union and the euro are a process of integration, not merely cooperation between countries.
They are an unfinished project that, at this moment, either strengthens itself or runs very serious risks of disappearing.
There are three topics that must be addressed first; it is important to consolidate the instruments that were launched in this climate of emergency; it is necessary to create a monetary fund.

The European euro—it is necessary to move forward with Eurobonds, it is necessary to move forward with the European supervisory and regulatory architecture, and it is necessary to move forward with a European dimension in the management of banking crises.
It is important to understand that there is no strong currency if the economy is weak; the 1% growth predicted for the European Union is unsustainable in terms of income.
Whether concerning its demographic composition or in terms of combating unemployment, the 2020 Strategy is nothing more than a collection of good ideas lacking the means of implementation.

Third dimension, Commissioner Lehne, fiscal consolidation is important, but it cannot coexist with growing divergences among the Member States that comprise the Union. The convergence policy must be urgently revisited. Thank you very much, Mr. President.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. Several colleagues here from the EPP have already provided a very comprehensive overview of the situation.
I believe that it will now be necessary to demand and make a reference to the role of nation states.
Indeed, national governments also have a role here in imposing within their states the requirements
and the conditions for the single currency to be strengthened and for this project of monetary and economic integration to be advanced.
And here I wanted to say that our party, the party linked to the EPP, which is PSD in Portugal, is supporting the government in the austerity measures, because we consider

May the errors that the socialist government committed over these 15 years in Portugal, and which today, unfortunately, are evident to all, be rectified, and will have the support of the PSD to be rectified.

But if we are supporting austerity measures, we also criticize the Portuguese government, and it’s a good example for other analogous cases, because it is not reducing expenditure, and what is fundamental is not only

It is not increasing taxes to reduce the deficit, but rather reducing expenditure; it is demanding that the government have the courage to take measures that reduce expenditure, that alleviate the deficit, that alleviate public debt.

This applies to Portugal and applies to other States that are currently in a difficult situation, and we, as Members of the European Parliament, have the responsibility to also do so in our own countries.
An advocacy of the measures needed for the euro to emerge strengthened and for this space of integration and this dream, a dream of the PPE and a dream of us all, to be realized.
Therefore, we criticize those governments that do not have the courage to take the necessary measures within their own states.

I would like to begin by saying that the report on the assessment of the outcomes of the 2006 gender equality roadmap, and which aims to influence strategies on this subject in the future, could, in our opinion, have been more decisive and less contentious.

In truth, the manner of addressing various ethically sensitive issues, particularly the question of women’s sexual and reproductive health, should have been distinct if the objective were genuinely to achieve the greatest possible consensus.

Having said that, I would like to emphasize that, during times of economic growth, this normality, concern for women’s rights, particularly the disparity between the situation of men and women in the workplace, in society, and in the family, is significant, but these problems are profoundly exacerbated by economic and social crises such as the one we are experiencing.
Hence the need for a strengthened strategic commitment from the Member States, at the level of local and regional entities and Community institutions, with regard to the protection of human rights.

We must say that, in line with what President Daul and colleague Werner Langen stated, it is fundamental that there be an economic government of the Union, but that this economic government be centered on the Commission.
This is the first point I wanted to underscore, and having said that, to say that we should not merely, as we did this morning, focus our debate on immediate issues, but

Also in those [areas] outlined in the Strategy 2020, and I would particularly emphasize the issue of education and training for the younger generation, the issue of innovation, research, and development.

Because these are the niches that will allow Europe to be competitive in the global space. And today I must say that, regrettably, the European educational model has failed and fallen short when compared with the model of emerging countries.

Like India, like China, like Brazil, it is today a less demanding and less rigorous model, and therefore it is also requested that in the boldness of this idea of innovation, development, research, and education, there be rigor and demand within the context of European educational systems.
Only with this rigor and demand will we prepare our young people to compete in the global market.

We cannot think only of this year's crisis or that of the next two or three years; we must think of the strategy for Europe over the next ten to twenty years, and it depends on an educational system of rigor and demanding standards.
Mr. President, Commissioner, never until today has the European project, built with so much effort over the last 50 years, been so threatened.

The frustration of European citizens is immense; the financial system that was meant to serve them has destroyed their savings, their pensions, their investment plans, their jobs – in short, their future.
Regarding the necessary strengthening of the entire financial services market—banks, insurance, and securities—the path forward is clear and lies in the architecture we are discussing today.
We do, in fact, need a robust European supervisory architecture, one that covers all products and actors, and is equipped with methodologies and instruments.
effective interventions and that are capable of responding to the reality of a market that, especially within the European context, does not recognize national borders.

Risk cannot and should not be eliminated from the financial market, but we need regulation that makes this risk more transparent and that prevents the accumulation of bubbles whose explosion affects the entire system and spreads to the real economy.

However, if despite these new safeguards future crises occur, it is crucial to have mechanisms that limit contagion, particularly concerning the banking system, because it is vital for the functioning of the economy and the safekeeping of citizens' savings.

Here, precisely, in the powers and responsibilities of banking authorities lies the capacity to implement a new strategy on the management of cross-border banking crises, a topic addressed in my report.
It is not within our power to prevent the bankruptcy of banks, but rather to ensure that their reorganization or eventual liquidation are carried out in
in an orderly fashion, limiting collateral effects on the rest of the system and, above all, preventing the taxpayer from bearing the costs of the crises they generate.

For this, a set of new instruments is necessary. It is necessary to adopt rules, definitions, methodologies, instruments, and terminology common to all stakeholders in restructuring, reorganization, or liquidation operations.
It is necessary to harmonize the relevant national legal frameworks for crisis management, notably bankruptcy and liquidation laws.
It is necessary to grant supervisors extended intervention powers.
It is necessary to define clear criteria, not only quantitative but also qualitative, that allow interventions to be initiated in a struggling institution.
Contingency plans must be prepared.
This entire process, for 27 Member States, requires time.
And meanwhile, approximately 50 of the 12 banks operating in Europe represent 70% of the assets.
Now, this signifies a substantial concentration of risk, but also an opportunity to intervene with priority regarding them.

Therefore, conditions exist to propose a special and urgent process for engaging with banks, which, being cross-border in scope and having relations with other banks, possess a potential systemic impact on the financial system.
Now, for these banks, it is possible to anticipate special supervision by the new European banking authority, although operating within the College of National Supervisors.
It is possible and urgent that they, in light of the risk they generate, begin to make contributions to a fund that finances potential interventions.
that are necessary, and it is important that the banking authority create a specialized unit to coordinate interventions in the event of difficulties at these banks.
Overall, the proposed elements ensure that interventions in transnational banks of systemic importance are consistent and coherent among the
different countries and, above all, that a principle so dear in Europe be upheld: that the costs of pollution caused by these banks be borne by the polluter themselves.
This proposal fits perfectly within what we are discussing, particularly concerning the competencies of the banking authority. I would even say that it is the most evident test of its effectiveness.
In the case of the vote in the Economic and Monetary Committee, there was an overwhelming majority in support of this proposal, 87 votes.

We also count here in this plenary session on a massive vote from this institution, in the sense that, by massively supporting this proposal, which is visionary, which is realistic, but which is pragmatic, we
Let us undertake an action that is urgent and necessary to revitalize the hope of Europeans in Europe, in its financial system, and, in particular, in the banking system. Thank you very much.
Thank you very much. -Bretô, to underscore only four points,

Mr. President, Commissioner, I would also like to begin by thanking the rapporteurs for this excellent work.

Deforestation, as we know, is one of the principal environmental and social problems of the planet, and each year, we lose 13 million hectares of forest, thereby contributing to 20% of the globe’s carbon emissions and constituting a significant threat to biodiversity.

The contribution of deforestation to climate change is undeniable and, as such, it is largely responsible for the occurrence of extreme weather events, floods, or even the desertification of vast areas of the planet.
Deforestation places all of humanity at risk, but this risk and this impact are not equally distributed among us.
Communities with fewer resources and those most dependent on the forest and nature for survival are the most affected.
Deforestation pertains to our coercive existence, the scarcity of natural resources, their distribution, the rights of local and indigenous communities, and social justice.
The primary cause of deforestation is the illegal exploitation of timber, which accounts for 20 to 40 percent of global industrial wood production.
Therefore, we are also discussing the transfer of wealth from producer countries to consumer countries in the same manner.
This illegal practice endangers the sustainable exploitation of timber and the companies that engage in it.
Fine words are not enough.
This Parliament should adopt strong and decisive measures in this fight.
This report represents a very significant step in that direction, by establishing the prohibition of timber trade.
Good intentions are not enough either.
Effective means are necessary, notably sanctions, which in this case may be of three types.

First, fines that effectively remove the economic benefit of the illegal practice, increased with recidivism; second, the confiscation of the timber and products in question; and third, the immediate suspension of the authorization to exercise a commercial activity.

And this is because whoever explores or commercializes a natural resource must be socially responsible, and it is also because whoever places wood or wood products in the European Union for the first time must be required to exercise due diligence to ensure that it is wood exploited legally.
That is why all subsequent operators must provide basic information about this timber, namely its origin and its destination.
The population must also have the right, and here I end, Mr. President, the right to access information about who complies and who does not. Thank you very much.
Madam President, Europe needs to renew trust and hope.
In a crisis still in the past, we had the firefighters, as Jacques Delors said.
We hope the Belgian Presidency will bring the architects.
The first test, naturally, will be, in September, the Council’s convergence with Parliament’s proposals regarding the financial architecture.

But today, one of the greatest European challenges is to ensure that the European currency does not collapse, whether due to a lack of supporting instruments, a lack of growth in the Eurozone, or, above all, the growing divergences and internal tensions caused within the economies that comprise it.

Cutting structural funds today, as proposed by the Commission—funds created to stimulate convergence in economies that diverge—appears to be like firefighters stoking a fire that is not yet extinguished.
We clearly need architects.
One final question I would like to know about the external dimension of European Union action, particularly, to learn a little more about what the Belgian Presidency proposes for Cancun and Doha.

Agricultural policies are increasingly market-oriented, and farmers in Europe are facing very low income levels, while millions of consumers, as a result of the crisis affecting everyone, find themselves in the primary necessity of maintaining affordable food prices.

That is why, if farmers' incomes are to depend increasingly on the values generated in markets and the price of foodstuffs on their proper functioning, then improving the functioning of the food supply chain is essential.

It becomes absolutely necessary for a more equitable sharing of the value generated, from agricultural producers to final consumers, ensuring fair incomes for the former and appropriate prices for the latter.

To that end, it is necessary to rebalance the relationships established throughout the food supply chain, to imbue them with transparency, ensuring the existence of a framework of fair and competitive best practices.
In this regard, we support the Commission in considering the proposals widely supported in the Committee on Agriculture.
A few days ago, in Aroca, Portugal, all the workers at a footwear company were dismissed via a simple mobile phone message, without further explanation.
Bring this case here because it is, unfortunately, a flagrant example of collective dismissal abuses in Europe.
It contravenes all European norms and wounds any semblance of common sense, respect, and dignity.
Europe, since the crisis began, has seen 8 million new unemployed individuals, bringing the total to 25 million. How many have been dismissed in such a shameful manner?
I would say it more and more, unfortunately.
The European Union claims a long tradition of safeguarding workers’ rights.
However, the current thaw has not been effective.
So, what additional measures will the Commission take?
That is why this question is so pertinent.
There is no justification for dismissals such as Arroca’s.
Firing someone via SMS will be an innovation, but it is not a good innovation; it is extremely poor security. Thank you very much.
The environmental catastrophe currently under debate, although occurring outside the geographical space of the Union, concerns us all, European citizens.

The notion of sustainable development we embrace is a concept that possesses no administrative boundaries, nor religious beliefs, and that views the planet as a whole and not as the sum of its constituent parts.
Therefore, the Jordan River is a problem for all of humanity and not solely for the populations or communities directly affected by water scarcity or its low quality.
Think globally, act locally, common sense tells us.
That is what we are here today to do, to think globally.
As the European Union, we must help facilitate local action as a means of minimizing and reversing this ongoing degradation of the flow and quality of the waters of the Jordan River.
And to act or assist in acting, the Union already has a legislative, institutional framework and instruments at its disposal.
I refer to the Union for the Mediterranean, its secretariat, and the FEMIP, managed by the European Investment Bank.
This is, obviously, a theme that the delegation of this Parliament, which I preside over, the relationship with the Mashreq countries, will follow closely.

It is evident that the action leading to the resolution of this environmental tragedy should, first and foremost, be undertaken by States and local authorities, whose populations directly benefit from it.
Within this context, I would like to highlight two ideas present in the resolution.
Firstly, the creation of a commission for the management of the entire Jordan River basin, comprised of representatives of the States or authorities that utilize those waters.
And here Europe can help, by sharing, for example, the experience of the International Commission for the Protection of the Rhine.
Secondly, the support and dissemination of good practices concerning joint community projects involving Jordanian, Israeli, and Palestinian citizens.
Notably, those promoted by Friends of the Earth Middle East, which the colleague of Rossi now invoked, regarding the efficient and correct management of water resources in the Jordan Valley Basin.
Finally, Mr. President, and within an even broader scope, to highlight the example of cooperation and peaceful coexistence that this design embodies.

At the moment when, while regretting the absence of the European Union in the process, we welcome and encourage the resumption of the new direct dialogue process between Israel and the Palestinian Authority, we wish to commend this direct engagement of the two parties.

Madam President, we are discussing here today yet another situation of human rights violation, that of the imprisonment of the Syrian activist Aytan al Malé, an 80-year-old lawyer, accused of disseminating false and exaggerated news that undermine his country’s national sentiments.

Beyond the violation of numerous international treaties and conventions, the imprisonment of this human rights defender is also contrary to the country's own legislation, which stipulates that military courts should not have jurisdiction to try civilians.

The decision that was made regarding this man and regarding other Syrian prisoners detained for similar reasons, the various detentions, the restrictions on freedom of movement, and the arbitrary measures taken.

The measures taken by Syrian authorities are practices that contradict Syria’s important role throughout the region and do not reflect the efforts that have been made in that country to improve the social situation.
I repeat, we discussed another human rights violation today.
It is not possible to separate it from the various discussions we had here this week.
I highlight two points: first, the rejection of the death sentence by stoning imposed on Sakineh Hashtani.
Many voices have united, and some results have already emerged.

It is not yet time to claim victory, but far less is it time for us to remain silent. Secondly, we approve today an important resolution against the abuses imposed by the Sarkozy government on Romanian and Bulgarian citizens.
The defense of human rights knows no borders and is not a struggle that can be fought only elsewhere.
Today, we offer a good example of how to resolve it behind closed doors as well.
The unjust imprisonment of Aitane al Malé unites us all here today.
She is a human rights advocate.
Human rights defenders must be free people, and that is what we demand of Syrian authorities.
We, also defenders of human rights, will not leave him alone, thank you very much.

Mr. President, the fact that the security profile of new medications tends to become fully known only after their entry into the market imposes the need for a pharmacovigilance system more effective than what has existed thus far.
We are facing a typical risk management problem, but at a macro and supranational level, we are bringing it closer to citizens now.
New medications have played a fundamental role in public health and advances in healthcare over the past decades.
Adverse drug reactions remain the fifth leading cause of in-hospital mortality.
The proposals presented reinforce the contribution of medicines to modern public health through a community-based pharmacovigilance system, enhancing coordination and transparency.
It aims to monitor, detect early, communicate, and evaluate adverse reactions.
The new medications will have a graphic symbol indicating that they are still under scrutiny.

User participation in control is encouraged, studies of effectiveness at the national level are stimulated, a new sensitivity to environmental consequences is fostered, and community control institutions are improved.
It is for this reason that I congratulate you, Mr. President, on the proposals.
I congratulate the rapporteur, as well as the Committee, for their spirit of cooperation, and also the Spanish Presidency.
Therefore, with the proposals presented in this legislative package, welcoming with approval the final document that will be voted on tomorrow.
Mr. President, first and foremost, I would like to express my gratitude and congratulate the rapporteur, as well as all colleagues who were involved in this process.
We know that adverse drug reactions are the fifth leading cause of hospital mortality—it never hurts to repeat this—and a strong, transparent drug surveillance system is essential.
We now have the opportunity to reinforce the safety of medicines already available, going beyond laboratory tests, which do not always anticipate problems.

If concrete examples were needed to justify the importance of a new system, consider what happened with the H1N1 flu vaccine: the speed with which the vaccine was placed on the market and the negligence in investigating the side effects that were detected and which continue to delay a complete investigation.
It is therefore necessary that we continue to deepen this path.
This directive ensures the more active involvement of healthcare professionals and patients in identifying difficulties.
Indeed, cooperation between countries and the Union can be a positive-sum game.
Mr. President, Commissioner, a Europe without economic, social, and territorial cohesion is not a Union.
Mountainous regions, islands, and areas with low population density have their own, considerably difficult challenges that must be overcome in the name of a Europe of the people.
But we must move beyond statements of intent, otherwise we have the opposite effect, that is, we reinforce inequalities.
These regions are enormous reservoirs of important resources.
Biodiversity, forests, wetlands, and green spaces provide an essential service for everyone, yet they suffer from the resulting limitations on their economic viability.
that which to reciprocate.
The populations of these regions must be collectively supported by all.
There are two proposals.
First, the potential contribution to science and development.
Many of these regions are authentic open-air laboratories, given their richness, but lack equal access to resources for research.
Why not, then, equip them with centers of excellence in research, generating quality jobs and revitalizing their economies?
A second proposal concerns energy.
These regions can and should serve as the foundation for projects that demonstrate the potential of self-sufficiency and energy sustainability, notably through the microgeneration of local sources.
It reduced that dependence, increased that equality, and the creation of employment.
Finally, I wish to state that using GDP as the sole or primary indicator for the allocation of funds in aid can only result in further injustice.
It is therefore very important to use complementary data, notably that which portrays the social and economic reality of these regions.
I cannot help but make a special reference here to the people of the Azores, Madeira, the mountainous regions, and the depopulated inland areas of Portugal.
With their efforts, they contribute greatly to development and the quality of life for all Europeans.
These and all regions have their own context.
Social, economic, and territorial cohesion should not be viewed as an act of charity.
This is where it is decided whether or not we want a genuine European redistribution policy.
I consider, for all these reasons, this resolution to be an important, but initial step.

Mr. President, Commissioner, the objective of territorial cohesion, now enshrined in the Treaty of Lisbon, embodies the value of European solidarity and the commitment of Member States and the Union to reduce disparities between the various regions.
However, it is not enough to express in the texts of treaties the objectives to be achieved.
There are regions of the Union that have persistent constraints that strongly condition their economic and social development.

Therefore, it is necessary to implement specific programs that effectively and realistically overcome the backwardness of these regions, by promoting an adaptation of their development model to their potential and resources, and contributing to the achievement of the objectives of the EU 2020 Strategy.

This incentive for these regions should result not only from the instruments of regional policy, through its structural adjustment mechanisms—such as the Cohesion Fund and the four Structural Funds—but also
Also, from a different utilization of the various sectorial policies, which have a significant territorial impact in each region and can therefore have a stimulating effect on their economies.
For the determination of European assistance to these regions, it is certain that we should maintain GDP as the primary indicator of eligibility.

Nevertheless, and considering its inherent disadvantages, it becomes pertinent to resort to other measurable criteria capable of providing a more realistic picture of its level of development, such as the unemployment rate, population density, or the level of education.
Only in this way will it be possible to have a more complete picture of the complex reality of the most disadvantaged regions.

Recall, for this purpose, the case of the outermost regions, whose status is recognized by the new Treaty and which constitute a group of regions within the European Union that possess specific characteristics and merit special treatment as well.
The regions of the ultra-periphery, united by their particular characteristics, also diverge in their levels of development.

Similarly, in relation to these [entities], complementary indicators to GDP should be utilized, capable of providing a more complete description of their specific reality and thus contributing to a more accurate determination of their level of development. Thank you very much.
I welcome this motion for a resolution that calls for the need for the existence of a European strategy that makes it possible to translate the principle of social cohesion and equal opportunities.

The Territorial Treaty gains with the Treaty of Lisbon, in opportunities for the populations of territories suffering from various permanent natural constraints to participate in the European project.

I come from a region, the Azores, where these constraints accumulate and intensify, as in other regions designated as outermost regions of Europe, as per Article 349 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.
Following the Commission’s communication, celebrating the outermost regions as a triumph for Europe in 2008 and subsequent extensive debate, in which the outermost regions themselves participated
Relatively, we also now await our version of this strategy, which will need to take into account not only our constraints, but, above all, our potential.
I therefore appeal to the Commission, renowned for its presentations, so that we may establish the best strategy before the debate on new perspectives.
financial, because we must first define the content of policies before allocating the necessary means for their execution, as has indeed been happening with Community policies currently under review.

Mr. President, Commissioners, dear colleagues, after four consecutive years of decline in the unemployment rate from 2004 to 2008, the current economic crisis has undone much of the progress achieved.
Unemployment rates in the European Union have experienced a significant increase; for example, in Portugal, we have reached the record level of an unemployment rate of 11%.
Another negative phenomenon is youth unemployment in the European Union.
Europe is currently traversing a period of transformation and faces immense challenges.
The crisis nullified years of economic and social progress and exposed the vulnerabilities of its member states' economies and, consequently, of the European Union itself.
Strategy 2020 outlines the path forward.
The European Union must intensify all its efforts to promote employment and social inclusion, as an integral part of its strategy to combat the economic and social crisis.
Thus, the proposal for a resolution concerning the future of the Social Fund, currently under debate, is welcomed, as this Fund plays a crucial role in achieving the objectives of the 2020 Strategy.

In fact, this fund is the primary financial instrument that enables the European Union to achieve the strategic objectives of its employment policy, improving the levels of education and qualification of its citizens.
The ESF should be strengthened as the main driver of the 2020 Strategy and should be used by Member States to invest in employment skills, training, and professional retraining.

Finally, I would like to emphasize that the reform of the European Social Fund, to be carried out in conjunction with that of the other Structural Funds, should facilitate and simplify its management and implementation.
to reinforce transparency, as well as to concentrate funds on achieving results and realizing objectives that are effectively felt by citizens in their daily lives.
The European Social Fund is likely the most structuring instrument of cohesion.
It should, therefore, have significant coordination with the Regional Development Fund.
It is essential to adopt a global approach to the issues at hand, that is, a global perspective for local action.

Local and regional authorities are the entities best acquainted with their realities, their investment needs, and job creation, as well as the most suitable measures for promoting employment in their regions.
We must take into account the positive experiences of the regions.
In the Azores, an ultraperipheral region where unemployment typically reaches record levels, the unemployment rate is 6.5%, the lowest in Portugal.

This is largely due to the prospective planning strategy employed for employment, outlining factors to act upon, how to achieve the desired objective, and also the utilization of the European Development Fund as an operational instrument of this strategy, influencing education, training, and employment promotion.
The Eurozone aims to support cohesion; it is the only way to guarantee strategic stability.
Cohesion policy is the cornerstone of European solidarity.
It is through cohesion that the objective of reducing disparities between regions is achieved and the harmonious development of the entire European Union is encouraged.
In the forthcoming 2014-2020 period, we must establish a framework capable of strengthening the effectiveness of regional policy.

Governance at various levels should be encouraged with greater involvement and participation of regional and local entities, in respect of the principle of subsidiarity and as foreseen in the new Treaty of Lisbon.
The special situation of the outermost regions must not be forgotten.
This set of regions faces very significant challenges and should continue to benefit, in the future, from specific provisions in the application of European policies.
GDP should continue to be the primary eligibility criterion, but we should consider other indicators that can provide a more complete picture of regional realities.
aged and with extremely low birth rates.
These factors represent enormous challenges for the European Union, to which we must provide concrete responses.
This finding has been universally agreed upon throughout our discussion, despite the diverse perspectives that this debate has highlighted.
In Portugal, for example, the birth rate does not ensure the renewal of generations and reveals a reality that compromises the future.
This situation occurs in my country, as it does in most Member States of the European Union.
I am confident that more flexible policies regarding maternity leave could help reverse these trends.
We must send families a consistent message of support for motherhood, with concrete measures to improve the reconciliation of professional, private, and family life.
Women should be protected so that they can choose to have children without having to leave the workforce.
The successful completion of this challenge is essential if we are to achieve the economic and social objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy and combat demographic aging.
In Portugal, for example, maternity leave is already fully paid for 120 days, in an attempt to counteract the low birth rate that we are experiencing.
I therefore argue that women’s salaries should be guaranteed during maternity leave in the manner outlined in the report under discussion.
Allowing each Member State, by 2020, to establish the conditions that guarantee full salary payment during maternity leave appears to be a sensible procedure.
Finally, I commend Rapporteur Edita Estrela for her persistence in advocating for measures aimed at protecting families, while simultaneously working to counter the dispossession of the population.

Colleagues Lena, Swoboda, Rohrberth, Diana Wallis, and Rebecca Harms, who were part of the parliamentary team that negotiated this framework agreement with the Commission.

I would also like to record the great openness and highly constructive spirit of collaboration of the President of the Commission and, following the formation of the new Commission, of Commissioner Šefčovič and his teams.
I believe a remarkable work has been achieved, leading to a historic agreement—an agreement that represents the first framework agreement following the signature of the Treaty of Lisbon.
Lisbon and the first Framework Agreement, which has a direct basis, a basis expressed in the treaties, more precisely in Article 295 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.
I would like to say that this agreement, in fact, creates a relationship of great transparency and dynamism, even of a certain intimacy in the relationship between the two countries.
Parliament and the Commission and essentially represents a compromise, a balance between the two institutions’ views on the new role that each of them plays after the Treaty of Lisbon.

I believe that the work of our negotiating team was, in fact, very positive, because it managed to give expression, within this framework agreement, to those which are the new competencies and the strengthening of powers resulting from the Treaty of Lisbon.
This applies to the legislative procedure and to programming or planning, specifically, for example, just to give two examples, in the involvement of Parliament in
work program of the Commission or, for example, in matters related to the use of soft law in those areas where the Commission exercises legislative powers belonging to Parliament.

Secondly, a very important aspect is the strengthening of Parliament’s powers of control and scrutiny, whether concerning the detailing and specification of the rules for the election of the President and the Board of Commissioners, or, for example

Regarding the Parliament's involvement in matters such as government reshuffles or the potential dismissal of a commissioner, or, for instance, the hearings of directors of regulatory agencies, as well as the monitoring of international negotiations.
In all these dimensions, there was indeed a consecration of powers—powers that result from the layout of Lisbon.
It is also very important to have access to information and, in particular, access to classified information or information that is
confidential and, furthermore, the exchange of information and the exchange of viewpoints between Parliament officials and Commission officials.

For example, we know that it is already possible for the Commissioner responsible for institutional affairs and the President of the Commission to participate in the relevant parts of the Conference of Presidents.

I would therefore say that, with profound respect for the Treaty of Lisbon and its new balance of powers, and with profound respect for the idea of the separation of powers,
We have here a clarifying agreement that will make the Treaty of Lisbon current, will make it alive, will make it applicable.

Madam President, Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, I begin by congratulating the rapporteur for her work, as well as welcoming all those who collaborated with her on this report, which made it possible to achieve this agreement at first reading.

Subject to these, which in some Member States are unreasonably lengthy when involving public administration.

The negative effects of this practice on the economic life are enormous, both at the level of small and medium-sized enterprises and at the level of the domestic market, and these negative effects can no longer be tolerated, especially as we are experiencing an economic and financial crisis like the one we are going through.
This legislative amendment serves to provide coherence and meaning to the European economic recovery plan and the implementation of the Small Business Act.
business act, I am certain that this directive will improve the liquidity of companies.

Mr. President, there is currently a significant disparity in many Member States regarding payment terms to companies, particularly when the State, SMEs, and large corporations are involved.

We who have come from the business world know that, in this situation of economic crisis and pronounced financing difficulties, businesses are increasingly grappling with liquidity problems, and in many Member States are even exposed to a significant risk of insolvency.
It appears clear that the current directive, which attempted to regulate this matter, had limited effects, therefore the proposal we are now analyzing represents an important step in fulfilling
of payment arrangements, not only in the relationships between companies and public entities, but also, and this is essential, in the relationships that companies establish with each other.

We now have legislation that brings us greater added value, with a clear system of sanctions for payment delays and that also brings about an effective improvement in the balance of the abuse of dominant position established by the State and large companies.
Madam President, Madam Commissioner, allow me to speak of the unspoken.

I listened very attentively, Commissioner, and from what I heard, it appears to me to say that, until a certain point, it seemed that the most effective action, both by the national authorities and the European authorities, was the management of silence.
Industrial accidents can and should be avoided; it is also for this reason that European legislation exists, and it seems obvious that the law has been violated.
There was ineffectiveness, delayed response, and abandonment of those affected, particularly the most vulnerable.
People have died, and many continue to be threatened today regarding their health.
It is impossible to calculate the total costs, and it is immoral not to care for the victims.
How is it possible, I ask you, Commissioner, that we learn of news through accounts reaching us from Hungarian citizens and the authorities see or tell us nothing?
That is why I would like to raise some questions.
How can one allow the bank to pressure citizens with mortgaged homes in the affected area, demanding that they pay what they owe, when their houses have lost value?
How can it be allowed for telephone operators to cut off the sole means of contact for those in a disaster zone?
How is it that the company responsible for this catastrophe has already resumed operations?
And, finally, Commissioner, she spoke of mitigating the effects of the mudslides.
I ask you what the reasons are for continuing to mitigate the true magnitude of this human tragedy.
It is that it seems as though we are always about to start from scratch.

The indicators that will measure the progress of the 2020 Strategy must not be overlooked either.
A reliability study on the issuance of European common bonds could constitute an opportunity to deepen and implement financial instruments for defense against speculation.
We wish we could have gone further than a simple study.

The establishment of a European monetary fund deserves our support and we see it not only as an instrument of discipline, but above all as a means of reducing speculative manipulation of sovereign debt markets.

Mr. President, I begin by congratulating Commissioner Barnier on the presentation of this important document.
As you diagnosed, the impact of the crisis we are experiencing is being felt in all sectors of society and our economy, causing our citizens discouragement and distrust regarding the single market.
But it is precisely this single market that is one of the trump cards Europe possesses to combat the current crisis.
Therefore, we warmly welcome this communication, which represents a new ambition for the policies of the single market, allowing us to restore confidence in our model of social market economy.
In the current situation, the European Union must give particular attention to its 20 million small and medium-sized enterprises.
In this respect, one of the Union’s priorities should be the creation of mechanisms that resolve the problem of access to credit for these companies.

We also highlight the Commission's proposal to evaluate the Small Business Act by the end of 2010, with the aim of facilitating the lives of these businesses, particularly through bureaucratic and fiscal simplification, as well as the promotion of social responsibility.
We hope that these 50 measures, now presented, will contribute to deepening the internal market, fully leveraging its potential, which could represent supplementary growth for the European economy.
Mr. President, we are here today to discuss what has been presented as one of the European Commission’s highest priorities: the innovation policy.
It takes shape finally, notably through European partnerships for innovation and with this pilot project that we are discussing today regarding active and healthy aging.
However, there are many aspects that still need to be defined, particularly in terms of clarification, in terms of defining future projects, and in terms of priorities.
Who, ultimately, will define the priorities and on the basis of what criteria?
I believe these answers are owed to us.
But I would like to leave some notes, specifically and in particular, regarding this first project on active and healthy aging, which was the one presented to us.

And these notes are, from the outset, a positive note, because it seems to me positive to focus on a sector of the population that is particularly vulnerable, in a Europe that is increasingly aging and increasingly disadvantaged.
However, I would like to add further questions to these, because it seems contradictory to present a project in this area when, simultaneously, we have nowhere to sustain this innovation.
How are we going to sustain it?
What is the eva?

Is there any viable innovation within a context such as the one we are witnessing, where there is a persistent and systematic attack on the welfare state, on the reduction of access to healthcare, on systematic cuts to services provided, and on continued disinvestment in this area?
The title of the communication presented—a union of innovation, more employment, improved lives, a better society—is ambitious.

I would even say that I would have no problem subscribing to it personally, but let’s agree that it is contradictory to what has been the practice in Member States, with the courts, and with austerity measures.

I believe that only sustainable innovation, if there are rigorous, sustainable, and demanding public policies, will prevent it from being a fleeting spark; otherwise, little remains and few answers do we have for these populations. Thank you very much.
President, esteemed colleagues, we welcome the Commission's efforts to place research and innovation at the top of the political agenda.
We are presented with an integrated strategy to make the European innovation ecosystem more effective and productive in service of a sustainable economy.
European innovation partnerships emerge as an instrument, and the major challenges they address are sufficiently broad as to avoid controversy.
However, it is not yet clear how the sub-thematic priorities will be defined, nor how the preponderance of each discipline within them will be established.
What level of transparency will be expected for stakeholders to participate? How to arbitrate conflicting interests?
What is the relative role of the Commission, the Member States, and the regions?
How to ensure accountability within a complex structure?
What financial dimension will these partnerships have?
The Commission and the Council, Mr. President, must ensure excellence in implementation, which is not guaranteed by the scant pilot testing months foreseen for the first partnership.
