Mr. President, let us be clear: the solidarity mechanism for sovereign debt did not work, nor does it work. The price of Greek debt has not decreased, and Ireland is in crisis.

The economic crisis and contagion were not contained. The process that was created, was created belatedly, is intergovernmental, and should have existed in a different format from the outset of the euro’s creation.
The President of the Commission now proposes a consolidation of this system.
But in the third of the instruments proposed for use, it suggests the involvement of private entities.
We had already heard that proposal to Chancellor Merkel, and it was as a consequence of that premature and inopportune announcement that the markets surged.
Parliament will fully utilize its powers and with the utmost responsibility and spirit of cooperation in the codecision process accompanying the package.
legislative action on economic governance, but not by sacrificing haste or speed, and placing quality second.

Therefore, let us be clear: Parliament will participate actively, but a matter as serious as the resolution of sovereign debt cannot be decided at the margin or in disregard of European citizens and their representatives. The two elements are intertwined.
Finally, we, the Europeans, need a clear European vision at this moment of crisis.

A European mechanism for sovereign debt consolidation is needed, the issuance of eurobonds is needed, and the euro area must be sustainably protected through European, rather than intergovernmental, systems.

It is necessary to reinforce the European budget; we cannot continue with a budget at its current level. It is vital to place genuine growth and convergence at the center of European political priorities.
And this agenda that the Commission and the new president have to defend.
And the President of the Commission cannot be an emanation of the Ecofin Council.
This is what we need to present to European citizens.
Mr. President of the Council, Mr. President of the Commission, I naturally want to say that the EPP’s position is clear, a position to the effect that the Commission cannot do anything.
Resolution of this crisis, this serious crisis facing Europe and the European Union, can only be achieved through a deepening of economic governance and the Community method.

For us, there is no doubt whatsoever that only with greater community coordination, only with economic governance, only with the appropriate instruments of a true single currency within the euro area is it possible to confront and address this crisis.
But this means that each of the institutions—the Council, the Commission, and the Parliament—assumes responsibility before European citizens.
It is necessary to state that it is clear here that at least the largest groups in the European Parliament are willing to cooperate evidently in order to increase
the community method of introducing economic governance, of giving the single currency the necessary conditions to triumph in contrast to the European crisis.

It is also evident today that the same applies to the Commission and to the President of the Commission, who, contrary to what socialists and Deputy Elisa Ferreira claim, have demonstrated that they are neither an emanation of the Council nor an emanation of the Parliament, but an emanation of European interest.
It remains for the Council, now in December, to assume its responsibilities.
It is with this that we count, and with your manifest adherence to the European ideal, President Van der Rohe.
Mr. President, I would like to begin by congratulating colleagues Luan and Manescu on the remarkable work they have done in their respective reports.
They both constitute an important contribution to the ongoing discussion about the new cohesion policy for Horizon 2014.
Today, more than ever, the realization of economic, social, and territorial cohesion is essential for affirming the competitiveness of the European Union on a global scale.
This goal will only be achieved if we are aware that only by reinforcing and developing the regional dimension can we have a cohesive Europe internally and a competitive one externally.

On this matter, I would highlight three points that I consider fundamental: first, decentralization, ensuring that local and regional authorities, particularly those with legislative powers, participate more and contribute to a better implementation of the cohesion policy.

invites Member States to invite regional and local authorities to participate in negotiations on the future of the Structural Funds, on an equal footing with national authorities and representatives, and, finally, to strengthen the role of regional authorities in the preparation, management, and implementation of the programmes.
Only in this way, with the fullest involvement of these authorities throughout the entire process, will the principle of subsidiarity be fulfilled.

Another aspect that I consider crucial is the request for a simpler architecture for post-2013 funds, not as a consequence of the economic crisis, but rather as a general principle of future cohesion policy, in order to facilitate the absorption of the funds.
The primary concern underpinning the Treaty of Lisbon was to bring Europe closer to its citizens.
Let us then not only do that, but also make your life easier, avoiding unnecessary administrative burdens that discourage your participation.
Only in this way will we be able to realize the objective of genuine territorial cohesion.
Only in this way will we see disparities within the European Union reduced, disparities that are currently markedly contrasting and with a vast gulf between rich and poor regions.

Greater participation also signifies greater responsibility, and it is this responsibility that should be assumed and shared by all, doing more and better in order to have a stronger and more competitive Europe.
Madam President, Madam Commissioner, colleagues, I would begin by congratulating colleagues Edith Bauer and Anne Heth on the excellent work developed in this report.
Human trafficking dishonors our society and demands a strong and coordinated response from all.
Organized crime underlying sexual exploitation, forced labor, the trafficking of human organs, and other abhorrent practices must be effectively combatted, but primarily prevented.
What is at stake is the defense of human rights and the protection of the most vulnerable individuals, specifically women and children.
The experience demonstrated that the current legal framework was not sufficiently effective and that the European Union must make greater efforts.
It is essential to have greater cross-border cooperation, including effective information sharing and the exchange of best practices.

Policies in this area should encompass aspects related to social affairs and social inclusion, such as the social rehabilitation of the victim. Thank you very much.
The NATO Summit took place in Lisbon, and therefore, allow me to say a few words about what happened in my country in connection with this Summit.

At that time, Portuguese authorities prohibited the entry into the country of European citizens, and the sole reason for this was that these citizens were carrying critical texts concerning the alliance.
In those days, the least we can say is that an arbitrary regime prevailed in Portugal, a veritable police of thought.
A regime so exceptional that it led the Portuguese Government to purchase riot control equipment valued at 5 million euros, which did not even arrive in time for the summit.
And these are, after all, the priorities of a government facing a massive social crisis.
In the Europe we dream of, freedom of expression is a fundamental value.
The Europe we dream of does not bow before military organizations that write their history with blood.
The NATO summit resulted in the legitimization of its military intervention worldwide.
There has also been the subordination of the European Union to military strategy and American interests.
Thirdly, the militarization of access to energy sources became established.
Finally, it established the military defense of a development model that generates environmental imbalances and that exacerbates social crisis.
Therefore, Madam President, I wish to state that, in my view, with this summit we have lost ground in democracy, we have lost freedoms, and we have lost so that some may profit from war.
Madam President, the first point I wanted to make clear and which is important to reinforce in this Parliament is that the Commission cannot simply be a speaker.
Contrary to what is sometimes read in the press and in the statements of some European leaders, the euro, as a currency, has been fundamental in responding to the current crisis.

Without the euro, we would be in a difficult situation, with the currencies of the more fragile countries experiencing enormous devaluation and with a potential German mark appreciating to an impossible level, unable to sustain the German economy and the European economy.
And therefore, the euro has been a factor of stability, especially not only for the countries within the euro zone, but also for the currencies of countries that chose not to join the euro zone.

And precisely because we must defend this community that has managed to respond to the crisis in no other way and as we will see in the future, for example, what will happen to the dollar and the United States of America, we will see how the euro indeed has advantages.

We now have the responsibility within this Council to do everything to defend the euro, specifically to establish a stabilization fund that follows the community method and is capable of introducing accountability into

countries that are in a more vulnerable situation, vulnerable and solidarity with those who have fulfilled their obligations and who have not always shown, at least in their external declarations, a willingness to be supportive in the context of Zone E.

I would like to extend my sincere congratulations to my colleague Sorbou for the excellence of the report produced, strongly advising that the Commission take it into account, particularly in those aspects where the complex dimension of agricultural issues, which far exceeds the strict dimension of agriculture itself, is of paramount importance.

agriculture require the involvement of other areas, such as competition, the internal market, and financial regulation, as well as others that also require their treatment in other extra-community forums, such as the G20 or the WTO.

The issues that are absolutely determinant for agriculture, for farmers, and for the provision of sufficient food in quantity and quality to the populations of Europe and the world can only, in fact, be addressed if they are tackled in all their dimensions.

The ambitious objectives of the CAP reform can only be achieved if the reform transcends the strict boundaries of agriculture and its objectives are equally considered in the necessary interventions of other policy areas and in other global-character organizations.
This report prompts my and the guarantor’s acknowledgement.

Mr. President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would like to begin by thanking you all for the words that have been expressed regarding the report that Parliament is presenting on Alzheimer's disease and other dementias.
We are all aware that the situation we are experiencing is substantially dramatic and remains significantly underdiagnosed, as was stated here.
And I simply want to refer to an issue that was transversal to all the interventions, but probably not so emphasized, which is the question of patient dignity, of their rights.
and not only of the patients, but also of their families and those who care for them, whether formal or informal caregivers, and the professionals associated with this type of illness.

I am genuinely pleased, frankly delighted, with the Commissioner's words when he states that he shares the same concerns as the European Parliament and that the European Commission views all the recommendations in the report presented by the Parliament very positively, and will do everything within its power to implement them.
We know that each passing day is later than the last, in this matter, given the urgency of what we have at hand.
And therefore, we also know that tomorrow the Parliament will pronounce itself on this matter.
We will await the result of the vote, but we know, Commissioner, that European citizens expect much more from us than solidarity and moral comfort.

They expect concrete and appropriate actions from us, and I sincerely hope, Mr. Commissioner, that you will put them into practice and that the Commission, which has initiative and, unfortunately, this Parliament does not, will put them into practice.

All this priority afforded to this domain and which transforms it into legislative initiative so that citizens and their families see their rights respected and are treated with the equality and dignity they deserve.

First, I would like to say that this Parliament, on a day when we are discussing the Hungarian Presidency, without prejudice to being able to address all the topics it wishes to, should concentrate on the problems of the European Union, which it is not doing here.

or aspects that are aspects of Hungary’s internal life and that, at most, could be regulated within a healthy and normal relationship between the European Commission, the Hungarian Government, and the Hungarian Parliament.

Food, which is entering a severe global crisis, energy, which is essential for our security and economic sustainability, and water, which has received little attention, but food will be the next challenge for Europeans.

Madam President, I believe that these two countries, like others in this region, show us how, in recent years, European leaders have often sided with business interests over democracy, and with dictators rather than the poor.
I am frankly concerned about the situation currently unfolding in Egypt and today’s developments, and that is why I believe we should not be calm, but rather demonstrate solidarity.
Solidarity with the millions of Egyptian citizens who are in Cairo and throughout the country, fed up with hunger, fed up with oppression, fed up with unemployment.

And that is why, after today, after Mubarak’s speech, after the regime’s dogs have been unleashed, after a clear and unobstructed path to violence has been created, we must say that we need to stand alongside these people.
We cannot allow a strategy of fear to be created so that they return home.
Thirty-six years ago, in Portugal, we would have returned home had we heeded that advice.
It is well that we did not return, for in that way we had a democratic revolution.
Mr. President, Commissioner, I would also like to say that I believe this matter is very important for us to move beyond the deception in which we have been living in Europe.

Deception is a false promise, however one wishes to term it, because we have been operating, particularly in the area of terminal cell collection from umbilical cords, based on misleading information.
And we know, and it has already been mentioned, that in Europe the collection of terminal cells via the umbilical cord does not reach

And yet, we also know that its possibilities for treating diseases may be inexhaustible. Diseases like those already mentioned, such as cancer, Alzheimer’s disease, and rare diseases, offer immense possibilities.

But what we allowed to happen was the establishment of a set of private cell preservation banks, telling parents that they could store their children's cells and, from that point onward, at the time of birth and from then on, cure them in the future, if necessary.
I believe we should be more responsible than that, because the likelihood of that happening is very low, as we know.
And this false promise, which is sold to parents, costs money.
In Portugal, for example, this false promise costs three and a half minimum wages.
The solution clearly involves creating public banks, terminal pools, because only with public banks can we guarantee equal utilization, equal access.
An effective medical treatment and further research that is equal for all, and not simply utilize stem cells as merchandise or a business that is growing, but is only for some.
Therefore, I believe solidarity, common sense, and impartial information are not, in the end, things that can be classified as excessive demands.
We do not have the power to impose, we have the power to promote.
This falls within our purview; I believe we should do it in the name of equality. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, the price of food has reached a historic high and this is the seventh consecutive increase.
And there are several factors that can explain this increase, with the first being a short-term factor.
It relates to the coincidence of adverse weather conditions in some countries, such as Russia and Argentina.
But there are two factors that are foundational, of a foundational order, and that is why I bring these two factors up here.
The first concerns the fact that some food producers and consumers who were previously exporters have become importers, as is the case with China.
The second concerns the fact that the weight of some large multinational corporations can secure rulings in their favor regarding pricing.
And the example of cereals is this very clear level that is dominated by six large multinationals.
This situation therefore places farmers in enormous uncertainty regarding food product prices.
Europe must, therefore, return to doing what it ceased to do some time ago, namely, protecting its producers and consumers.
In a world where everyone resorts to forms of protection and where multinationals manipulate prices, we cannot continue to be naive. Thank you very much.
(SAMANTA) I will explain to the rapporteur colleague, Marisa Matias, and offer my greetings to all those who collaborated with her.
Regrettably, over the past several years, we have witnessed an increase in pharmaceutical counterfeiting in Europe.
According to data from the European Union, one and a half million boxes of counterfeit medications are sold annually through the legal supply chain.
This is a criminal activity that represents a serious threat to European patients and to the European industry.
The objective of this directive is to prevent the introduction of falsified medicinal products into the supply chain and, thereby, to protect public health.

I would like to highlight the following key points in the partnership I developed: the introduction of the definition of counterfeit medicine, clearly emphasizing consumer protection, and the application of the devices

the security of prescription medicines, the accountability of all stakeholders in the distribution chain, and, finally, the application by Member States of effective sanctions to deter this criminal activity.
Mr. President, I want, of course, to thank all the comments that were made by all colleagues.

I believe that if there were any doubts about what the word commitment means, it has become quite clear here what commitment means.

We do not all have the perfect proposal, but far more important than knowing if it is the perfect proposal is knowing that we have an instrument in our hands that will allow us to no longer delay the protection of patients' health.
And we have the obligation not to delay its adaptation either, we have the obligation not to delay real action, and we can only do so together.
I must also say personally, and the Commissioner mentioned, that in my initial proposal, I presented an amendment for mandatory inspections in third countries.
Commitment is precisely that, and yet, one gains in some things, one loses in others.
We were informed by the Commission that obtaining this would be impossible.
I would also like to add another note regarding this commitment.
I believe we all see ourselves in this commitment, but I also think and am aware that we will all be demanding to ensure it is fulfilled, because otherwise it will not be effective.

This commitment ensures safeguards so that we can monitor the process, evaluate, and systematically obtain information that allows us to verify whether it is being implemented, appropriately or not, and if adjustments are needed.

I therefore wish to conclude by thanking the European Commission for its collaboration and, in particular, the Spanish and Belgian Presidencies, with whom we have worked closely over the past six months.

And as my contribution is also full of shortcomings, I failed to thank colleagues Regina Bastos and Amália Sartori, from the partners of the other committees.
Thank you very much for your support as well.
Mr. President, Commissioner, it is hardly necessary to reiterate that the current moment represents the most serious test of the euro’s survival, and therefore, of Europe’s.
The Polimata report opens constructive solutions, and for that reason, I also want to commend our colleague for the ideas she puts forward.

The gravity of the moment does not stem from the fact that the Eurozone as a whole has an excessive deficit or external debt, but rather from the fact that the economies that comprise it persistently and severely diverge under the impact of the common policy.
We lack instruments that allow for the convergence between these economies, that allow Europe to regain balance, that allow Europe to grow.

Let us be clear: the euro zone and the European Union cannot survive with the current level of integration and the diversity of the economies they comprise, with a budget of 1% of the collective wealth.
In practice, after the crisis, the only solution we were able to construct was the recipe of austerity, and it is workers and businesses who pay today.
the deficits generated by the speculative crisis in the financial sector, for the rescue of which 26% of the European Union’s wealth was committed.
The financial transaction tax, levied at a very low rate, for example, 0.05% on transactions of highly speculative, high-risk products, is indeed true that these should be paid by their consumers.
But why should they not pay if common citizens pay VAT on bread, on milk, and on the most basic products?
The tax burden must be redistributed to affect workers and businesses less and to be shared more equitably among the financial sectors, particularly the speculative ones.
And, Commissioner, I believe it is not for the Commission, at this moment, to reject or shy away from the clear message that this Parliament is giving it politically.
The public consultation cannot exclude the analysis of the financial transaction tax; rather, it should be analyzed with the highest priority.
(FELIPE) We know very well what happened with the A flu, and that should serve as a lesson to everyone.
I don’t know if you recall well how all this began, but the truth is it started in one way and then the response was completely disproportionate to the scale of the problem.
That is why the report voted on here today is so important, because we must learn from what has been done so that what has been done is not repeated.
We have the right to know who made the decisions, how the entire history unfolded, and who determined that it should have happened this way.
We have the right to know which countries responded in a certain way, why they responded without transparency, and why they did not allow us to stay.
Without a shadow of a doubt, because we retain all doubts whether or not there is a deal, we must have the assurance that no trace remains, whether or not there is a deal related to this influenza.
That is why, Madam President, I understand that all threats to public health must be confronted, but it is not irrelevant how they are confronted, nor who pays for them.

Mr. President, Commissioner, we are here discussing proposals regarding salaries and proposals regarding the retirement age, and the least we can say in relation to these proposals is that they are frankly unfair.

We could not accept that.
The other thing we have in common is that workers and retirees and pensioners are paying for this crisis, and an entire generation of precarious workers is also paying for it.

There is no guarantee in the society in which we live, and it is for this reason that I would like to conclude by saying, Mr. President and Mr. Commissioner, that we cannot continue to condemn people to poverty.
I sincerely hope
Thank you, Mr. President, I begin by saying that I fully support what my colleague has said.

The prevention of natural and human-induced disasters is of enormous and increasingly significant importance, and the European Commission consistently presents a number of procedural intentions and timelines.
But there is a very complex problem, as has already been mentioned.
The Solidarity Fund is an instrument that typically responds to these situations, but responds in a very, very protracted timeframe – nine months to a year – and this after the catastrophe.

As has already been mentioned, and as I have repeated and will repeat as many times as necessary, in the case of timber, there was a significant disaster a year ago and no support has yet been received.
And I ask this, and reinforce this question: is it not the appropriate time for the Commission to review the procedure of the fund itself and of the financing model itself?
How can we maintain an exceptional fund to address situations that are increasingly chronic?
We do not know where it will happen, but we know that it will, and climate change is there to prove it.
Therefore, an exception can never address a situation of regularity, thank you very much.

Mr. President, the concerns raised here regarding disaster prevention and response are a matter of great sensitivity and of utmost importance to our populations, which must not and cannot be exploited.

We are discussing highly sensitive situations that impact the safety of people and their possessions, situations that often evoke emotion in all of us due to the loss of life, the devastation of families, and the ruin of entire working lives.

But all our expressions are of little value when confronted with the dramas that, in a mediated fashion, impress and sensitize everyone, if subsequently we fall asleep on the work we must do to ensure that those situations can be avoided, minimized, or, better still, assisted.
Commissioner, the matter here is very well focused by my colleagues.

It is an area where the European Union can best demonstrate its presence among its citizens, assisting them in disaster prevention, particularly when these events occur, and standing by their side during times of greatest need and vulnerability.
I would gladly respond, although I do not wish to transform a debate in the European Parliament into a debate about Portuguese politics.

Incidentally, if Deputy Edita Estrela wishes to debate Portuguese policy, she has a simple solution. We should hold elections, present candidates for the Portuguese Parliament, and have the opportunity, in the opposition, to debate with the PSD government the policies it intends for Portugal.
I say only the following: we can no longer endure a government that has failed four times over the years.
It is impossible, it is unsustainable, it is not credible to the markets, there are no more solutions for the socialist government.

Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, I begin by congratulating Mr. Schwab on the commercial persistence that led to this important agreement and I also congratulate everyone who collaborated with him on this report.

We aim not only to ensure a high level of protection for European consumers, but also to enable European businesses, whatever their size, to provide goods and services to consumers in the 27 Member States without unnecessary legal obstacles.
This new directive will end the legislative fragmentation that has been harming the participation of our companies in the cross-border market and will give a significant boost to the internal market.
We highlight the new provisions concerning information to be provided to the consumer, requiring that this information be clear, comprehensible, and furnished in a timely manner.
It is also important that the burden of proof regarding compliance with information requirements now falls upon the merchant.
Regarding distance contracts, particularly those concluded by telephone or over the internet, their rules must be defined and the consumer protected by simple and effective mechanisms.
We are certain that, at the conclusion of institutional negotiations, the new directive will contribute to making the European Union more competitive and dynamic, as is required in a global economy.

Madam President, President of the Council, President of the Commission, first and foremost, I would naturally like to congratulate you on the results of the Council of 24 and 25 March, notably the consolidation of the European Semester.

but far more than that, whether through the institutionalization of the European Stability Mechanism, or through the, let's say, closure of the Europolis pact, which was already coming from the euro area summit of March 11th.
I believe these are very positive results for Europe, and it is regrettable that this process was not fully concluded on March 24th.
I believe that if we had given that signal, if the States had given that signal in the Council, completely closing this package of Fund reforms, we would be in a position today

stronger to face the three, four months and, in part, we would have attenuated the effects of the crisis that my country, Portugal, is currently experiencing, and on which I also do not want to remain silent.
to state that, in the case of BPSD fully integrated into the PPE, there is absolute and complete availability to fulfill the requirements and obligations of integration within the European space.
That is what we have been doing, even now, at this moment, when there are difficulties regarding short-term funding.
Unlike what the socialist government has done, the Social Democratic Party has demonstrated a complete willingness to provide Europe with the guarantees necessary within the context of this crisis.

And with that, I want to give this signal, without bringing domestic politics into the European Parliament, of the commitment, the commitment, the total guarantee of the Social Democratic Party to the rigorous agenda that the country will have to follow after its June 5th elections.
Madam President, esteemed colleagues, Commissioner Stefan Füle, the historical moment we are living through demands firm and resolute action.
Like many of you, we observe the events unfolding in the Mediterranean basin with a mixture of hope, concern, and anticipation.

However, I am satisfied with the proactive position the Parliament is preparing to adopt regarding the review of the European Neighbourhood South policy, which I hope will lead to a greater presence of the Union in this region, not only as a payer, but equally as a committed partner.
From the outset, by affirming the absolute necessity of defending our founding values in relations with neighboring countries.
We can no longer compromise on the defense of democracy, nor on the defense of human rights, and even less on the defense of social justice.

We can no longer prioritize short-term stability at the expense of the superior interests of citizens and their uncompromising defense, their individual and collective freedom, with particular attention to the rights of women.
In the future, the Union must prioritize a bottom-up approach in its neighborhood policy.
It is essential that this occurs.
Only the greatest involvement of local communities and civil society will guarantee maximum effectiveness in its implementation.

But I cannot help but express a frustration. I regret that this Parliament and the Commission do not wish to seize this opportunity to definitively differentiate the Eastern Partnership policy with countries that potentially may become, in the future, our partners in the Union, from the Southern Neighborhood policy.
I also challenge the Commission to demonstrate, in its review process of April 20th, the ambition that the current moment demands of a neighbourhood policy.
Tailor-made, designed for each State, with clear benchmarks and a careful evaluation that allows for a future Mediterranean economic space with the new democracies of the south.

To conclude, Mr. Commissioner, we trust that the positive atmosphere and cooperation that have characterized the work on this topic will lead to the permanent involvement of the European Parliament in the planning and evaluation of this policy. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, the reports we have debated and which today’s rapporteurs I congratulate reinforce a set of initiatives that aim to relaunch the internal market.

I would like to highlight the commitment of the European Commission, particularly that of its Commissioner Barnier, whom I welcome and whose positive reception of this Parliament I acknowledge through his
Committee on Consumer Protection and the Internal Market, to prioritise market competitiveness and dynamism, a fundamental pillar of the 2020 Strategy.
Citizens and businesses expect effective measures to enable Europe to regain economic growth, anticipate increased employment, and aspire to the creation of greater prosperity.

As the Commissioner rightly pointed out, opening the markets to our companies, eliminating obstacles and difficulties, will provide a very special boost and an unparalleled opportunity that will allow them to continue their mission as a driving force of our economy.

Measures aimed at reducing the administrative and bureaucratic burden on SMEs and their access to credit and the services market, the European patent, and the recognition of qualifications are essential.
the relevance of e-commerce development in bolstering consumer and business confidence in this type of commerce, the investment in innovation
essential for strong and sustainable growth. Social entrepreneurship is indispensable for creating innovative business projects for social inclusion.
These are some measures that will ensure this ambitious project of completing, deepening, and fully exploiting the single market for the benefit of European citizens.
Finally, it is important to recommend that Member States redouble their efforts to improve the transposition and implementation of the internal market rules. Thank you very much.
I also wish to add my voice to all those who have expressed concerns here regarding the low incomes of fishermen, exacerbated by historic fuel prices, particularly in recent months.
As has been very well stated here, fuel costs have a very significant impact on the survival of our small and medium-sized shipowners, particularly exacerbating the already fragile income of fishing.

This vestigial rise in prices is also bringing us profound negative effects: reduced opportunities to go to sea, poverty-level incomes for fishermen, exacerbated by the low prices paid at the first sale.

increases in imports of aquaculture and fishery products from third countries to the European market and a resulting abandonment of the activity due to financial difficulties, with further job losses.
In this context, to avoid the continuation of the worsening crisis, it is necessary to act, and to act swiftly and decisively on the problems of fishing.

The Commission must, therefore, provide positive responses, with short-term and long-term measures, to address the adversities facing the sector and the severe income losses being experienced by our fishermen.
Firstly, I would like to congratulate, in particular, the work of our PPE colleague, Mário David, who represents us here today through his absolute dedication.

I did not have the opportunity to attend this plenary session, and I wanted to state that we have always considered support for the victims of the floods in Pakistan to be an ethical and moral imperative.
And for this reason, we strongly support all measures that have been taken in the direction of traditional humanitarian aid.
We even consider that work should continue in the direction of helping to stabilize the situation of so many millions of affected people.
What we cannot accept is that the European Union’s trade policy is now considered a suitable instrument for humanitarian aid.

The truth is that this brings two detrimental consequences: one within the European Union, especially for the southern countries and their textile and clothing industry, which is today highly vulnerable due to an economic, social, and financial crisis unprecedented since the

And secondly, at a global level, in WTO negotiations, where this openness of the world's largest trading bloc, which is the European Union, to these potential Pakistani negotiations could completely destabilize the proceedings.
and it is no coincidence that they find themselves in the impasse in which they find themselves.

It is, therefore, natural that, faced with a situation like this, we had to say, concerning the history of this regulation and the difficulty it encountered during these eight months of intense negotiations to

We will collaborate with the most constructive proposals; however, we will now, unfortunately, have to take a position—a position aimed at supporting the amendment that, essentially, foresees the end of this proposed regulation as we know it.
We must do so at this moment, not out of any lesser solidarity with Pakistan, but because we believe that humanitarian aid should be given in the appropriate place and in the appropriate manner.
Mr. President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by saying that, naturally, I believe the agreement reached for Portugal is a balanced one.
It is a very difficult agreement for the populations, but one that places its fundamental point on structural reforms to increase growth and competitiveness.
And I assure you that this is very positive.

I do not adopt the stance of others who believe that countries like Greece, Ireland, and Portugal did everything correctly, made no mistakes, overspent in no way, and acted appropriately, with the international crisis being solely responsible for the resulting problems.

No, our governments erred and had misguided policies, but that does not mean there is not now an opportunity, within the context of the Union, to have here the possibility of returning to the right path and the correct course.

Therefore, it is important to remember here that, indeed, it is necessary to tell public opinions that are against supporting countries in difficulty that they are not giving money to these countries, they are only lending money to these countries.
But they are lending them out at very high interest rates and, therefore, are making a deal that is positive for their budgets and their populations.

However, I also say here that perhaps it is time to have a global European response, with the admission of eurobonds, with the admission of the possibility of selling in the primary market, to respond to international markets.

It might perhaps be the moment for the European Commission, the Fund, and the IMF to review interest rates, in order to provide the possibility of seeing sustained growth in these countries that are currently facing difficulties, by lowering those rates.
Mr. President, Commissioner, and Rapporteur, this strategy is important for all European countries, especially those whose economy lacks greater competitiveness.
It is essential for the creation of small and medium-sized enterprises.
Today, the creation of new jobs is more active.
It is essential for universities and laboratories, whose relationship with productive sectors depends on part of their survival.
It is essential for the financial system, which will find in innovation a new market, as the classic manufacturing model runs its course.

Innovation is at the top of the European agenda and, being a pillar of the EU 2020 strategy, will need to be supported by new financial instruments so as not to succumb to budgetary constraints arising from consolidation.
Finally, I would like to acknowledge Judith Merkies for her important contribution to a more innovative Europe and an economy more grounded in knowledge.
Mr. President, Madam President, and Madam Commissioner, I would like to begin by congratulating the colleague Odi on his excellent report.

The interim assessment, albeit delayed, allowed for highlighting the critical aspects of the seventh program: its excessive bureaucracy, the industry's disinterest, the number and complexity of the new instruments, and the slow disbursement rate.
There remains a heightened risk of substantial transfers of funds from the current program framework to large-scale programs of questionable added value.

It also allowed for highlighting positive aspects: greater articulation and international cooperation among scientific groups in common projects, some success stories, including the European Research Council, and a greater gender balance.
There are priorities that should be developed first: simplification, secondly, promoting scientific excellence not in some countries, but throughout Europe, a closer link of

A framework program with innovation, with instruments directed at small and medium-sized enterprises and entrepreneurship, of which the most successful is the Eurostar program, which should be expanded. Thank you.

Madam President, Commissioner, I address myself directly to the proposal that I will present to Parliament today and I say to you with complete candor that I believe some of us, both men and women, have the right to be disappointed with this proposal, because the proposal presented is not only weak, but contains numerous shortcomings.
I believe this is a European issue; it is not a question of states that have nuclear industry and those that do not, but of the entirety of Europe, and Europe desperately needs good news.
I must, frankly, tell you that one of the good news items is assuring citizens that we are taking care of their safety.
Now, when these tests are conducted as the Commissioner presents, that is, a first phase is carried out by the interested parties themselves, and a second phase is carried out by the States that

These stakeholders and a third phase are carried out by peers who are genuinely interested, and I ask myself if the result won't be to say, ultimately, that all nuclear power plants are in very good health and are recommended.

We know that is not the case, and therefore, I strongly hope there will be serious consequences and that we can tell our citizens—and our citizens—that we are taking care of their safety and not merely pretending to do so.
I expect this European Council, especially given the atmosphere it has been experiencing in recent weeks, to make a decision of great responsibility.
It is of greater responsibility than that which occurred in the last Council, where an effort was made to postpone a problem for three months, solely due to electoral calendars.

I hope that from this decision concerning essential responsibility, it will become clear that economic and financial matters are crucial and decisive for Europe, but that economic and financial matters are instrumental to that which is Europe’s principal purpose—namely, the purpose of maintaining peace.
If an approach is taken to the problems that leads only to states beginning to distrust one another, to install distrust between the different states.
To create and accentuate differences and rivalries between Southern and Northern states, between central and peripheral states. What we have led to is the decline of the European Union.

I believe that what is at stake in this European Council, irrespective of technical solutions, irrespective of political drawbacks, is knowing whether or not we believe that the European project continues to be a valid project for peace strategy in Europe.
I believe that is what is at stake.
What I observe in many speeches by leaders, both those from countries facing difficulties and those from countries that are donor countries, and that
of taxpayers, is an irresponsible discourse, which often even appeals to certain characteristics of nationalities that are extremely negative.
I appeal, and only for this, to the sense of responsibility of European government leaders to find solutions that lead Europe to an exit and a resolution.

Madam President, Commissioner, my first words are to commend the work carried out by the rapporteur, colleague Giorgio Stravakakis, who has done an extraordinary job in identifying future synergies for enhanced effectiveness between the various structural fronts.

Your report also fits into this joint debate on cohesion policy, a debate that takes on greater importance not only due to the substance of the topic, but also, above all, due to the timeliness of its discussion.
Indeed, we are at this moment poised to learn the Commission’s proposal, both regarding new financial perspectives and the future cohesion policy post-2013.
Cohesion policy is a fundamental policy for the European Union.

It is a horizontal policy that, through its excellence instruments and territorial funds, finances projects and programmes in Member States, seeking to reduce the disparity between the levels of development of the various regions.
However, experience has demonstrated the difficulties, in terms of efficiency and results, that result from the fragmentation and complexity of this policy.

That a single overarching strategic framework for the various funds, with an integrated and results-oriented approach, is the starting point for greater and better synergies among the different instruments and for strengthening their effectiveness.
It is also essential for improved coordination between various sectoral policies and for greater efficiency in the allocation of resources.
We must seize the danger of crisis to seek out new alternatives.

It is true that all these reports we are discussing today will pose enormous challenges, and we know that to respond to these challenges, we also need a good budget, but we must make a clear distinction between budgetary aspects and political objectives.
The political objectives are well known, and indeed, it is by affirming these political objectives that we may offer a future to the regions.

And if that is the case, we must then put the budget at the service of the future of the regions and the citizens, and not the citizens and the regions at the service of the budget. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, cohesion policy is the key policy for the future of the European project.
The construction of a common space, with an internal market and a single currency, requires, in order to function, a certain level of convergence among its member states and regions.
Current competitiveness divergences and development asymmetries have inevitably led to the weakening of the European space and the crisis affecting the Eurozone.
That is why this vital need for convergence absolutely requires a powerful cohesion budget that cannot be weakened to finance other policies.
The European Union, to do more, must have more, and this is achieved by growing its budget and not reducing, even abruptly, the cohesion budget.

Therefore, I ask the Commissioner whether the creation of the Infrastructure Fund and the new innovation policies, which will be coordinated with cohesion and regional development, something which I support, without an increase in the Community budget, cannot be transformed into the Trojan horse introduced into the cohesion budget.

The modernization and renewal of energy infrastructure are essential factors for the sustainable and intelligent growth objectives we seek with the 2020 Strategy and for our energy security, which we require.
It is essential to involve all regions in this challenge.

To this end, the incentives stipulated in regulatory systems should be improved, particularly those applicable to higher-risk projects and more innovative projects, such as those being developed in the Azores islands in renewable energies.

Regions should be linked to the phases of granting and implementing projects, in defining priorities, in their elaboration, and execution, because this ensures better results and, consequently, a stronger defense of European interests.

The current economic climate further emphasizes the need to adopt an innovative and integrated approach to energy issues, ensuring that all economic, environmental, and social aspects are taken into consideration.
It is essential not to lose sight of its medium- and long-term effects, seeking to ensure all European citizens have secure, sustainable, and reasonably priced energy.

Mr. President, the report we have been debating is of particular importance, considering the influence that general interest social services have on the daily lives of European citizens, as well as on social cohesion, job creation, and economic growth.

Collaboration with Rapporteur Próncias de Rossa proved very fruitful and clarifying, as the Rapporteur himself just stated, allowing for the adoption of several commitments in the Employment and Social Affairs Committee.
Considering the result we have here today and that we have debated, I commend and congratulate the rapporteur.
In truth, from our side, the principal concern was to make clear that the competencies in this area belong to the Member States.
National authorities hold the competence to define, organize, and finance general interest social services.
Thus, the creation of harmonizing legislation at the European level is unnecessary, given the highly diverse realities of these general interest social services across the 27 Member States.

It suffices to consider health services, social security, employment, and social housing, which are examples of how proximity and knowledge of contexts are the cornerstone for their appropriate and more equitable provision.

Mr. President, as rapporteur for the REGI Committee’s opinion on the future of international social services, I wish to congratulate the colleague from Rossa, emphasizing the fact that we are dealing with an essential pillar of the social market economy model that we defend for Europe and in which the SIEG plays a fundamental role in its cohesion.

Social cohesion at the European Union level advises against neglecting the existence of minimum protection standards in all Member States, without prejudice to the respect for the competencies of their national, regional, and local authorities.

European regions play a crucial role in providing these services to populations, and their views should be considered, given the specific nature of their constraints, to ensure the provision of services to those populations.

At a time of crisis such as the one we are currently experiencing, international social services constitute a social safety net for the most disadvantaged or for those whose income does not allow them access to private services.

It is important to ensure that Member States decentralizing powers do so accompanied by the corresponding financial resources, so that regional and local authorities can guarantee their proper provision to the populations.
Madam President, honourable Member Ashton, I begin by saying that it is obvious that we must continue to provide support to the democratic revolutions that are happening in these countries.
I don’t have much time and, therefore, I simply want to leave a few notes.
First, we must not forget that the conditions for negotiation, in order to secure a democratic transition and not civil war, must be defined by the peoples of those countries.
The situation in Syria is dire, and this applies to Syria, but also to Yemen and Bahrain.

If we want to avoid civil war, the last thing these countries need is to restrain Europe and meddle in their internal affairs, and especially and very particularly, through the presentation of military or paramilitary solutions.
And if I say this, I say it because we must utterly repudiate what is happening in Libya.
NATO and the United Nations have exceeded all resolutions, even those voted for by the United Nations Security Council.
It is this silence regarding Libya, this repudiation we must make, and it is because it does not appear in this resolution that I cannot subscribe to it.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. President of the Commission, Mr. Prime Minister. Firstly, I would naturally like to congratulate the Polish Presidency for the ambitious program it has brought here and, in particular, to congratulate it for the

neighbourhood policy not only to the east, but also on the southern border, where I believe a challenge is currently unfolding, perhaps more demanding than the one we have to the east, which is more long-term and less short-term.

But, having said that, I would like to ask the Prime Minister and the Polish Presidency to pay special attention to economic integration policies, economic governance, and the supervision of financial markets.
I believe that at this moment, however ambitious our objectives may be in the areas of defense, energy, food security, the environment, agriculture, and multi-year financial frameworks, if we do not

If we resolve, in a clear and solid manner before global markets, the problem of the debt crisis within the European context, we will not have a Europe strong enough to deal with these challenges that the Polish Presidency has set out.

Therefore, I would emphasize the importance of convincing the remaining heads of state and heads of government that it is necessary to provide greater economic integration and greater economic governance to the European Union.

Without it, what will happen is that we, instead of being the drivers or at least the representatives of our peoples, whether in the Council, in Parliament, or in the Committee of European Interest, instead of being that, we will be only
Mr. President, as president of the Mashreq delegation, would it be permissible to offer a sentence about each of my, obviously, four countries?
Beginning with Syria and reiterating what some colleagues have already lamented—that, in the eyes of public opinion, the international community appears to apply double standards.

It is necessary to denounce, if needed, the countries that, in the Security Council—and I am obviously referring to Russia and China, as well as Brazil—but with veto power, have prevented the international community from taking a more consistent position in line with the values we should share.
Regarding Egypt, I believe there is a persistent need to raise awareness among Egyptian authorities regarding the postponement of elections, as was already done in Tunisia.
Regarding Lebanon, I believe it is essential that a very clear message emerges from this debate for the new Lebanese Government.
so that they are aware that they will be judged based on their conduct in relation to the charges brought by the Special Tribunal for Lebanon.

Under Jordan, it is an example of what a peaceful transition is possible and that perhaps there is only a need, at this stage, to raise awareness and encourage the authorities to accelerate the reform process.
We cannot forget, obviously, in a debate of this nature, the peace process in the Middle East and reiterate our hope that the meeting of the Quartet next Monday can be
Indeed, to be productive and to reaffirm that this House would certainly like to see a much greater involvement of the European Union throughout this process.

I have no doubts that there will be a new round of negotiations before the United Nations General Assembly in September, but I hope that this round of negotiations is productive and conducted in good faith.
Thank you, Mr. President, I begin by congratulating the rapporteur and all those who contributed to achieving this work.
There is no doubt that this report constitutes and will constitute a reference with regard to recommendations and robust, coordinated responses to the challenges of the crisis.
The inescapable conclusion is that the crisis we are experiencing will only be overcome with a deepening of European integration.

In a period of severe financial, economic, and social difficulties, and of painful austerity measures, in some Member States, such as my own country, Portugal, there is a temptation to seek refuge in a protectionist and nationalist attitude.
But, Gisele, I was mistaken.

The European response to the crisis requires a genuine European economic governance that pursues sustainable growth, promotes job creation, and develops the social market economy, providing long-term responses with clearly defined objectives to which Member States can identify.
The strategy for exiting the crisis needs to be financed with a sufficiently ambitious community budget.
To avoid a new sovereign debt and euro crisis, closer coordination in budgetary policies is needed, as well as the creation of a system for issuing public debt securities and euro bonds.
I conclude by emphasizing that, during this difficult period, it is also necessary to maintain levels of social protection, particularly for the most vulnerable citizens. Thank you very much.
Madam President, Commissioner, Presiding Presidency, it is customary to say that crises help strengthen Europe.
Historically, that was the case, but today I am not so certain that this continues to be true.

The slow, improvised, reactive manner in which the Union is responding to the Greek crisis exacerbates the situation daily and spreads contagion and a lack of confidence in the Union and its currency in a frightening way.
This, despite the problems of the eurozone, stems from obvious failings in the construction of the single currency, which today are concentrated on its most vulnerable links.

For the current crisis to result in the strengthening of the Union, a strategic vision is needed—as there was in the past—and which, unfortunately, neither the Commission nor the Council were able to impart to the European program and project.
This parliamentary report, however, gives us this vision of more Europe, not less, being the solution.
Parliament recalls that the market and the single currency generate intolerable divergences between economies and that these must be countered by specific policies.

It recognizes that the functioning of the euro requires a strengthened European budget financed by own resources, requires a European agency for the joint issuance of debt, capable of protecting Member States from market speculation.

and to provide them with credit at reasonable prices and terms. It also recognizes that diplomas and the transferability of workers between countries require the mutual recognition of social rights and pensions.
Parliament has united to send clear messages, let us hope that the Commission and the Council will heed them.

Madam President, Commissioner, esteemed rapporteur, first and foremost, I would naturally like to congratulate the rapporteur for considering this report extremely useful and enabling us, in fact, to take new steps in the field of mediation.
The report presents an overview, a snapshot, of the solutions adopted by the various Member States in the implementation, in the application of the
Directive 2008/52/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 21 May 2008, currently relating to mediation in civil and commercial matters.
Now, we all know the advantages of mediation.
On the one hand, it is a judicial system for resolving conflicts, which contributes to the decongestion of courts, to the rationalization of the justice system, while simultaneously providing
providing the parties simultaneously with the possibility of obtaining a friendly, faster, and less costly resolution of the dispute in which they were embroiled.

It is therefore worth noting that it is curious to reaffirm the objective of Article 1 of the Directive, when it calls for the adoption of measures to encourage the use of alternative dispute resolution methods and, in particular, mediation.
Promoting access to and utilization of extrajudicial conflict resolution mechanisms contributes to improving, simplifying, and making our justice system more accessible.

It is, therefore, a very important challenge for the European Union and for the establishment of the area of freedom, security and justice, I would say, for the idea of the rule of law within the European Union.
And that is why, within this context of crisis as well, I consider it very important that, as stated in the report, public opinion and stakeholders can be made aware.
to this topic and appeal to the Commission and the Commissioner to present a legislative proposal swiftly regarding alternative dispute resolution.
Mr. President, Commissioner, I also want to refer to the fundamental importance of this report concerning the transparency of the European energy market.
I simply wish to state that this constitutes a central domain of cooperation in European terms if we safeguard certain dimensions that are fundamental, among them avoiding that
Liberalization translates into increased energy prices for citizens, ensuring equal access, and exercising caution regarding sanctions, as numerous colleagues have already pointed out.
Precisely because this is a central domain of European cooperation, Mr. President, Commissioner, I cannot fail to mention it and to question you and ask you, Commissioner, straight in the eye.
I would like to give you the opportunity to explain yourself regarding the recent statements you made concerning Greece, Ireland, and Portugal, as these are also matters of European cooperation.
Symbolic measures, such as lowering the flags to half-mast, Commissioner, are reinforcing the shame of citizens who are worthy and who fight for a Europe

Mr. President, Mr. Šefčovič, members of the Council, representatives of the Polish Presidency, firstly, I would like to clarify that I will be intervening here in a dual capacity, on the one hand, substituting the rapporteur for the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs.

Constitutional affairs, my colleague Nasser Schmidt, who is Danish and currently absent due to the ongoing electoral process in Denmark, and therefore I am representing him as a member of the AFCO, but also as a member of the jury, as a shadow rapporteur for the jury of this report.

The first point I wanted to make is that, in the crisis we are experiencing, in this economic and financial crisis, the issue of intelligent regulation, of "smart regulation," of better legislation is a central one.

There is no doubt that, in the so-called structural reforms, which can drive the economic and financial recovery of the European space, improvements in legislation and regulation are also absolutely essential.

It is evident that a Europe aspiring, on the one hand, to be dynamic and competitive must have regulations that are simple and accessible to businesses and, obviously, to citizens, and therefore must be oriented toward their needs.
The truth is that, in this sense, it is essential today that, first and foremost, the program of administrative burden reduction is achieved, and that all efforts are made in the direction of
to conduct consultations with market agents, representative citizens' and businesses' associations, and to assess the impact of the legislation itself, that is also extremely important, so that

The decision-making process can essentially be based, let's say, on the opinion of those who are the recipients of the legislation, and can be carried out without administrative burdens and with fewer economic and financial costs.

It is important to state that, for the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, in particular, the idea of the principle of proportionality and subsidiarity is relevant—this idea that European intervention should be an appropriate intervention and not an intervention that promotes the complexity of the system.

and of the regulatory system, and therefore, in our opinion, we give special attention to the reinforced role that national parliaments have in this dynamic, precisely due to the principle of proportionality and the principle of subsidiarity.

It is, therefore, essential that, at the level of smart regulation and at the level of legislative improvement, we now involve the national parliaments, so that whether at the European level or at the national level, both legislation and regulation are addressed.

Let us be more agile, more intelligent, more efficient, and therefore, this is a good moment to put into practice what we announce every day: a more competitive Europe and a more agile Europe through more intelligent argumentation.
Mr. President, the number of homeless people, as well as those living below the poverty line, has continued to rise in recent years in several Member States.
The economic, financial, and social crisis, and the rise in unemployment, have exacerbated this problem, as everyone has already diagnosed.
We all agree that this phenomenon is a negation of important values of the European Union, respect for human dignity, and respect for fundamental rights.

In my country, for example, which is subject to a strong measure of austerity, the concept of homelessness, according to the national plan, encompasses individuals who seek assistance to obtain a meal.
And the number of people seeking help with eating has increased by more than 20 since 2008.
A notable increase is observed in families and individuals in vulnerable situations whose living conditions have been altered by unemployment and also by bank debt.
This is merely an example that demonstrates the gravity of this situation.
Last year, the European Parliament approved a written declaration concerning a strategy of the European Union for the homeless.

With this declaration, this Parliament has highlighted the need for the European Union to develop a strategy underpinned by national and regional strategies, with the long-term objective of ending situations of people sleeping rough and long-term homelessness.

National strategies should focus on preventive measures, but also on concrete actions to improve the quality of services provided to people experiencing homelessness and the availability of affordable housing.
It is also evident that this European strategy must be compatible with the social housing policy of the Member States.
We took good note of the Commissioner's words and recorded the state of affairs presented to us.
I conclude by urging the European Commission to provide a strong impetus for coordinating the action of Member States and regional authorities in order to combat this social injustice.
We debated the peace process in the Middle East, but is there some process underway that has escaped me?
Unfortunately, no.

The European Union repeatedly voices, as does the majority of the international community, its support for the existence of two peoples and two states, sharing the space between the Jordan River and the Mediterranean, who have the right to aspire to live in peace and security.
But without dialogue between the parties, entrenched in a surge of hatreds and misunderstandings that has persisted for 63 years, only extremism and frustrations are fueled.

It is fundamental that Europe and the Arab League become far more involved in seeking a negotiated solution for borders, based on those existing in 1967, with exchanges that allow most of the Jewish settlements to remain in Israel.

May the question of Jerusalem, a holy city, future capital of two states, be clarified and mutually accepted as a symbol of peaceful coexistence between two peoples who have the obligation to fulfill the prophecy of Isaiah that it is the land of milk and honey.

May all countries of the EU participate in the resolution of the question of Palestinian refugees and may the international community, and in particular the Arab nations, participate in the necessary financial compensation.

It is also absolutely essential that a military force, under the aegis of the UN and with the participation, among others, of American and Islamic forces, be deployed on the ground as guarantor of the maintenance of peace.
Thus there is courage and political will.
Mr. President, Commissioner, tourism requires a clear and coordinated European approach, with careful consideration of the potential and challenges offered by the various forms of tourism.
The touristic diversity that the European Union presents is so rich that it allows for exponential growth of this sector and of the European Union’s competitiveness itself.

An investment in this key sector, which represents 10% of GDP and approximately 12% of employment in the European Union, will enable not only the creation of European added value, but also address the economic crisis in which we find ourselves.
It originates from an ultraperipheral region, Madeira, where tourism is the principal economic activity.

Therefore, the creation of a specific heading for the sector within the financial framework of 2014 is indispensable for the cohesive and sustainable growth of tourism, which is essentially comprised of small and medium-sized enterprises.

The implementation of a genuine, sustainable, and diversified European tourism policy requires a concrete strategic plan, with a clearly defined timeline, actions, and funding, capable of reinforcing the visibility and quality of the tourism sector within the European Union.

Mr. President, the absence of an ongoing peace process is jeopardizing fundamental rights and has led to the adoption of unilateral measures by each party, measures that do not need to be taken jointly.

did not contribute in any way to easing tensions in the region and even less to the genuine pursuit of a future for the two peoples who have the right to live harmoniously in peace, security, and with dignity.

The time has come for the international community to say enough, the time has come for Europe and the Arab League to drive the search for a lasting solution, with prudence, presenting viable solutions without delay and with deadlines.
It is evident that the United States and Russia are no longer part of the solution.
Let's begin with Jerusalem, why not revisit the initial idea of a separatum corpus administered by the UN and functioning, obviously, as the capital of the two states?
Boundaries, we'll begin with 67.
Adjust land parcels as much as possible and consistently.

Care for the defense of Israel, a matter obviously unavoidable for the Jewish people, for example, through the deployment of blue helmets with American, European, and Islamic forces along the Jordan River.
There are approximately 4.8 million refugees, and they have the right to their dignity, to a future linked to a land, preferably their own.

But they are not exclusively an Israeli problem, nor a Palestinian one, but also ours, of the neighboring Arab countries, of the wider Arab community, but also of Europe and the rest of the international community.
Columnatos must end its expansion, and this is non-negotiable.
The announcement made today is shameful and betrays hypocrisy and bad faith in an announcement of availability for immediate negotiations.

Above all, we desire good-faith negotiations, earnestly pursued, with a deadline for their conclusion, after which the international community, to maintain its credibility, will have to adopt a different approach.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, since the shameful situation in the refugee camps in Tunisia has been mentioned, we all share, and I particularly share, what my colleagues who just spoke have said.
I will not refer to that, but rather to another situation that is more overlooked, namely that of the citizens who were received into families' homes in Tunisia.

And that is one of the situations that should make us even more ashamed, because let us observe that Tunisia, in a situation of crisis, knows how to be supportive. Europe does not know how to be supportive and is not in a process of transitioning to democracy; it does not know how to be supportive, it does not know how to receive.
I believe it is, in fact, shameful that we can count only a few hundred refugees who have been received in Europe.
Many of these individuals, contrary to what has been stated, cannot return to their homes.
And there were children who were enrolled in public schools, which has implications at the infrastructure level, and implications regarding the reception offered in these countries.
That is why, Commissioner, I am deeply affected by what you are doing, and I do not say this ironically, I say it seriously, but, please, what about the Commission?
And Europe.
What can be done?
How does Europe live so well with this double standard?
We are so quick to repatriate and so slow to assist, Commissioner.
It cannot continue.

Mr. President, I naturally wanted to congratulate you on this supplement of hope that you have given to all Members of the European Parliament and, in particular, to the citizens of the European Union that we represent here.

And having said that, I would like to say that we now expect a very, very determined action from the Commission towards the Council, so that this sovereign debt crisis can be resolved in the short term.
We know it’s a marathon, but immediate signals are needed.

And therefore, without prejudice to the fact that we have all already begun to consider an amendment to the Treaties that would provide political translation for the entire project we have brought here today, without prejudice to that, something must be done immediately.

This set of measures, and perhaps an agreement between the States, what I have termed a kind of parasocial agreement that extends beyond the Treaties and that may, from this moment onward, set in motion all these ideas.
Many congratulations on your courage and your determination.
I believe we are on the right track and leaving here today with a different decision.

Mr. President, the crisis that the European Union is experiencing has had serious consequences in all Member States, and thousands of workers have been affected by layoffs caused by globalization and the crisis.
We cannot fail to express our solidarity with these workers who have lost their jobs and to affirm that Europe must assist Member States in maintaining an employment rate and combating unemployment.
A rapid reintegration of workers into the labor market is a priority objective.

An example of the usefulness of this fund is my country, Portugal, which has drawn upon it four times, although we are aware that access to this fund could be improved, particularly in the countries most affected by the crisis.

Thanks to the existence of this Globalization Adjustment Fund, it has been possible to assist thousands of workers through vocational training measures, support for business creation, and incentives for recruitment.
This proposal is positive because it will allow Member States to request the intervention of this fund to support workers dismissed as a direct consequence of the economic and financial crisis.
We support the extension of the deadline and understand that the Member States most affected by the crisis should have greater access and easier access to this globalization and crisis support fund.
I greet the Polish Presidency and also Commissioner Wally Rehn, simply to say that I believe the gentleman
Today, following and building upon what was presented in the State of the Union address, a very, very significant step was taken to resolve the problems of the Eurozone crisis.
Because the Commission has assumed its commitment here to use its power of initiative and to use it with the Council to resolve this crisis.
I believe this is an extremely important step and the only way we currently have of resolving the euro zone crisis.
There is no possibility of resolving this in the short term, merely through an intergovernmental approximation, and therefore it is necessary for the States, the governments of the States, to give
The Commission has the instruments and the mandate to lead this resolution process, to implement, execute, and develop this roadmap it presented here.
But I didn't want to fail to say that this is not incompatible with what we do simultaneously, with what we develop simultaneously our capacity to alter treaties.

I am also convinced that, in the medium term, it is necessary to amend the Treaties, but also there we will have to do so with the aim of strengthening them, with the aim of giving the Commission more power and a better position.

It is through the strengthening of community metrics, initially in the short term and subsequently with a revision of the treaties in the long term, that we will achieve greater integration and a solution for the 17 countries of the Eurozone and for the 27 countries of the European Union.

Mr. President, Dr. Durão Barroso is here today to announce that banks lacking sufficient capital requirements must submit plans to obtain them, and if they fail to do so, they must then suspend dividends and bonuses.
I could not help but agree with this presentation given by the president.

This week we have witnessed what transpired with Banco Zexia, and just a few months ago, an administrator of this bank received a prize of 600,000 euros for his remarkably successful management, as we know.
But, to be serious, the President of the Commission has to call the governments and present the complete package, and the complete package is what contains the essentials.
The essential thing is that taxpayers' money should be matched by a credit policy for growth.
The essential thing is that banks begin to pay taxes on their profits, which does not happen in many countries, notably in my country, Portugal.
In two years, or rather, in three years, it is the second time we are asked to save the banks with the money of taxpayers, of the unemployed.
(FEL) Banks that save the economy should also help create employment. (SAM) Thank you very much.
Madam High Representative, there are times when I feel I need to make few assessments, and this appears to be one of those times.
It seems to me that this is because we are always caught up in the rhythm of events and responding to event after event, and we lose a bit of the perspective of the whole.

It is true that each case is unique and each country we are discussing here is a specific case, but, if you’ll permit me to say so, Madam High Representative, it seems to me that it is difficult to scrutinize the criteria the European Union has been using to act in relation to each of these cases.
We fear that we are often held hostage by the interests of the countries of the European Union, by part of some of those countries of the European Union, and not by all of them.
That is why we often use the expression “two weights and two measures” in this house, and we continue to use it.

Sometimes it is sanctions yes, sometimes it is sanctions no, sometimes the interference extends to the threshold of the bomb, as was the case with Libya, other times it is total silence, as was the case with the invasion of Bahrain by the forces

Now, the Baroness, let me say that I have studied all the ACER reports attentively; I have yet to see a single statement from European institutions condemning the invasion of Bahrain by the military forces of Saudi Arabia.

These are death sentences, an endless cycle of violence. They are doctors and nurses condemned to up to 30 years in prison by a military tribunal because they were allegedly opposing the regime and not assisting the wounded who needed them.
