Regarding the dictatorial monarchy of Bahrain, regarding the dictatorial regime of Yemen, the Saleh regime, we have had much more silence than action.

I am not in favor of management, never have been, but I fear we are placing ourselves in an uncomfortable position, the position viewed from the outside, Lady Baroness, which is instead of aiding development, aspirations,

democratic and revolutionary actions of the peoples in the Arab countries. Instead of helping the first Arab era, what we do is prevent it from spreading, whether by excess or deficiency, and I don’t believe we should bear that sin.
I hope the awarding of the Nobel Prize to a Yemeni activist can serve as a sign that our side is the side of the peoples who are in revolution. Thank you very much.
Madam President, Commissioner, this is a good report by the colleague Casa.
Firstly, it is necessary to ask why reviewing VAT in the European Union.
First, there is the need to harmonize with the single market.
The more regimes and varieties of VAT, the less fluid the market will be.
A reform of the VAT favors e-commerce, centers competition on the base value and price of goods and services, and not on fiscal differences.
Combating fraud and ensuring trust, so vital particularly in cross-border transactions, strengthens the economy of SMEs and reduces administrative burdens.
What other measures, concerning Youth, are already underway in the single market that could be linked to VAT?
First, a simple, clear, and transparent digital support mechanism, measure 7 of the single market.
Measure 5 regarding services, the need to review legislation on standardization, and the implementation of the Directive.
The new measure aims to remove fiscal obstacles and to explicitly review the VAT system and the VAT equation in online and face-to-face commerce, which we all experience when ordering books.
The pressures for VAT reform stem from two fundamental orders of reasons.
First, the economic crisis.
Further recipes are needed, including, likely, in some countries, a reduction of contributions on labor to promote economic development, shifting that burden to VAT.
Secondly, the second major source of pressures is population aging, demographic aging, and the tendency to shift taxes from indirect to direct taxation, due to the reduction in the tax base.
It is necessary to rethink the balance between direct and indirect taxation.
Finally, we must, in these reforms, reconcile subsidiarity with harmonization.
It is necessary to restrict the variation range in the standard VAT rate so that we may all understand it better.
Greater transparency is needed in the definition of the reduced VAT rate and its scope of application, along with a clear and widely publicized list of reduced rates.
It is necessary to study exemption thresholds for SMEs, fully aware that each exemption is accompanied by a retinue of small or large frauds.
Finally, to welcome the Commission's recent proposal to create a European VAT.
Madam President, I thank colleague Rübig for the excellent report she prepared.

The advantages of public procurement are certainly well known, but the obstacles are also evident. Conflicts of interest between European legislation and the objectives of Member States harm competitiveness.
The dichotomy in price quality and the complexity of laws and procedures are evident.
It is fundamental to examine existing best practices, notably in Portugal, where electronic procurement has functioned well and has facilitated public contracting.
An effective European public procurement represents a privileged means of controlling public deficits and fostering greater growth.
To this end, it must have a stable and predictable legal framework, less bureaucratic procedures to attract SMEs, and uphold social and environmental values.

It is for this reason that I express satisfaction with the intentions presented by Commissioner Barnier here for the revision of public procurement, still this year, as one of the twelve priorities of the Single Market Act.
to congratulate colleague Rula and all those who collaborated with her.
Important within the realm of public contracts is the issue of electronic public procurement.
Unfortunately, the objectives proposed by the European Union—50 of the awards via electronic procedure in 2010—failed, with average values reaching a meager 5.
Only a few countries, such as my own, Portugal, have been successful in this domain.

The advantages of electronic public procurement are, moreover, evident and have been outlined here. It allows replacing costly access processes with the simple consultation of the electronic platform, that is, it significantly reduces costs for companies, especially for smaller enterprises.

Small and medium-sized enterprises, the dissemination via the internet and the ease of receiving procedural documents broaden the number of suppliers, increasing competition and allowing for improved purchasing, render the contract award process for public procurements

Easier and more flexible, it simplifies access to European Union public contracts, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises, thereby facilitating their participation in the market for these public contracts—vital drivers of the economy.

In this regard, we welcome and encourage the European Commission for strengthening the mechanisms to transform electronic public procurement into an increasingly comprehensive reality. Thank you very much.

We are living decisive hours for the destiny of Europe, and if the situation has rapidly, before the eyes of all, shifted from a problem of the Greeks or the Portuguese to a problem of significant European scale, the truth is that the inadequacy of the proposed solutions and their delay have produced no effectiveness in the rapid deterioration of the situation.
The pursuit of solutions targeted at individual States, to the detriment of genuinely European solutions, allowed markets to continue speculating on sovereign debt and imposed timelines and rhythms.
it is absolutely impossible that some States are seeking to achieve with measures of an invincible brutality applied to people, companies, and the public sector.

A common solution, already found for the risk of European sovereign debt, is absolutely indispensable – one that removes market pressure and speculation and provides time for the adjustment that is essential to undertake.
Without it, what we will have in the end are countries that will continue without further means to pay their creditors, devastated economies, and immense suffering.

To my fellow shadow rapporteurs, with whom I had a fruitful collaboration, and I also thank the rapporteurs of the partners from the four committees involved. These partners represent a valuable contribution to this report.
We received 400 amendments and drafted 47 commitments, all of which were approved.
This demonstrates the importance and interest aroused by this topic of new skills and jobs.
It is, ultimately, about preparing Europe’s human resources, anticipating the needs of the labor market in the coming decade.
The key strategy for drafting the report was to reformulate common ideas to avoid repetitions and ensure the report's coherence.
I believe that objective was achieved.
We all know that the crisis currently affecting us has highlighted the vulnerabilities of the European economic and social model, as well as nullified many of the advances achieved in the past.
Since the initial effects of the crisis began to be felt in labor markets in 2008, Europe has already lost more than five million jobs.
Today, there are nearly 23 million people without employment.
Youth unemployment remains particularly alarming; the youth unemployment rate is nearing 21% and represents more than double the overall unemployment rate.
On the other hand, in all Member States, unemployment rates vary with qualification levels.
This means that people with higher qualifications find employment more easily.
We also know that, in the near future, the needs regarding aptitudes, skills, and qualifications will increase across all types and levels of profession.
In this context, Europe faces four challenges: first, job creation; second, the need to develop and remain competitive.
Subsequently, the sustainability of social security systems and, finally, the difficulty in finding people with the appropriate skills to fill job openings.
This report, therefore, has a dual objective: first, to underscore the need for rapid action to address skills gaps in Europe; second, to better anticipate the labor market’s needs regarding skills.

To this end, several measures are highlighted. First, to ensure the availability of skilled labor, it is necessary to improve basic skills, as well as skills in science, innovation, information and communication technologies, and foreign languages.
As I have already mentioned, skill needs should be identified early on, within a timeframe of at least ten years.
Today, the potential of a new sustainable economy, the green economy, and the need for investment in ecological qualifications are recognized.
Subsequently, participation in lifelong learning and professional requalification should be increased, alongside a reduction in school dropout rates.
Another important matter is the mutual recognition of diplomas and professional qualifications, and the urgency of advancing this recognition.
Fourthly, we draw attention to the connection that must exist between educational institutions and the needs of the labor market.
Interns must be of high quality and supervised by mentors, so as to facilitate their transition into employment and eliminate potential abuses of the internship situation.
Particular emphasis is also given to the role of social partners and social dialogue.
The report also proposes measures to promote demand and job creation.
We have a future ahead of us and we must create jobs.
Small and medium-sized enterprises play a decisive role in this objective.

It is also necessary to strengthen the single market to facilitate the free movement of workers and, consequently, the need for coordination of social security systems so that workers can have their acquired rights guaranteed, particularly the portability of pensions.
Finally, the issue of labor market flexibility. To improve the functioning of the labor market, flexicurity rules should be adapted to the socioeconomic contexts of each Member State. Thank you.
Thank you, Madam President. I begin by thanking all colleagues who participated in this lively debate.
All colleagues made very useful interventions and contributed to a highly constructive discussion on an agenda that is ambitious at a time when we are experiencing a serious crisis.

Incidentally, this discussion is taking place exactly on the eve of an EU Council meeting that will show whether or not there is the political will to overcome the difficulties we are experiencing and whether there is willingness
policy for a deepening of our coordination in economic terms and whether there is truly a harmonized and unitary will to carry forward the ambition that exists in this agenda, that is, to have

new jobs in the next decade, new jobs that will lead to young people who are currently unemployed and those who are training having hope in the job market, having hope in an inclusive job market that responds to their

ambition for self-improvement through work and who also have the opportunity to be in a state of perpetual dynamism, keeping pace with the challenges of a globalized economy with a momentum unprecedented in recent generations.

Therefore, our ambition is genuinely to foster job creation, to achieve economic growth not only to address those who are unemployed as a result of the crisis, but also to those who will enter the labor market and also to provide.

a response to the major challenges facing the green economy, healthcare services, transportation services, and housing, all of which require from each of us a different, intelligent, and inclusive vision of the labor market.
Thank you very much to everyone.

Madam President, what we were told here today in the Council’s statement is that, for technical reasons, democracy would have to be sacrificed regarding the European semester, but what we are discussing is a political matter, and the question I pose is whether political coordination can exist without democracy.
Where, then, does the European Parliament's scrutiny lie?
Where does the scrutiny of national parliaments over their major budgetary choices take place?

But, if the question were technical, as it has been stated here, then we are speaking of a variable technique, because we know how the Council substantially eased the conditions for the four countries awaiting accession from France, Italy, Hungary, and Spain; it did not do the same with respect to the countries under bailout.
Consequently, what model of intergovernmentalism is this that allows Germany to offer opinions on Portugal, but does not allow Portugal to offer opinions on Germany?
And, Mr. President, I simply ask that you pay attention to the fact that no problem of democratic legitimacy is resolved by requesting that deputies consult information on the Internet.
This is an issue of under-exclusion, not an issue of democratic exclusion. That is what we are here discussing. Thank you very much.
Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, a first word to congratulate rapporteur Dardenne on the quality and timeliness of this report and also Commissioner Andor on the initiatives announced.
Poverty is truly a very serious problem, requiring effective and rapid action to halt the increase of a phenomenon that, at present, affects more than 80 million Europeans.
The serious crisis we are already experiencing has exacerbated this situation and made the times we are living through dramatic, as stated by your commissioner Andor.
The number of people unemployed continues to rise, and we all know that a lack of employment is a passport to poverty and social exclusion.
This panorama demands resources, resolve, and considerable commitment from the European Commission and the Member States.
If this does not occur, the objective of lifting 20 million European citizens out of poverty during this decade will not be achieved.
Therefore, I warmly welcome the initiative of the Platform against Poverty, which is a very important instrument for ensuring social justice.
But no one doubts that the best antidotes to poverty and social exclusion are the creation of jobs and the promotion of economic growth.
Access to the Internet should today be considered a new fundamental right of citizens, and not merely a commercial object, because this right concerns freedom of expression.
depend on essential things, such as freedom of expression, access to and sharing of information, access to and sharing of culture and knowledge, as well as democratic and media pluralism.

That is why this access cannot be subject to speculative tariffs or contracts that block free choice and the ability to easily change providers, particularly in the world of mobile telecommunications, as we know.
Active citizenship therefore requires that comprehensive and transparent information be provided.
The blocking of Internet usage is not exclusive to political regimes that fear their people.
It can also occur, as a result of economic choices, through the offering of privileges to special clients and through a less egalitarian treatment of clients who are not as profitable.
That is why I support Parliament by clearly standing alongside the neutrality of the Internet and the defense of its totality.
Let us speak the truth.
We have been taking the medication for three years to overcome the crisis, and the situation worsens day by day.
Instead of healing, we created two vicious and fatal cycles.
The first between banks and states.
In Europe, the failure of a state is more easily discussed today than the failure of a large bank, yet it is still expected that banks will finance states and that states will save their banks.
This spiral must be broken.
The Commission must proceed with the European legislation that protects taxpayers from bank crises.
But it is vital, also, to protect the debt of the States from the attacks of speculators.

To that end, it is urgently needed, and has taken some time to prepare, coordinated sovereign debt issuances, whether termed Eurobonds or Stability Bonds, and guaranteed through robust instruments of a community, rather than intergovernmental, nature.
In sum, we must also review the involvement of the European Central Bank.
But the second vicious cycle results from the argument that some states are rich because they are virtuous, while others are poor because they have sinned.
This narrative is politically explosive and technically flawed.

She overlooks the essential fact that a single market and a single currency, built by political choice and among unequal partners, necessarily exacerbate competitiveness imbalances between the center and the periphery.
And that is what must be charted in economic governance.
No, Mr. Rompoi, through sanctions that promote the crushing of salaries and income with one country’s control over another.
Previously, Commissioner, through engagement—both of countries with surpluses and countries with deficits—so as to converge productivity through investment, education, and science.
(FEL) The sanctions have only generated unemployment, disillusionment, and a wave of crisis from which we cannot escape.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, integrated maritime policy advocates for a coordinated approach to the management and governance of the oceans, seas, and coasts, from a global perspective and ensuring coherence with all European policies related to the sea.

Having a global perspective and an integrated approach implies the interaction of European maritime policies and calls for improved governance through greater involvement in the European decision-making process.
The success and relevance of this policy have been demonstrated over recent years through various initiatives funded in the form of preparatory actions and pilot projects.
Consequently, integrated maritime policy should continue to benefit from adequate funding during the upcoming years of the current financial programming period.

In this regard, I advocate for adequate funding until 2013, not only to consolidate previous projects, but also to support the establishment of a stable framework regarding the objectives of this program.

Issues of policy, governance, sustainability, and maritime surveillance are, for obvious reasons, topics of particular interest to certain regions of the European Union, such as the outermost regions.

Rural Units of Production (RUPs) are regions, with the exception of French Guinea, that are small in size and dependent on a limited number of economic activities, in which those related to the sea and fishing hold particular importance.
Furthermore, the outermost regions contribute to the European Union having the world’s most extensive exclusive economic zone.

RMs represent over half of the European Union's exclusive economic zone, approximately 15 million square kilometers, and, together with coastal regions, are fundamental to the economic growth of the European Union and its Member States.
A program such as that of integrated maritime policy should benefit these regions, prioritizing transnational coordination of maritime policies and relevant international cooperation.
It is thus necessary to guarantee continuous and sufficient funding, not only for the next two years, but also and above all for the next financial framework starting in 2014.
To fail to seize the opportunity when discussing integrated maritime policy to underscore the immense potential held within the Atlantic and insular dimension for the European Union.

The Atlantic, being the western maritime border of Europe, also establishes its connection to North and South America and to Africa, conferring a strategic dimension for Europe indispensable in the architecture of a maritime policy designed with an eye toward the future.

And it is with a view to the future that integrated maritime policy, beyond promoting the coordination of maritime activities, should place the potential of the Atlantic in its three-dimensional dimension at the forefront of its priorities, based on science and technology.

Research into the Atlantic crisis, the deep sea, and the seafloor constitutes a new frontier, with potential in biotechnology and mineral resources, and is of incalculable value to the knowledge economy.
The Union should therefore take advantage of the Azores’ privileged position and the location of its oceanographic department to have a deep-sea observatory installed there.
Enough of this way.
When the diagnosis is incorrect, the medications do not work.
And in the case of the eurozone, its remedies have brought it to the brink of death.
The successive miraculous solutions that were proposed were also equally discredited by the markets.
the Financial Stabilization Fund, successive austerity measures reinforcing the Stability and Growth Pact, the troika’s prescriptions in countries under the program.
Rigid discipline, devoid of growth, generated a recessive wave among fully interconnected economies, which were thereby infected with bankruptcies and unemployment.
And, at the hands of the markets—that is, the rating agencies and the speculators—governments are falling one after another, and solvent countries are transforming into insolvent ones.

Altering the Treaties is now another step on this disastrous trajectory, a development that risks destroying what remains of national sovereignty, placing countries in the hands of the European Court of Justice.
No, it is not necessary to alter the treaties.
It is necessary, in this emergency in which we find ourselves, to make two decisions.
First, it is necessary to define a genuine agenda for sustained growth and cohesion.
Where is the 2020 Agenda?
Where is the relaunch budget?
Where are the so-called project bonds for Europe’s structural investments?
And, secondly, it is necessary to protect sovereign debt.
Naturally, aerodromes are necessary, but in this emergency in which we find ourselves, it is urgent that the European Central Bank, directly or indirectly, defend sovereign debt against speculators.
Not in a hesitant way, but with a definitive, resolute stance—as befits any central bank that defends its currency and the economy it supports.
For this, it is not necessary to amend the Treaties; what is required is political will and European conviction.
We will move the Treaty when we have extracted all the lessons from the present crisis, and there are no few lessons to be drawn, but this is certainly not the moment.
Mr. President, Commissioner Dalli, the first forum of the single market, an idea stemming from the GREEK report, took place in Kraków, in
It was rich in content and fruitful in the debate conducted by the Polish Presidency with European, national, regional, and local authorities and civil society.
We have a roadmap, outlined in the Commission's communication of April 12th, encompassing the 12 levers.
The law needs to be passed, as well as the strategy for the other 38 priorities identified in the Act for the Single Market.
For a market to exist, trust is necessary.
Now, citizens’ and consumers’ trust cannot be taken for granted; it requires stimulation and nurturing.

The single market is not merely a transaction of buying and selling; it involves horizontal policies, such as health, social and consumer protection, labour law, the environment, and sustainable development.
The Single Market Forum should, therefore, become a flagship event of the European Union, held annually and with a diverse and increasingly engaged audience.
Mr. President, I believe we are at a point of assessment regarding these crisis policies, austerity measures that have affected so many countries, and also the so-called structural reforms.
And it is within this context that I believe we cannot fail to see how they have generated so much social commotion.
And it has generated social unrest not only in countries facing the greatest difficulties, in southern countries, not only at the so-called peaks, but also in other contexts across Europe.
Last week, Portugal witnessed its largest general strike ever, encompassing both the public and private sectors—a strike that took to the streets.

However, if we look at what transpired today in the United Kingdom, we observe that we witnessed the largest strike ever, especially if we consider how readily people took to the streets, as they have done in Portugal.
We anticipate a large demonstration in Brussels on Friday.

What this demonstrates, Mr. President, and what strikes and people taking to the streets demonstrate, is that the causes and problems we have faced are common, and it is for this reason that the reaction is also common.
The crisis of the European Union is spreading to all member states, reaching unbelievable proportions.

We are witnessing chaos in the financial markets and a growing inability to secure essential financing for the activity of our small and medium-sized enterprises, even healthy ones, leading them to despair, bankruptcy, and unemployment.
It is a spiral that fuels the recession and is destroying the economy and society.

No one denies the rigorous necessity of fiscal discipline, of profound restructurings, of greater economic governance, but these are necessary conditions that, in the short term, are no longer sufficient to counter the ongoing degradation within the Union.

And if it is true that policies are needed to foster employment and growth, without which we will never be able to control sovereign debt, the central question today is to guarantee the financing of our companies and our economies, without which the Union will plunge.
Therefore, more than ever, more than the revision of the Treaties, we need today a strong and secure intervention from the European Central Bank.
Madam President, Commissioner, we are all here today united around a resolution with a set of very important requests in terms of intervention.
We are speaking on World AIDS Day and World HIV Day, and this assessment of the 2009 resolution and communication is essential.
It is fundamental, precisely, the things that have already been mentioned.
And we repeat ourselves, because, unfortunately, there is still room for repetition, which means there is much to do.
There are many new cases diagnosed every year in Europe and the European economic area. A 2010 report mentions over 25 new cases.
If we consider neighboring countries, we are talking about over 100 new cases.
And if we think there are things that cannot get worse, they always can.

One of the points I want to make very clear here concerns the disinvestment that has been occurring in the health sector, as a result of the economic and financial crisis we are currently experiencing.
And this disinvestment has seriously affected domains that are fundamental to combating HIV/AIDS.
Therefore, Commissioner, I believe that here the Commission has a fundamental role to play in requesting that Member States fulfill their obligations in these areas.
A second issue also concerns the increase in discrimination, evidenced by the economic and social crisis, discrimination against workers who lost their jobs because they were carriers of this virus.
And that is why prevention, treatment, and care should be equal for all, regardless of sex, age, or the region where they live.
I hope we can implement these measures with the support of the Commissioner. Thank you very much.
Welcome to this Parliament, Mr. Draghi.
We are living through special and dramatic circumstances, and they require determined and urgent measures.

The spiral between state debt and bank debt must be broken, but at this moment the priority is to defend the states, to ensure that the countries of the Eurozone and the euro itself are not destroyed by rating agencies and speculators.
In the report that we will approve, from Tremosa and Baselt, we have proposals to rethink the architecture of the euro zone, create eurobonds, and a European treasury, but all of this takes time.
At this moment, we are discussing an emergency, and in that context, the only solution rests with the European Central Bank.
Technically, the European Central Bank knows what needs to be done.
Today, do not allow your intervention or actions to be inhibited by limited interpretations of your mandate.
Your mandate is to safeguard the euro, not to deal with inflation.
At this juncture, there is no doubt that saving the euro and doing what is necessary is what this Parliament and citizens expect from the European Central Bank.
Good luck, courageous and sincere, dear ones.
The European Neighbourhood Policy Committee has already taken note, in a very explicit manner, of the positions that the European Parliament has been adopting.

Today it is clear that, without some type of obligation of this kind, properly articulated with the European Stabilization Mechanism, so-called protective barriers, these firewalls for sovereign debt, do not exist, and as long as they do not exist, the euro is in danger and so is Europe.

In the resolution that this Parliament overwhelmingly approved regarding the new Treaty, it became absolutely clear that it is not permissible to continue imposing further rules of fiscal stability, budgetary discipline, and sanctions on euro area countries without taking concrete and urgent steps in the area of solidarity in managing sovereign debt.

That is what we expect from the Commission, and it is now too late.

These individuals, when they provide their personal data, do so under the understanding that it will be protected by European entities and institutions and that it will not be distributed for other purposes.

Mr. President, Mr. President, Commissioner, I understand the rapporteurs, but I would like to say that enough is enough with pious speeches about employment and growth.

Today, with the initial results regarding macroeconomic imbalances in Europe, the veil begins to lift on why, within the European Union and, particularly, the euro zone, some countries prosper while others inevitably struggle.

Europe is losing competitiveness in external markets, and this agenda must be revised because much of the insufficient domestic growth passes through here, but is concentrated within the domestic market.
Four countries, among which Germany, accumulate surpluses successively year after year, while twenty other countries, I repeat twenty, accumulate deficits year after year.
As deficits accumulate, the external debt of these countries increases unsustainably.
Certainly, this process must be controlled.
Of course, discipline is required.
But it is important to ask today, within this framework, whether the solution of crushing the most vulnerable with regressive policies is the only possible solution?
Is fiscal competition from some winners within the domestic market still being tolerated?

Could the best European economy continue to develop common policies that favor it and internal economic policies that, while certain for its economy, capture the largest share of the domestic market's gains for its benefit?
Could the Commission and the Council continue to impose recessionary policies that strain the economies of the most vulnerable, discussing
openly considering the possibility of sovereign states within the Eurozone going bankrupt, while knowing that these firebreaks never left the realm of intentions.
Do the Commission and the Council fully appreciate the explosive political and economic risk that this discourse poses to Europe?
Yes, it is necessary to revise the formulas radically.
But, for that to happen, political will is required.
While that will does not exist, out of respect for the citizens, let us cease saying that we defend growth and employment, because it is not true.
And citizens cannot continue to be deceived.
Thank you very much, Mr. President, I begin by greeting the rapporteurs.

Youth unemployment is dramatic in my country, Portugal; more than one in three young people are seeking employment and have no prospects of finding it.
Our citizens are distrustful.
It is urgent to restore their trust.
After years of imprudent management of public finances, it is time to adopt budgetary consolidation reforms and to put public accounts in order.
But let us not be deceived: austerity without economic growth is no more than a partial solution.
The creation of more jobs and better jobs is the great European ambition.
Measures to ensure that young people do not go more than four months without receiving a job or training offer, as well as to reduce the risk of poverty and social exclusion, must become a reality.
Mr. President, one year ago we witnessed the tragic combination of an earthquake, a tsunami, and a nuclear industrial accident, all in sequence.
Today, we pay a heartfelt tribute to the many thousands of victims of Fukushima.
To honor the victims is to tell them that we have learned the lesson we must learn to deal with natural disasters, with nuclear ones we have the obligation to avoid them.
But, unfortunately, that does not appear to be the truth.
A year after Fukushima, new nuclear power plants continue to be built.
One year after Fukushima, new nuclear power plants continue to be planned.
Japan has, unfortunately, the memory of tragedies that endure: Hiroshima, Nagasaki. And we, Europeans, also have the memory of a tragedy that endured: Chernobyl.
Fukushima obliges us, for all of this, to reopen a debate that should never have been closed—the debate about nuclear energy.
A year ago, nuclear energy was unquestionable for the Japanese. Today, two-thirds of the Japanese do not want it.
They know it costs lives, and they know that this cost is immeasurable; rather, it is a cost that increases from generation to generation.
The stubborn policy in favor of nuclear power is a policy of arrogance.
Here in Europe as well, there is a majority of public opinion against nuclear power, and despite this, nothing seems to change.
There are currently 320 refugees in Japan, of whom 100 will never be able to return home.
What was once familiar is now dangerous, what was once comfort is now ruin.
It is the ruin of a building or house with radioactive vegetation, it is the ruin of contaminated soil or water.

And Fukushima cannot be visited as other ruins are, for example, a Mayan ruin or a Roman ruin, but nevertheless, like these, Fukushima also portrays a civilization, and the ruin of Fukushima portrays our civilization.
that which chose to include in its development model a lethal technology.
An earthquake and a tsunami have no culprits, but a nuclear disaster has those responsible.

We can simulate what happened in Fukushima, and that is why we know that energy policies are national, but in the sky.
As previously mentioned, diabetes affects more than 30 million people in Europe.
And these are, in fact, figures of an epidemic.
It is therefore my understanding that a specific resolution regarding diabetes is also justified, especially since this is the first time this Parliament has addressed this topic.
It is the result of a collective effort and a work that does not negate the work done to date on chronic diseases; on the contrary, it reinforces this capacity we have to intervene jointly.

We have approximately 325 annual deaths associated with diabetes, because we know that diabetes is the primary cause of, for example, heart attacks, blindness, amputations, bankruptcies, and vital organ failure.
Given these data, we have two options, in my understanding.
The first is to say that it isn't so grave, that we can live well with it, and that each government looks after itself.
The second is to say that the absence of a European strategy in this area is part of the problem.
I understand that, from this side, we have much to do.
And we have much to do in early diagnosis, in coordination, in investment in research.
And that is why this Resolution has the value of a beginning and of a collaborative effort in this regard. Thank you very much.
