Mr. President, I would essentially like to say that we are delighted to see steps taken to integrate Serbia into the European Union.

This is very important because the experience of countries like Portugal, like Spain, or like Greece—countries that lived through dictatorships and experienced a set of very serious problems—is the experience that European integration was the way to consolidate democracy.
And for that reason, Serbia also deserves this opportunity.
In any case, I would like to offer here a note somewhat different from those given by my colleagues.

I am aware and acknowledge much concern for minorities, but it is necessary not to forget the Serbian majority. It is fundamental that the Serbs themselves have a place in the European Union and a place of full right.
This cannot be forgotten.

There will be no peace in the Balkans without Serbia, and therefore, however much we emphasize the rights of minorities and they must be respected, we cannot forget the Serbian majority, its identity, and its full right to be European citizens equal to all others, with its own state and its own national pride.
Mr. President, Portugal voted last week on the Treaty, better said, the budgetary ultimatum, which, incidentally, is not a European Treaty, it is good to refer to that.
The favorable vote of the ruling parties reflects the accumulation of decades and decades of stupidity and a typical "good student" attitude—racist, unthinking, and obedient to bad teachers.
The PS's and its leader's position was to transition from a perilous, forceful abstention to a servile vote in favor.

This alliance makes our Portuguese Assembly of the Republic the first Parliament to accept the humiliation of amputating itself from one of its most important functions: to allow the people elected to decide annually on the country’s budget.
This is yet another blow from the European Union, another one. It is a maneuver in which the power of money becomes increasingly beyond the reach of the citizens’ vote.
And I ask you, Mr. President, is it democratic for someone to vote in a way that prevents future voting? Thank you.
Mr. President, budgetary consolidation is imposing almost unbearable demands on some European citizens.
However, fewer and fewer are those who have to bear a greater burden.
The tax burden falls on workers, small and medium-sized enterprises, and consumers, while at the same time, we are witnessing wholly disproportionate tax flight and evasion.
The Group of the Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament wanted to know how much this tax evasion and avoidance is worth in the twenty-seven countries, and it is worth one trillion euros.
This is more than countries in the European Union spend on healthcare.

This signifies a volume so substantial that, were we to invest only one-fifth of this value, investment in Europe would rise from 2.7% of GDP to 3.5%. We are therefore discussing an exceptionally high figure.

The purpose of the resolution we are about to approve, initiated by this Parliament, is precisely a very clear demand to the Commission and the Council to accelerate concrete action to combat tax evasion and fraud.

This means, in particular, concrete initiatives for fiscal cooperation within the European Union, fiscal cooperation with our neighboring countries, particularly Switzerland, but negotiated by the Commission and not country by country on a bilateral basis.
This means reforming and harmonizing accounting rules, increasing transparency and reporting.
This clearly signifies reactivating the fundamental issue of combating fraud and tax evasion through tax havens.
Europe is not a minor partner.
Europe is a significant partner in the international context.
Europe has an obligation, within the framework of the G20, to clearly advocate for a common fight against fraud and tax evasion.

Without this, we lose credibility with our citizens, and therefore, my final words in this debate are to urge the Commission and the Council to initiate an effective fight against fraud and tax evasion.

Mr. President, I begin by congratulating the colleague, Nybler, for the excellent work and I endorse the coincidence of, on Europe Day which we celebrate today, debating and tomorrow approving measures that align with the legitimate aspirations of our citizens.

This regulation seeks to impose limits on mobile tariffs charged to European consumers when roaming, with its primary objective being to eliminate roaming charges within the European space starting in 2016.
Our citizens will now benefit from a significant decrease in prices regarding calls, SMS messages, and data.
If operators currently charge 3 euros per megabyte, from July, the maximum price they may charge will be 70 cents per megabyte, decreasing to 20 cents in 2014.
Regarding incoming calls, the maximum price that can be charged will be eight cents this year and five cents in 2014.
In July 2012, a family with two mobile users will save, as the Commissioner stated, 200 euros on their bill.
Second benefit: higher quality information for consumers.
From as early as the summer, operators will be obliged to inform consumers of the rates applied when they also travel outside the European Union.
Until now, the obligation was only within the European space.
Third advantage: the possibility of more operators entering the market, which signifies increased competition, stimulating better services and improved pricing.

Ultimately, in the near future, the consumer may, if they so desire, have two contracts—one for services within the national territory and another for services abroad—maintaining the same mobile number and receiving only one invoice.
The consumer, our citizen, will also be granted the possibility of contracting with any European operator that offers them the best price.
This report is the perfect example of Europe of citizens, Europe of freedom of movement and freedom of establishment. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, in February 2009, this Parliament approved a report supporting the European Commission's proposal to revitalize the European economy.

There were projects in clean energy, transportation, new technologies, and innovation, and at that time, the role of the European Investment Bank and the Structural Funds was already being considered.
More than three years later, we were able to produce the Six Pack, the Euro Plus Pact, the Fiscal Pact, and the Two Pack, all replete with reinforced discipline and sanctions.

But, meanwhile, while unemployment, especially among young people, reaches alarming levels, the European economy enters a recession and more than seven of its member countries are experiencing negative growth.
And meanwhile, while Greece is no more than a first stone threatening to bring down the castle, the relaunch agenda seems to have been forgotten.
At this moment, that agenda is clear.
What matters at this moment is no longer assigning it a character of urgency, but a character of emergency, in a situation that threatens to explode.
It is necessary to intervene urgently in a set of pillars.
First, it is necessary that the European Marshall Plan be constituted with investment promoting growth, employment, and convergence.
Project bonds are one possible source.
Secondly, it is necessary to stabilize the interest rates at which countries finance themselves.
Let us, at the very least, coordinate sovereign debt issuance and manage the accumulated debt in common.
Thirdly, the European Stability Mechanism and the European Central Bank must prepare to function, in fact, as genuine firebreaks in the defense of European sovereign debt.
Fourthly, the credit that was immensely transferred by the European Central Bank to commercial banks must reach businesses.
It is a billion euros held within the banking system, while thousands of viable businesses die every day due to lack of funding.
Fifth, investment lacks sense without research.
The most fragile economies are crushed by austerity plans.
It is the strongest economies that must unleash domestic demand.

It’s that almost 80 of the exchanges find their home within Europe, and it falls to the Commission, Commissioner Olesen, to make recommendations directed not only to the most fragile economies but also to the most dynamic ones.
And finally, I shall conclude, Madam President, it is necessary to place a limit on the prescriptions imposed by the troika.

To what arbitrary, punitive approach—devoid of dialogue and accountability—with which high-ranking officials determine the fate of millions of European citizens and the democratic institutions of member states. Thank you, Mr. President.

Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Mr. Commissioner, what I wished to convey is very clear: naturally, the Portuguese MEPs of the EPP fully support all measures that may contribute to growth. There is absolutely no possibility of

to exit this crisis without promoting growth, particularly in those states most affected by the financial crisis. But sometimes, when I hear some colleagues here, it gives the impression that they think growth can continue with excessive deficits and more public spending.

Now, we must continue to insist on reducing expenditure and implementing structural reforms. We can proceed on the side of growth, but we cannot abandon the path of restraint and reduction of public expenditure and

More growth cannot be more relaxation, more rest; more growth and more growth policies have to go hand in hand with significant austerity in public finances and significant rigor in structural reforms.
If we only start talking about growth and thinking that there are magical growth solutions, we will end up again with unsustainable public debt and will continue without structural reforms.

Having said that, I wanted to draw attention to the fact that, at tomorrow’s summit, not only will the long-term or medium-term issue of growth be at stake, but the urgent question of Greece will be at stake as well, and I believe it is fundamental that European states stand by Greece in some way.
We are responsible for finding a solution to the Greek problem and wished to repudiate here the statement of the British Member of Parliament who spoke of the Portugalization of Europe, perhaps.
The Portugalization of Europe, at least on the level of values, wouldn't be a negative thing, and therefore I reject this idea of attempting, ultimately, to demean or diminish any people.
We are all Europe, and we all have a place within it.
Mr. President, Commissioner, you came here to tell us that every additional euro spent on debt is one less euro for job creation. Then explain to us why we continue in this obsession.

It also comes to us that one of the summit's priorities is to keep Greece in the Eurozone, and I ask you, Commissioner, do we believe in you or do we believe in Dr. Doron Barroso or Mr. Trichet, who just a few days ago were saying exactly the opposite?
He spoke about the maintenance of the Eurozone and I ask, in which Euro?

in the euro we currently live in, in this zone we currently live in, or in the euro announced yesterday by Deutsche Bank in a study in which it referred to a second-tier euro should the left win these June elections in Greece.
This is a trap, Commissioner, the trap of a Europe held hostage by governments and the trap of a Europe held hostage by financial interests.
Let us not allow people to live in fear, because it is not a way to live. Europe can be something else; the wise gentleman says, there is no lack of money, there is a lack of shame.

Mr. President, Minister Lehmann, the first thing I wish to declare is that it is regrettable that, in a debate of this importance, the Vice-President of the Commission and the High Representative, Ms. Ashton, are not present.
In any case, we are pleased to work once again with the Honorable Minister Vámen, who here made a declaration in which me revo in-ter-

I would, first of all, like to offer a word of comfort and solidarity to the people of Guinea-Bissau, who have essentially been, the people of Guinea-Bissau, a people systematically massacred by democratic instability, political instability, and profound insecurity.
Poverty, already widespread, has been systematically affected by these ills.

I wanted to say, on the other hand, that the PPE, during its Presidency, has followed this issue from the beginning and that it is regrettable that the European Parliament only manages to have a debate on this matter after a month.
This relates to the invisibility of the Guinean people and the Guinean question.

And this invisibility is due solely to the fact that, unlike other matters also very serious, there are no large-scale economic interests at stake here that would motivate European, American, and global powers to debate the situation of the Guinean people.
But I must say, if an external reason is needed, if poverty and political instability are not enough for us to have a global humanitarian and political action, there is…
No less than the situation of drug trafficking that plagues Guinea and directly affects both European and American peoples would be reason enough for us to commit ourselves to this.
And for this reason, I ask the European Union here to be stronger.

There is no doubt that Resolution 2048, the decisions of the European Union, the Community of Portuguese-Speaking Countries, the African Union, but perhaps not those of the Economic Community of West African States, are heading in the right direction.
But resolutions are not enough; action is required.
We must be firmer, we must be more effective with the States that have the capacity to intervene in Guinea-Bissau.
That is our responsibility.

I believe that the European Union, at this moment, is responding well in terms of principles, but is not responding as it should in terms of the practical instruments for operation on the ground, and that is what I am asking of the Council and asking of the Commission.

Mr. President, Mr. President in Office, Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, globalization has brought with it a disproportionate growth of the financial sector, whose transactions are today, as is well known, 70 times greater than global wealth.

Opacity, very frequent transactions, high remuneration, and exceedingly high risk ultimately came to characterize not only the world we live in today but also to be fundamental reasons for the crisis we are experiencing.
However, this crisis demanded accountability and far greater effort from ordinary citizens than from the sector that had caused it.
Thus, today and this moment are important.

It is important, and I would personally like to achieve a situation in which the tax were generalized across all countries of the European Union and subsequently extended to the rest of the world, through active participation of the Commission and the European Union in general within the context of the G20.
I would like it to cover all products, without exceptions.
I would like it to serve as a basis for the necessary strengthening of the European Union’s own resources.
In the short term, commitments must be accepted, but we must not lose sight of where we need to go.
This can only be achieved with a clear identification of these objectives by this Parliament, by the Commission, and with a considerable spirit of compromise on the part of the Council.

This is what European citizens expect from us today, and I can only, here today, thank the role not only of Annapolis Mattei, who was tireless in this process, but of all those who managed to overcome the divergences to reach a common position.

Mr. President, thank you, colleague Podimata. Today, we discuss here, for the first time, the financial transactions tax, and its approval is the first sign that speculation will not go entirely unpunished in this crisis we are experiencing.
This House and the European institutions must answer to the people, not to financial markets.
For decades, the financial markets' lobbyists have managed to govern the world without opposition and without any problems.
It is obvious to us that, during 2008 and 2012, the crisis of the speculative financial market was at the root of most of the problems we experienced.

And yet, these speculative financial markets managed not only to ensure that nothing would be done, but that a direct transfer would occur from the pockets of citizens to those very speculative markets.

For many years, we have fought for this, Mr. President, but it was only when the peoples, across Europe, began to say enough that there was finally some initiative from the institutions that govern the European Union.
And therefore, that is the response we have to give to citizens; it’s a first signal we have to give.
The citizens of Europe, who have everything paid for, do not deserve that we should show them disrespect.
And therefore, this proposal is not complete, it is not perfect, and it will not resolve the entirety of the problem of financial speculation, but it is an important signal.
We have been walking, we haven't, European leaders have been apologizing to financial markets.
They should apologize to those they have affected.
And, quoting to conclude, Mr. President, a currently renowned politician, is speaking of these markets—these markets that govern us without ever having been elected.

I sincerely hope that governments will give a sign of confidence to the people, and I sincerely hope that, with this approval and with the positive vote of my colleagues, we begin to speak of justice and solidarity in Europe.
Colleagues, summon your courage, let’s get this project through.
Mr. President, the financial transaction tax should function as a means of controlling and discouraging high-risk speculative activities within the financial sector.
It aims to reduce speculation and broaden healthy competition, the basis of the single market, and also generate revenue.
The Podimata report sought to align the initial European Commission proposal with the well-known Stamp Tax of the United Kingdom. Thus, we made this proposal more appealing to hesitant Member States.
It is expected that the Council will also understand the message.

If, in the Commission’s proposal, the tax applied to transactions of financial institutions located within the territory of the European Union, the intention now is that transactions involving European assets, even if carried out by non-Europeans, should also be taxed.
This measure will broaden the tax base and reduce tax evasion.
It is expected that tax revenues will be considered as a source of own resources for the Union or the Member States, reducing the taxes of the Member States, a matter still to be decided.
Concluding, Mr. President, I commend the rapporteur for the quality of her work and I hope that this symbolic text…
Madam President, we received yet another request this weekend to save the private banking sector.

They continue to offer the same argument, which is to avoid contagion within the Eurozone. And what I ask is: have we learned nothing from Greece, Portugal, Ireland, and now Spain? Yet, contagion persists.
But what kind of contagion control is this that is destroying us?

This policy isn’t working; we should have known it by now. It’s the same leaders who claim there’s no funding for culture, education, healthcare, or public goods, yet when banks request it from the markets, it suddenly appears, almost miraculously.
This economic policy is not a remedy; it is a lethal poison for growth, for employment, for the European economy, for social Europe.
The markets dictate, and governments obey, black mailing the people—and that is what governments are doing to Greece at this moment, during an electoral period.

I sincerely hope it will be in the best interest of us all, the Greek people, not to be blackmailed next Sunday and that it will give us a lesson, because this recipe, Madam President, is a recipe for disaster.

Mr. President, dear colleagues, unfortunately, the proposals we have discussed here today confirm the prohibition of anti-crisis policies in the Eurozone and further embody the logic of the Fiscal Treaty.

Some statements of intent, but they are very timid. I am referring, for example, to the roadmap for a day when it might be possible to begin considering ways to define a potential legislation for the hypothetical introduction of eurobonds.
The problem is that this day is only when all the problems of the eurozone are resolved, and that is taking a very long time to arrive.
We support certain aspects of this proposal, but, at this rate, it will be too little and too late.
Placing a country under legal protection implies maintaining rates and amounts, as well as prioritizing new loans; that is, it requires the
Member states that honor their debt, but from which all and every instrument that could allow them to grow and find the resources to do so are withdrawn.

Let's be frank with each other. The only legal protection that exists within these proposals and is stipulated is for creators, but even they won't be resolved, because it's not effective even for them.

As we have seen in Greece, Ireland, Portugal, and now Spain, this means condemning countries to recession, unemployment, and insolvency. And to conclude, Mr. President, the worsening of these situations and their spread to other economies bring us closer to a point of no return.

Faced with the complete failure of austerity, the European Commission or the German government propose the same policy to us, but under a guise, and to the neoliberal fanaticism that is killing the euro.
With the extremely limited weather conditions we have, I wish solely at this moment to tell the Commission that it can count on this support, as it always has.
Parliament in effective work in favor of the soundness of the euro zone and of Europe, but which is only achieved when the initiatives that focus on discipline, on

We have managed to add the conditions for a balanced sharing of gains and sacrifices among the different Member States and among different citizens, and a hope that we will emerge from the crisis we are experiencing.
For that hope to exist, other initiatives are necessary, and these are what this Parliament is attempting to fill—an initiative geared towards investment, growth, and control.
of sovereign debt that has been the Achilles' heel, evident, reflecting the fragility of the economic systems of some of the member countries.
Commissioner, you can count on us, the Council and the President can count on us, but the agenda must be a comprehensive agenda; it cannot be an agenda that does
of the discipline, the condition for everything else to follow, even if it makes discipline the alpha and omega of our European proposals.

Our citizens expect this from us, they can count on Parliament, and I want to thank my colleagues again, the rapporteurs, Mr. Gozelski and another rapporteur, and all colleagues who, as shadow rapporteurs or merely active contributors in the construction of this project, were able to contribute.
for a more balanced, more solid parliamentary project, one that I hope will merit the respect, the capacity for dialogue, and the spirit of construction and compromise it has had until now.
Thank you very much, Mr. President, thank you very much, Madam President, thank you very much, Commissioner.

Madam President, beyond expressing gratitude to all those who contributed to this outcome, I would like to request that the final vote be postponed so that we can immediately negotiate at the rail level.
The EU is today confronted with three agendas: the growth agenda, the agenda concerning bank management, and the agenda concerning sovereign debt management.
And treating the European semester implies including these three dimensions.
regarding the issue of growth and I think that, at this moment, it's important to emphasize that the Commission's recommendations cannot solely focus on
Countries with deficits must also focus on countries with surpluses, and if some have to curb their domestic demand, others must release it.

I also believe that, at the level of growth, it is essential that the Commission controls the recommendations of the so-called troika, because when a country enters a recession, it cannot continue to crush its public investment, to crush public spending, as if nothing had happened.
The troikas must have their recipe reviewed and adjusted according to the results. And I want to tell you, Commissioner, that we approved it here in Parliament today.
Parliament needs to launch an instrument for growth and countercyclical activity amounting to 1% of the European Union’s GDP over a period of ten years.

A second dimension, which is fundamental, is the dimension of what is now called banking union. We requested in Parliament that this be done two years ago, in the June 2010 report, and it remains unrealized to this day.

A third dimension is that of sovereign debt; without it, there is no stability in Europe, and I also want to say that today we approved the TUPEC here, but we introduced into the TUPEC, beyond austerity.
some dimension that has been lacking, and it is the immediate establishment of a redemption fund, utilizing German terminology, so that sovereign debt exceeding 60% can be managed collectively.

This is a legislative text, and we anticipate the Commission's positive support for this Parliament initiative, so as to control the entirely threatening spiral that is currently destroying the European Union.

Mr. President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, as we now intend to discuss a growth pact, it is essential not to forget citizenship and consumers, fundamentally, the human and social dimension that our society possesses.

that gives it substance and which was the subject of one of the three reports on the Single Market Act of 2001, because any growth pact should take into account the sacrifices and social benefits associated with it.

As important as an internal market test will be conducting a social impact assessment of all measures taken to achieve the single market—a test, an examination that allows us to measure the progress achieved for the benefit of the citizens of the European Union.
Since 2008, Europe has already lost over 6 million jobs.
In my country, Portugal, the economy is experiencing a contraction unprecedented in its scale, and unemployment among men, women, and young people is reaching historic highs.
According to Bank of Portugal forecasts, the situation will worsen over the next two years.
It is within this context that we support and welcome the initiative of the new employment package and congratulate Commissioner Andor.
Insisting now and always on the basic premise of the need for economic growth, Member States will truly have to concentrate their efforts on job creation.

The means to achieve this should involve subsidies for hiring that create new jobs, a reduction in the tax burden on labor, and support for the creation of new businesses and entrepreneurship, but also for small and medium-sized enterprises that maintain employment.

It is necessary that national employment policies take into account that the areas with the greatest potential for job creation are healthcare, information and communication technologies, and the green economy.
It is imperative, as stated in the communication, to reduce the gap between the qualifications provided by education and the competencies demanded by the labor market.
On the other hand, one of the solutions to combating unemployment involves worker mobility.
It is also crucial to utilize structural funds for job creation and the practical importance of the EUROS portal as an outstanding recruitment and job offer instrument in Europe.
Finally, social governance must be on the agenda, because our citizens eagerly await concrete results. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, Commissioner, it is true that six months have passed since this scandal involving GDP occurred, and the most unbelievable aspect is that a private company may have managed to, for ten years…
to operate in the market and have introduced silicone implants that were intended for the construction and manufacture of collections and were used in women in 71 countries.
This affected several hundred women, as previously mentioned, with an estimated figure of around 500,000.

Now we are discussing estimates because there were failures and serious failures in this process. We know that what happened with this company is a criminal case, it is fraud, it is a legal case, but we also know

there is a fraud here that must be controlled by the courts, and the courts will deal with it, but there is a legal deficiency, a legal vacuum, and that is what we must address. We have responsibilities in this matter.

For ten years, we were unable to identify what the criminals managed to identify, and therefore there was a void in terms of control, in terms of traceability, in terms of the files, in terms of the records – everything failed. However, these gentlemen at this company managed to implement what we were unable to control, and that is why

And in this process, there is not only the issue of a lack of information, which is very important, indeed, a lack of information in all matters relating to breast implants, but also the humiliation of thousands of women and the humiliation, in particular, of those women who have had to undergo testing to determine whether or not they had received appropriate implants.

We are discussing a public health issue, and we cannot be lax when it comes to public health. We regulate so many unnecessary things; we even regulate the authenticity of replacement parts in automobiles, and just recently we approved a directive on this matter.

We must control what is fundamental to people's lives. The revision of the medical devices directive is good news; it was the best news that we wouldn't have to do it, but now that we are doing it, that we apply with

It requires conditions, with traceability, transparency, control, and sanctions, because, unfortunately, the sanctions, even when applied, will no longer apply to women who have suffered this problem, and States must assume full responsibility.
Mr. President, I wished to state here very clearly that for us, the Council to be held at the end of June is fundamental, and what is essential is that a European solution be sought for this crisis.
From our perspective, the problem thus far has been that we have been addressing each of the issues that arise in isolation and individually.

The time has come to have a global solution for Europe, a solution that involves, as President Doulou very clearly stated, greater integration, more cooperation, a closer alignment of European policies, and the strengthening of the Community method.
It is fundamental that alongside stability there be growth, but that we do not abandon concerns regarding stability.
We are therefore counting on a global European response and not on a divided response for each State or each region facing difficulties.
The productive and increased possibilities of production have caused considerable increases in milk production, creating critical situations of surpluses and low prices in the milk and dairy market.

In many regions with strong productive potential, these surpluses were sold off at bargain prices in the markets of other countries, resulting in even greater pressure for lower prices paid to producers in those countries.

This occurred, for example, with French milk, sold in France at twice the price it was sold in Galicia, and producers, with the high increase in the cost of raw materials and factors of production, now see their capacity to withstand low prices as extremely reduced.

This is a poor pronunciation for many explorations and many productive territories of Europe, and it appears to be a clear indication of what may become a future without quotas and without adequate supply regulation instruments.

Therefore, there should be a detailed audit conducted on the territorial impacts of thousands of explorations throughout the European Union resulting from the abolition of these instruments that we currently have to regulate supply.
Mr. President, I begin by congratulating the rapporteur colleague on this report.
This is a matter of extreme importance to Europe.

At a time when we are living through a severe economic, financial, and social crisis, protecting intellectual property rights, by combating counterfeit products, is fundamental for the European economy.
This protection should enhance research performance and promote innovation, ensure scientific and technological knowledge, contributing to the development of new products and services.
All of this with the aim of generating growth and creating quality jobs.

Unfortunately, in recent years, we have witnessed a significant increase in the infringement of intellectual property rights in Europe, representing annual losses, as previously mentioned here, of 250 million euros for companies and the destruction of 185 jobs within the European space.

However, beyond these negative effects on the European economy, the violation of these rights also constitutes a serious threat to the health and safety of European consumers, since many counterfeit products, including foodstuffs, cosmetics, medicines, etc., are frequently introduced.
etc., are produced in unregulated environments.
Therefore, the customs authorities of the European Union play a crucial role in preventing counterfeit products from entering the internal market.
With the revision of this regulation, the aim is to strengthen the control over the application of the legislation in question, reinforce the legitimacy of its intervention, and increase the
legal clarity, adapting the provisions of the regulation to new realities and new developments, thereby contributing to better protection of the European economy and consumers.
Intellectual property rights are, therefore, a crucial priority for achieving the objectives of the 2020 Strategy in terms of achieving smart, sustainable, and inclusive growth. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, indeed, the election of the new Egyptian president, formerly Mubarak, is good news, but we must not delude ourselves, and these presidential elections do not, in any way, close the transition process that is underway in Egypt.

It has been aptly pointed out that the dissolution of Parliament, days before the presidential elections, places several risks on the table and, in this case, the power concentrated in the United Nations Standing Committee.
The Armed Forces were minimally exaggerated, possess legislative power, reduced the President’s authority, and furthermore, retain the power to define changes to the Constitution.

Now, all of this raises some concerns and should raise some concerns for us, because Egyptians risk becoming hostages to military power and a return to the past, lacking a fundamental element, which is a democratically elected Parliament.
It is not for us to make the change in Egypt, it is for the Egyptians.

But I believe that we, Europeans, will have to stand alongside all the changes that propose the restoration of what constitutes democratic legitimacy and a democratically elected Parliament. Thank you very much.

Madam President, dear colleagues, Commissioner, I would begin by congratulating the rapporteur, Lara Comi, on the excellent work developed in this report, which is of vital importance for the future of Europe.
In a world and a society undergoing rapid transformation, Europe needs a comprehensive, integrative, effective, and updated standardization system.
A system that ensures the proper functioning of the internal market, that improves consumer protection and their well-being, but also that protects the environment, is essential.

It is also very important to foster further innovation and social inclusion, alongside the interaction and communication of networks and systems, particularly in the realm, as has already been emphasized here, of new information and communication technologies.
As Professor Monti stated in his report, A New Strategy for the Single Market, European standardisation is essential for the governance of the internal market, as highlighted in the
The need to revise the European standardization process, maintaining the advantages of the current system and finding a fair balance between the European and national dimensions.

In this sense, the report we are now discussing follows and defends these objectives, which are the correct and appropriate ones: to end the sluggishness and fragmentation that exist and which cause companies to incur costs.

due to transaction costs and higher unit costs, to strengthen the participation of SMEs in standardization activities, in particular at the national level, as well as to facilitate their access to those standards, also to strengthen

On the other hand, the participation of parties representing the interests of society, such as consumers, environmentalists, workers, and people with disabilities, should be maintained, along with financial support for European organizations created to represent public interests.
I conclude by stating that the approval of this report will contribute to the relaunch of the European project, to European innovation, and to the strengthening and competitiveness of our companies.
Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, the future common fisheries policy must prioritize its environmental, economic, and social sectors, and the fisheries policy must be privileged.
In a synergistic and non-hierarchical manner, in pursuit of sustainable development and in alignment with the objectives of intelligent, sustainable, and inclusive growth of the EU 2020 Strategy.
As rapporteur for the third scheme, I would like to highlight the particularity of certain regions, such as those that are ultraperipheral, whose economies are heavily dependent on the sector.

In these regions, the reform of the common fisheries policy should seek to ensure the survival and future prosperity of their artisanal and small-scale fishing fleets, thereby safeguarding and defending the employment that depends on them.

I concur with the European Commission’s position regarding the necessity of adjusting this policy and implementing specific measures that should take into account the disparate realities of the fisheries and aquaculture sector in various coastal regions.

I contend that this policy should prioritize regionalization as a form of governance, through strengthened stakeholder engagement, to enable a more appropriate response in the future to the demands and sensitivities of each maritime basin.
We are approaching the decisive moments in which we will shape the new fisheries policy in Europe and we cannot fail.

The necessity and urgency of achieving sustainable reequilibriums in our biotic resources, but also in the revitalization of our coastal fishing communities and the promotion of their socioeconomic level, in the modernization of the sector, and in the provision of quality food, demand, as never before, boldness and courageous measures.
We must, therefore, make choices and prioritize objectives.

I proposed protection for the vulnerability of my region, suggesting that the exploitation of its resources be undertaken considering scientific data and prioritizing our coastal communities in their exploitation, while restricting external access beyond 100 nautical miles to the existing fishing grounds.
It proposed safeguarding the fishing capacity of our important fishing communities, rejecting proposals for transferable quotas.

He proposed that our communities have improved involvement in the management of their fishing affairs through the creation of a regional advisory council specifically tailored for interperipheral regions. I hope that this will allow us to have a better future.

Considering what we know about the application of the third package and part of this issue has already been discussed today, regarding the transposition or delay in the transposition of its directives, the latest information available to the Commission is that…

18 Member States were notified, likely this information is already outdated due to a lack of transposition. The question I pose is how you address the possibility that, in the legislation being prepared, particularly concerning networks
trans-European, if it includes a device, an incentive, that conditions a conditionality for the submission of PICs, of projects of common interest or that

conditions the fulfillment by Member States of obligations arising from the third package or, conversely, considers this to be an extravagant mechanism and that it should be left only to the regular mechanisms of competition, Article 101.
201 and its successors shall have authority over all interventions in this matter. Thank you very much.
The question is whether, while legislation is in preparation and may be approved, we will be able to do our part.
Do you introduce an additional and much stronger conditionality, considering it an abusive instrument, or do you believe that such conditionality would be acceptable?
I confess that I share much of the concern that was initially presented here, regarding the democratic legitimacy and democratic control, which are related to this proposal.

of the Banking Union and Banking Supervision, because an essential issue remains to be clarified and resolved, one that concerns the role of Parliament, the only institution elected democratically by citizens, directly.

But there is another concern as well, a fundamental one, which relates to the following: monetary policy instruments are controlled by the European Union. Monetary policy is the responsibility of the European Union.

Banking supervision is also becoming the responsibility of the European Union, and yet, if everything goes wrong, if banks fail, the responsibility for paying that failure continues to rest with the national taxpayers, it remains a national responsibility.

This is not a minor issue; it is a fundamental problem that remains unresolved. Finally, I simply want to point out that the fact that we continue to tie monetary policy to what is a secondary concern in the context in which we live – inflation – and not to job creation and growth, as it should be, also remains unresolved.
Mr. President, European leaders continue to insist on budgetary discipline, and I ask, budgetary discipline—so let's examine it. What exactly do we mean when we talk about budgetary discipline?

In my understanding, budgetary discipline is respecting contracts with pensioners and not abandoning the State's commitments midway. In my understanding, budgetary discipline is respecting the contracts of those who work and not inventing extraordinary taxes or cutting subsidies.

The budgetary objective is to respect commitments in health, education, and culture, and to avoid closing services or terminating and cancelling projects midway. Discipline means putting banks in order, not using taxpayers to hand over funds to speculators to save their banks.
This is the budgetary area I would like to see implemented in the European Union and not continue with this market-driven free-for-all.

Mr. President, do you need an example? The budget being discussed in Portugal, under the troika’s guidance, is a perfect example. It violates all the commitments any state should have with its citizens, to not violate agreements made behind closed doors that are ruining Europe and its countries.

Mr. President, President of the Council, President of the Commission, firstly, I would naturally congratulate you on the results of the Council, although it seems to me that it is somewhat delayed in time, that the final decision comes a little late.
The truth is that there is an advancement.

Now, precisely because I see myself reflected in everything my colleague Caçula Lida has said, I would like to pose just one question to the Council President: the countries that are under assistance,
Countries facing difficulties have strongly advocated for the retroactive application of bank debts in their separation from state debt.
And, apparently, that was not the site.
But yesterday we heard statements from the highest German and French authorities saying they would treat Ireland as a special case.
What I am asking is whether the Council approved any discriminatory treatment decision for Ireland, different from that reserved for countries like Portugal, Greece, Spain, and others.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, Commissioner, it is a privilege to present the report on the 20 concerns of citizens and businesses regarding
Regarding the functioning of the single market, precisely in this debate with Commissioner Barnier, in which the twentieth anniversary of this market was marked.

A first word to express my gratitude to colleagues from all political groups and, in particular, to the rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs, for their so constructive contributions and their such positive attitude.
It was a pleasure working with everyone, and the report greatly benefited from our combined effort.

We are well aware and proud that, over these 20 years, the single market has been the engine of significant economic and employment opportunities in Europe, transforming the lives of European citizens and European businesses.
Travelling, residing, and working within the spaces of the Union are freedoms accessible to all citizens of the 27 Member States.
For European consumers, the single market means greater freedom of choice and lower prices.
For our companies, the single market means more business opportunities, with access to 500 million consumers, which translates to greater economic growth and more job creation.
To illustrate the progress that the single market has made in Europe since its creation in 1992 until the onset of the crisis,
In 2008, it suffices to note the 2.7 million jobs created and the additional 2.13% growth in GDP.
Today, taking a TOEFL or receiving a TOEFL score while traveling in Europe is cheaper than it was in 2005.
The freedom of movement of people finds its most eloquent expression in the Erasmus program.
Over 2.5 million students have benefited from this European education and mobility exchange program.
Over the past five years, companies have also benefited from a 25% reduction in administrative positions due to single market legislation.
But a question arises: is everything well in the single market?
No, not everything works well.
The economic and financial crisis affecting us has had negative repercussions on the functioning of this market.

Our citizens, in some countries, living with the drama of unemployment and confronted with austerity measures, have developed a skeptical view of Europe and a negative perception regarding the internal market.
People still do not know or sufficiently understand their rights, nor do they know where to find information or assistance.
On the other hand, many Member States unduly delay the transposition of European directives and legislation on the single market, thereby hindering its full potential.

In certain areas of citizens' daily lives, things as simple as, for example, the reimbursement of medical expenses following a temporary stay in another EU country, the opening of a bank account for a student in the Program

Erasmus, the change of energy supplier, the transfer of retirement pensions, the recognition of qualifications, and the registration of a vehicle in another Member State remain highly complex, difficult, or costly procedures.
It is important to address these problems.
That was my concern, as rapporteur.
Therefore, the message conveyed in the report is very clear: more political will is needed, much more political will from the Member States and the European institutions.
Council, especially Council and Commission, in order to govern better and collectively, it is necessary to regain the trust of people and businesses and to facilitate the exercise of their rights.

Finally, I would like to acknowledge the European Commission, represented by Commissioner Barnier, for presenting the Market II Act, 12 priority actions for new growth, which I am certain marks a new stage for the future. Thank you very much.
Madam President, Commissioner Barnier, and dear colleague Regina Bastos, my congratulations on your efforts, already so successful.
When Jacques Delors presided over the European Commission, the single market of the Union was created in 1992.
Delors then synthesized the three basic principles of the single market: competition that stimulates, cooperation that reinforces, and solidarity that unites.
Twenty years later, the economic and financial crisis brought back the threat of national protectionism and it became clear that the internal market is not a completed work.

And the celebration of these twenty years must be leveraged for a relaunch of the single market, with the concern of placing the market at the service of the citizen and not the citizen at the service of the market.
To that end, it is necessary to define priorities, and I would like to discuss one priority in particular.
A common policy is essential for producing and distributing energy at affordable prices for consumers, with a high level of energy efficiency.
through a European energy market, served by cross-border infrastructures, with the possibility of community leverage of investment that represents added European value.
In energy as well, Madam President, the common market will be subjugated.
The European Union’s greatest achievements undoubtedly represent one of the strongest pillars of the Union’s, its Member States’ and its regions’ development.
However, for it to be effective and equitable, it is necessary to emphasize its policies towards equal opportunities for citizens and all regions, promoting internal cohesion within the Union.

In this context, it is essential to recognize that we can only achieve the greatest development of our most remote regions, such as ultraperipheral regions, through their greater integration into the single market.

Regions like the Azores need to continue increasing their competitiveness, improving their conditions of competition, but we will never achieve this if we do not better resolve our accessibility problems in the area of transportation.
We can achieve this through specific instruments that best address the problems raised by our detachment.

Therefore, we argue that the Commission should consider a specific program, of the POSEI transport type, as an essential instrument for the integration of this kind of regions into the internal market.
Thank you very much, Madam President, I begin by saying thank you very much for this excellent debate.
It was a very constructive debate, and a debate that demonstrated that the single market is truly a great achievement of the European project.
I welcome the presence of Minister Mavroyiannis and his participation in this debate, and I thank all colleagues for their constructive approach, and to some, a skeptical one which is understandable.

And to extend a very sincere thank you to Commissioner Barnier for his dedication and the enthusiasm he brings to the discussion of these issues, these internal market problems, and the political will to resolve them.
We still have much to respond to for the citizens.
Citizens are dissatisfied, they are disillusioned, and they expect more from us, expect more from the Council, expect more from the Commission, expect more from the Member States.
This assessment is very useful; this assessment of 20 years is important, but, as many have said here, it is important to open the door to a future perspective.
And the gaze of the future passes through many questions raised here and many measures already announced by the European Commission.
The Digital Single Market, citizen mobility, the reform of the EURES portal, and the European energy market are examples.
eloquent reminders that we still have significant progress to make in the future and that this progress is very important and vital to respond to this era of crisis in which we live.
Citizens are suffering; citizens expect much from politicians and the answers that politicians can provide to the adverse conditions they are enduring.
Therefore, it is important that the single market be one of the responses to the major challenge of competitiveness, employment, and economic growth.
I am certain that all of us, following this celebration of 20 years, are more committed to providing the answers our citizens require.

Mr. President, the Gozez report, together with the report we will prepare on the European Union’s annual growth prospects at the end of this year and which will precede the Spring Council, are two essential components of the so-called European Semester.
This report addresses the recommendations made to each of the member countries by the Council, upon proposal from the Commission, and these recommendations frame, as just mentioned, with
Six-pack and the future two-pack, an extraordinarily strong body reinforcing European control over the economic and budgetary policies of Member States.

Finding a balance and anticipating control alongside autonomy and legitimacy at the national level is not easy, and it has declined to a point of imposition, particularly of discipline, and may ultimately result in a serious package of sanctions.

Concerning TUPEC, I would like to briefly comment that it is important that the Council, which is absent here today, grants a negotiating mandate to its negotiators, consistent with the ambition of swiftly concluding this package, this TUPEC.

But more European coordination, returning to the subject, means less control by countries over their own destiny, which necessitates a subtle balance, but also an increased demand for the quality of recommendations made to countries in at least three or four dimensions.

First, it is important to ensure coherence between medium- and long-term objectives, which include growth, employment, and real convergence, and short-term recommendations, focused primarily on discipline and nominal convergence. Second, there must be coherence

drawing the conclusions to be derived from the analysis of macroeconomic imbalances, particularly regarding the asymmetric impact of common policies and the negative externalities of spillover effects from certain national policies on other countries.

Thirdly, it is necessary that we agree that there is a minimum threshold of social, economic, and labor rights that these recommendations cannot exceed. Finally, it is important that the quality of the recommendations be assessed in terms of the results achieved, which is far from being the case thus far.

Madam President, I have already finished speaking, and I would simply like to thank Mr. Gozez for his spirit of collaboration, and I hope that he will take an even further step in that spirit, so as to broaden the base of consensus surrounding his report, and that this spirit will also endure with respect to next year.
It is true, as has been mentioned many times, that there are many things we do not know about shale gas extraction.
But there are also many that we already know and it is advisable not to forget.

We know, for example, that each shale gas extraction operation utilizes over 19 million liters of potable water, which is sufficient to supply, for one year, 1,000 European citizens in terms of their needs.

We also know that with each shale gas extraction, in each of the operations, approximately 300 pieces of cotton swabs—which can total up to 300 tons of chemicals—are pumped into the soil, with around 80 of these remaining in the soil and not leaving it.

We also know that, with each extraction of gas X, radioactive elements and heavy metals are released into the subsurface, and these, together with the evaporation of the toxic waste resulting from the process, constitute an effective threat to public health.
This is a risk of contamination of potable water resources, and it is a contamination that is real and imminent.

Knowing this, we know that shale gas extraction is also a response that appears easy, that only considers the immediate, the industry, and profit, ignoring the populations, the future, and the environment.

But this is also the Europe that knows, within this forum, that water is an essential, vital, and important resource, that knows how to protect the health of citizens and must protect it, that seeks to make agreements to avoid emissions and to promote energy efficiency, because we know that environmental standards are important, environmental standards and those of health.
Therefore, when one does not know everything, being internally consistent is the minimum.
And they may want to do so, but do not do it in our name, nor in the name of the citizens who are here to represent us.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, indeed, the past years have shown us how the Economic and Monetary Union did not withstand the crisis.
We have also shown that we have a European institutional architecture riddled with loopholes, particularly the institutional architecture of the euro.
That is why the report presented here and the proposal presented are so far above the mark in terms of vision compared to what is proposed by the governments.

But also, as the rapporteur said, we are on ground where political choices must be made, and it is for this reason that I would like to clarify the reasons why we have some problems and cannot support this report.
The first concerns issues related to conditionalities.

What we see and continue to have is a narrative in which solidarity between different countries can only exist when everything has been fulfilled regarding the stability and growth plan, regarding the intergovernmental agreement, the pact for
It is a set of measures that impose nothing but massive doses of austerity in the peripheries and also a set of recessive measures that, as we have already seen, are not working.
A second reason relates to banking union.

The rapporteur presents the banking supervision mechanism very well, but it is so necessary that we cannot evade the essential, and the essential is slipping away to the extent that we continue to add.

We are clustered in national systems, which means we are all together in banking policy, we are all together in banking supervision, but we are all separated when something goes wrong and, therefore, taxpayers will continue to pay.
A third point concerns the issue of common debt and the issuance of eurobonds.
Here, once again, the possibility of the emission of ordinary water is considered, but only when it is already too late.

Because we need common debt, and it's not just when the deficits of excessive debts have been corrected, because with the policies we are following, they will never be corrected; on the contrary, they will be increasingly aggravated to the despair of an entire population group.

Therefore, I want to conclude, Mr. President, by saying that, despite all efforts, I believe we have here a very clear example of that, together, we could still rise, but divided, we will surely fall. And that was why it was important to have gone even further.
Madam President, Madam Ferreira, please, there are always margins for progress, but for Portugal, the support of the European Union has been fundamental in recent years.
Portugal has transformed from a country whose competitiveness was based on cheap labor into a country of highly skilled and sophisticated labor.
But, when a country exports, it must have conditions for where [the goods are going].

Therefore, it is important that some countries with surpluses open their doors to the re-qualified exports of countries that originated from a specialization profile that was absolutely unsustainable.

A final note to state that immigration cannot be the solution, that skilled labor, where European Union support was utilized, should not now be lost through a massive export of the most qualified to countries with the capacity to accommodate them.
This is dramatic and completely jeopardizes our future.

Mr. President, small-scale fisheries deserve specific protection under the Common Fisheries Policy, not only because they promote socioeconomic cohesion and ensure the livelihoods of many families, but also because they represent a factor in the retention of these communities along coastal areas.
Their economic and social sustainability should constitute an objective, ensuring them a differentiated fishing regime that prioritizes access to resources.
It allows for proximity management and protects the fishing rights that benefit fishing professionals in these communities against transferable fishing rights.
It is equally important, for its sustainability, to consider the water access regime, especially in waters or regions with biogeographical basins.
Marine environments with limited continental shelves and scarce resources concentrated on seamounts and fishing grounds that must have protected access.

Within the context of liberalization and the crisis affecting vulnerable regions, it must also be ensured that products originating from international trade comply with the same requirements as those imported by the Union.
Mr. President, President of the Exercise Council, Commissioner, I will be very brief, because I assure you that what is at issue here is essentially a political point, it is not a political point.
A financial point, and the question that arises, is the following: whether we want the European Union to make a difference in the context of the crisis, or whether we want to worsen the crisis.

Most European countries are currently making a tremendous effort, from the perspective of their public finances, to overcome the crisis in a competitive manner, in a way that can position their countries.

The European Union, on a global scale, possesses significant capacity for competitiveness and competition, but it is obvious that without investment, there can be no growth and this crisis cannot be overcome.
If the European Union insists on these drastic cuts, particularly in cohesion policy and the common agricultural policy, what this will mean is that the countries that are making a tremendous

As a result of this effort, they will not manage to grow, and this plan that we have accepted in all countries for the European Union will fail—sound accounts with prospects for growth and competitiveness.

The sole and principal instrument for this is precisely this multi-annual financial framework, and therefore, if we want the European Union to succeed and this policy to be an exemplary policy for other countries, we must invest in the budget for the financial perspectives.
